102-009.text: Geography, the world, is in it,The Great Sea, the brood of islands, Polynesia, the coast beyond,The coast you henceforth are facing--you Libertad! from your Westerngolden shores,The countries there with their populations, the millions en-masseare curiously here,The swarming market-places, the temples with idols ranged along thesides or at the end, bonze, brahmin, and llama,Mandarin, farmer, merchant, mechanic, and fisherman,The singing-girl and the dancing-girl, the ecstatic persons, thesecluded emperors,Confucius himself, the great poets and heroes, the warriors, the castes,all,Trooping up, crowding from all directions, from the Altay mountains,From Thibet, from the four winding and far-flowing rivers of China,From the southern peninsulas and the demi-continental islands, fromMalaysia,These and whatever belongs to them palpable show forth to me, andare seiz’d by me,And I am seiz’d by them, and friendlily held by them,Till as here them all I chant, Libertad! for themselves and for you.
caption: A collage-like image with a map of the world in the center. Surrounding it are images of the Great Sea, various islands and coasts, and different types of people from all across the world - from farmers to emperors, from temples to marketplaces. All are coming together and being embraced by the central figure of a person named Libertad.

A mixed media canvas encapsulating the diversity of the world through the representation of people and places sparkling with vibrant colors and intricate details. The globe is mapped out, highlighting Polynesia and western Golden shores, where inhabitants of various races and cultures gather together in marketplaces, temples, and numerous social activities. From warriors to poets, farmers to merchants, heroes to emperors, all form a large cosmopolitan family, warmly united under the banner of Libertad.

102-010.text: For I too raising my voice join the ranks of this pageant,I am the chanter, I chant aloud over the pageant,I chant the world on my Western sea,I chant copious the islands beyond, thick as stars in the sky,I chant the new empire grander than any before, as in a vision itcomes to me,I chant America the mistress, I chant a greater supremacy,I chant projected a thousand blooming cities yet in time on thosegroups of sea-islands,My sail-ships and steam-ships threading the archipelagoes,My stars and stripes fluttering in the wind,Commerce opening, the sleep of ages having done its work, racesreborn, refresh’d,Lives, works resumed--the object I know not--but the old, the Asiaticrenew’d as it must be,Commencing from this day surrounded by the world.
caption: A grand parade is taking place with a plethora of flags and banners waving in the wind. The center of attention is a chantress loudly singing about America's supremacy, its empire, and its many islands. The scene is filled with the promise of new life, new races, and renewed culture.

The painting is a panoramic view of the Western sea, with an abundance of beautiful islands in the distance. The painting celebrates the grandeur and beauty of American empire, with images of ships and flags waving in the wind, people working and living their lives, all surrounded by the vast expanse of the sea. The style is impressionistic, with vivid colors and dynamic brushstrokes capturing the energy and excitement of the scene.

102-011.text: 3And you Libertad of the world!You shall sit in the middle well-pois’d thousands and thousands of years,As to-day from one side the nobles of Asia come to you,As to-morrow from the other side the queen of England sends hereldest son to you.
caption: A statue of Libertad, poised and balanced in the center, with a steady stream of visitors paying their respects from both sides - one from Asian nobles, and the other from the queen of England's eldest son.

Surrealism. An enormous, long-haired figure, half-woman half-man, sits nonchalantly in a large, lavish throne, surrounded by thousands and thousands of jubilant people from all around the globe. Nobles in flowing robes approach from one side while the Queen of England sends her eldest son from the other.

102-012.text: The sign is reversing, the orb is enclosed,The ring is circled, the journey is done,The box-lid is but perceptibly open’d, nevertheless the perfumepours copiously out of the whole box.
caption: A magic box with a reversing sign on it which encloses an orb. The box has just been opened ever so slightly, yet the scent inside the box is escaping and spreading out into the world.

This picture, in the style of Surrealism, depicts an orb encased in a box with a lid that is slightly ajar. The box is surrounded by a ring and a sign that appears to be reversed. Despite the lid being slightly open, a strong scent emanates from the box.

102-013.text: Young Libertad! with the venerable Asia, the all-mother,Be considerate with her now and ever hot Libertad, for you are all,Bend your proud neck to the long-off mother now sending messagesover the archipelagoes to you,Bend your proud neck low for once, young Libertad.
caption: A young person, Libertad, standing tall and proud with an image of a mother figure, Asia, in the background. The mother figure is sending messages across various islands. Libertad is then shown bowing their head in respect towards the mother figure.

Photorealistic with a closeup of a young person's face looking towards the horizon where several islands can be seen in the distance. The person's neck is bowed down in respect to the maternal figure of Asia standing behind them.

102-014.text: Here the children straying westward so long? so wide the tramping?Were the precedent dim ages debouching westward from Paradise so long?Were the centuries steadily footing it that way, all the whileunknown, for you, for reasons?
caption: A group of children walking towards the west, lost and wandering on an unknown path. Behind them, the silhouette of a distant paradise can be seen, and the journey appears to have been going on for centuries, with no clear destination in sight.
Surrealism. A group of children walking in the opposite direction of a parade of shadowy, faceless figures. A vibrant, colorful garden lies unnoticed in the background.

102-015.text: They are justified, they are accomplish’d, they shall now be turn’dthe other way also, to travel toward you thence,They shall now also march obediently eastward for your sake Libertad.
caption: A group of accomplished individuals turning around while walking on a road, and marching towards the east, guided by Libertad.

The picture shows a group of marching figures passing by a turning point. They are facing west, but are now turning around to face east in order to head towards the viewer. The overall tone is one of obedience and loyalty to the viewer (Libertad). The visual style is a mix of abstract and surrealism.

103-001.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-001.text: Out of the cradle endlessly rocking,Out of the mocking-bird’s throat, the musical shuttle,Out of the Ninth-month midnight,Over the sterile sands and the fields beyond, where the childleaving his bed wander’d alone, bareheaded, barefoot,Down from the shower’d halo,Up from the mystic play of shadows twining and twisting as if theywere alive,Out from the patches of briers and blackberries,From the memories of the bird that chanted to me,From your memories sad brother, from the fitful risings and fallings I heard,From under that yellow half-moon late-risen and swollen as if with tears,From those beginning notes of yearning and love there in the mist,From the thousand responses of my heart never to cease,From the myriad thence-arous’d words,From the word stronger and more delicious than any,From such as now they start the scene revisiting,As a flock, twittering, rising, or overhead passing,Borne hither, ere all eludes me, hurriedly,A man, yet by these tears a little boy again,Throwing myself on the sand, confronting the waves,I, chanter of pains and joys, uniter of here and hereafter,Taking all hints to use them, but swiftly leaping beyond them,A reminiscence sing.
caption: A picture of a barefoot, bareheaded child wandering alone in the barren fields beneath a swollen moon. The image is filled with memories and emotions, such as the haunting notes of a bird's song and the relentless yearning of the heart. The scene is revisited as a flock of birds flutter overhead, while a man lies on the sand, confronting the waves. It is a poignant reminder of the joys and sorrows of life, and the fleeting nature of our experiences.

Surrealism. A small, barefoot, bareheaded child wanders alone over fields and sands, while mystical shadows twist and dance around him. A man lies on the sand, immersed in memories and emotions that rush back to him: the sounds of birdsong, the yearning for love, and the aching joy of life itself.

103-002.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-002.text: Once Paumanok,When the lilac-scent was in the air and Fifth-month grass was growing,Up this seashore in some briers,Two feather’d guests from Alabama, two together,And their nest, and four light-green eggs spotted with brown,And every day the he-bird to and fro near at hand,And every day the she-bird crouch’d on her nest, silent, with bright eyes,And every day I, a curious boy, never too close, never disturbingthem,Cautiously peering, absorbing, translating.
caption: A young boy cautiously observes two feathered guests from Alabama who have made their home in some briers near the seashore on Paumanok Island. The air is heavy with the scent of lilacs and the grass is long and green. The male bird spends his days flitting back and forth nearby while the female perches on her nest, silently watching with bright eyes. The nest holds four light-green eggs, each spotted with brown. The boy is curious but respectful, observing and learning quietly.

Impressionistic. A painting of a beach with a background of lilacs and green grass, with two birds in the foreground watching over their nest filled with spotted eggs. The image shows a young boy watching from a distance, intrigued by the scene before him.

103-003.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-003.text: Shine! shine! shine!Pour down your warmth, great sun.’While we bask, we two together.
caption: A picture of two people holding hands while standing under the bright and warm sun. The sun is shining brightly in the blue sky while the two people stand close to each other, basking in the warmth of the sun.
With a warm, glowing aesthetic, an image is depicted of two people sitting closely together, basking in the sun’s rays as they shine down, illuminating the world around them.

103-004.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-004.text: Two together!Winds blow south, or winds blow north,Day come white, or night come black,Home, or rivers and mountains from home,Singing all time, minding no time,While we two keep together.
caption: The picture shows two people holding hands and standing against a backdrop of changing weather and landscapes, be it mountains or rivers. They are singing and seem to be lost in their own world, without any worries about time.

In the foreground, two silhouetted figures hold hands. Behind them, the weather and time of day shift between a glowing sunrise and a dark, starry night. The landscape changes from a cozy home to rugged mountains and flowing rivers, yet the two keep holding hands and walking together without a care for time. The image is stylized as a simple yet intricate paper-cut art piece.

103-005.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-005.text: Till of a sudden,May-be kill’d, unknown to her mate,One forenoon the she-bird crouch’d not on the nest,Nor return’d that afternoon, nor the next,Nor ever appear’d again.
caption: A nest with eggs and the silhouette of the male and female bird in the background. Suddenly, the female bird disappears and never returns.

A photograph in a nature magazine with shallow focus on a bird's nest on a branch, surrounded by green foliage. The nest appears empty and the mate bird looks around in confusion, hinting that this photograph may tell a story of loss and disappearance.

103-006.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-006.text: And thenceforward all summer in the sound of the sea,And at night under the full of the moon in calmer weather,Over the hoarse surging of the sea,Or flitting from brier to brier by day,I saw, I heard at intervals the remaining one, the he-bird,The solitary guest from Alabama.
caption: A setting sun on the ocean with a single bird perched on a brier bush in the foreground. The moon rises high in the background, casting a calm reflection over the water.

The visual style is impressionism.  A peaceful beach scene at night, with the full moon casting soft light over the waves. Amidst the sounds of the crashing waves, a lone male bird is intermittently heard and spotted perched on various shrubs.

103-007.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-007.text: Blow! blow! blow!Blow up sea-winds along Paumanok’s shore;I wait and I wait till you blow my mate to me.
caption: A silhouette of a person standing next to the ocean shore with their hair and clothes blowing in the wind as they look out to the sea expectantly, waiting for their mate to arrive.

Photography through the lens of a black and white film camera. The picture shows a person standing on the seashore, their hair and clothes wind-tousled and their back turned to the camera, facing the sea. The frame is centered on the individual and their body language suggests hopeful anticipation for their loved one who is yet to arrive.

103-008.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-008.text: Yes, when the stars glisten’d,All night long on the prong of a moss-scallop’d stake,Down almost amid the slapping waves,Sat the lone singer wonderful causing tears.
caption: A lone figure sitting on a moss-covered stake, silhouetted against a starry sky. The crashing waves create an emotional atmosphere, as tears stream down the face of the listener.
Photorealistic. A solitary singer sits on a mossy stake in the middle of a tumultuous sea at night, beneath the twinkling stars, evoking an emotional response from the observer.

103-009.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-009.text: He call’d on his mate,He pour’d forth the meanings which I of all men know.
caption: A man standing on the shore with his arms wide open, calling out to the sea. The ocean waves appear to be carrying his thoughts and emotions, as depicted by the abstract patterns and shapes emerging from the water.
Abstract Expressionism. A blurry, colorful image with a bird's silhouette in the forefront, and lines indicating sound waves emanating from it.

103-010.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-010.text: Yes my brother I know,The rest might not, but I have treasur’d every note,For more than once dimly down to the beach gliding,Silent, avoiding the moonbeams, blending myself with the shadows,Recalling now the obscure shapes, the echoes, the sounds and sightsafter their sorts,The white arms out in the breakers tirelessly tossing,I, with bare feet, a child, the wind wafting my hair,Listen’d long and long.
caption: A figure standing on a dark beach, with moonlight casting shadows all around. The figure appears to be listening intently, with their hair being blown by the wind. The ocean can be seen in the background, with white arms emerging from the waves.
Realistic Watercolor Style. A shadowy figure stooping low on a beach, with moonbeams shining against the coast with white waves banging against it, their hair blowing in the wind, listening intently.

103-011.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-011.text: Listen’d to keep, to sing, now translating the notes,Following you my brother.
caption: Two people walking side by side, one holding a piece of sheet music while the other listens intently. They are both in mid-step, as if they are moving to the music.

A silhouette of two individuals, one taller than the other, walking in a forest with musical notes floating beside them, suggesting they are singing and enjoying each other's company. The overall visual style is impressionism, with high contrast and vibrant colors.

103-012.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-012.text: Soothe! soothe! soothe!Close on its wave soothes the wave behind,And again another behind embracing and lapping, every one close,But my love soothes not me, not me.
caption: A serene beach with gentle waves washing ashore. In the foreground, a person looks out at the ocean, seemingly troubled despite the calming atmosphere.

With a surrealist art style, the picture depicts a turbulent ocean with a figure in the foreground reaching out towards an indistinct wave. The waves behind it seem to condense and swell, forming a series of embracing figures that threaten to engulf the central figure who remains untouched and unmoved.

103-013.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-013.text: Low hangs the moon, it rose late,It is lagging--O I think it is heavy with love, with love.
caption: A moon in a blue sky surrounded by clouds. The moon seems to be hanging low, as if struggling to rise. The weight of love seems to be pulling it down.

The moon appears as a large, drooping ball in the night sky, appearing to sink lower as time passes, almost as if it's weighted down with a profound sense of love. The visual style is melancholic with a hint of whimsy, using a subdued earthy palette with shades of blue and warm yellows.

103-014.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-014.text: O madly the sea pushes upon the land,With love, with love.
caption: A turbulent sea with waves crashing onto the shore in a passionate and loving manner.
Expressionist. A tumultuous sea crashes against rocks and cliffs, its waves appearing violent but imbued with an intense, passionate love.

103-015.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-015.text: O night! do I not see my love fluttering out among the breakers?What is that little black thing I see there in the white?
caption: A person stands on the shore at night, looking out towards the ocean where waves are breaking. They seem to see their loved one out there, and notice a small dark shape in the white of the waves.

The picture is in the style of impressionism - huge waves crashing on the shore at midnight, a vague figure reaching out toward the sea, and a little black object glimpsed amidst the white's frothy crests.

103-016.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-016.text: Loud! loud! loud!Loud I call to you, my love!High and clear I shoot my voice over the waves,Surely you must know who is here, is here,You must know who I am, my love.
caption: A person standing on a cliff by the sea, shouting with their hands cupped around their mouth, calling for their loved one.
Pop Art. A figure with their head tilted upward, screaming with vibrant, colorful waves as the background.

103-017.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-017.text: Low-hanging moon!What is that dusky spot in your brown yellow?O it is the shape, the shape of my mate.’O moon do not keep her from me any longer.
caption: A dark silhouette of a person pointing towards the low-hanging moon with a pleading expression on their face.

The picture is done in surreal style, with a big bright moon in the sky that is hanging very low. In the center, there is a human figure gesturing towards the moon, wanting it to bring his lover back.

103-018.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-018.text: Land! land! O land!Whichever way I turn, O I think you could give me my mate back againif you only would,For I am almost sure I see her dimly whichever way I look.
caption: A person standing on the deck of a ship, gazing out at the horizon with hopeful eyes. They seem to see something in the distance that they believe is their lost partner, and are yearning for the land to bring them back together.

This would be a melancholic painting, with dark colors, depicting an ocean in the foreground and a distant, misty shoreline in the background. In the center of the painting, a sad figure stands, staring out at the sea, hoping to be reunited with their lost love.

103-019.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-019.text: O rising stars!Perhaps the one I want so much will rise, will rise with some of you.
caption: A silhouette of a person looking up at the night sky filled with stars. The person is pointing to the sky, indicating they are searching for a specific star that they hope will rise among the rest.
The artwork is done in a celestial style, featuring a vast night sky with various stars. One shining brighter than the rest, giving the impression that it may be the star the viewer is searching for.

103-020.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-020.text: O throat! O trembling throat!Sound clearer through the atmosphere!Pierce the woods, the earth,Somewhere listening to catch you must be the one I want.
caption: An open mouth, singing with a strong and powerful voice that reverberates through the atmosphere. The woods and earth are alive with the sound and someone is listening intently, hoping to catch a glimpse of the source of the beautiful music.

In a minimalistic style, the image captures the essence of sound waves travelling through the atmosphere, bringing life to the still woods until it reaches an unknown listener, who waits for it with bated breath.

103-021.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-021.text: Shake out carols!Solitary here, the night’s carols!Carols of lonesome love! death’s carols!Carols under that lagging, yellow, waning moon!O under that moon where she droops almost down into the sea!O reckless despairing carols.
caption: A figure standing alone at night, singing songs of love and death under a drooping, yellow moon. The songs are filled with pain and despair.

I would suggest a photograph with a dark and moody atmosphere, taken at night or dusk. In the foreground, an individual stands alone, arms outstretched, as if singing. In the background, a yellow moon droops close to the horizon over the sea.

103-022.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-022.text: But soft! sink low!Soft! let me just murmur,And do you wait a moment you husky-nois’d sea,For somewhere I believe I heard my mate responding to me,So faint, I must be still, be still to listen,But not altogether still, for then she might not come immediately to me.
caption: A person kneeling on the shore, quiet and attentive, listening to the sea in the background. They believe they heard their companion, and they pause in anticipation of a response.

A picture of an individual crouching down with their ear to the ground, listening intently. The background is a vast and calm ocean with the faint image of another person waiting in the distance. The visual style is a soft-focus or impressionistic art piece.

103-023.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-023.text: Hither my love!Here I am! here!With this just-sustain’d note I announce myself to you,This gentle call is for you my love, for you.
caption: A person, arms open with a welcoming expression, calling out to another person off-camera. The surroundings exude warmth and love.
The visual style would be a surreal portrait. It shows a person with outstretched arms and a gentle face calling out to their beloved, with a floating musical note in the background of the scene.

103-024.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-024.text: Do not be decoy’d elsewhere,That is the whistle of the wind, it is not my voice,That is the fluttering, the fluttering of the spray,Those are the shadows of leaves.
caption: In the midst of a forest, a person is standing and looking around. The wind is blowing and shaking the leaves of the trees, casting shadows on the person. The sound of the wind and the fluttering of a nearby stream's sprays can be heard.

In a monochromatic style (black and white), the photo is a nature scenery with a tree next to a river during a windy day. The leaves are swaying while branches move along with the wind. The water is showing ripples, creating shadows and a ''fluttering'' effect with its waves.

103-025.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-025.text: O darkness! O in vain!O I am very sick and sorrowful
caption: A silhouette of a person standing alone in a dark and desolate place, with a heavy heart and downtrodden spirit.
Minimalism. An empty, dark room that feels heavy, with a figure slumped in the corner, expressing pain and sadness.

103-026.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-026.text: O brown halo in the sky near the moon, drooping upon the sea!O troubled reflection in the sea!O throat! O throbbing heart!And I singing uselessly, uselessly all the night.
caption: A night-time seascape with a brown halo near the moon, casting a reflection on the troubled sea. The visible throat conveying the throbbing heart. A figure is singing, but it appears to be fruitless.

Surrealist. An image of a brown halo suspended over the moon that is dropping onto a restless, turbulent sea. The image also includes a disembodied throat and heart, and a solitary figure futilely singing into the darkness.

103-027.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-027.text: O past! O happy life! O songs of joy!In the air, in the woods, over fields,Loved! loved! loved! loved! loved!But my mate no more, no more with me!We two together no more.
caption: A picture of a person standing in a landscape with arms outstretched, appearing to be in a joyful state. However, there is a sense of loss as there is no longer a partner present.

In a melancholic and surrealistic style, an individual stands alone in a vast, empty field surrounded by a lush, expansive forest and a rich blue sky. The person is facing away, looking out into the distance as if searching for something, lonely and yearning for a long-gone past.

103-028.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-028.text: The aria sinking,All else continuing, the stars shining,The winds blowing, the notes of the bird continuous echoing,With angry moans the fierce old mother incessantly moaning,On the sands of Paumanok’s shore gray and rustling,The yellow half-moon enlarged, sagging down, drooping, the face ofthe sea almost touching,The boy ecstatic, with his bare feet the waves, with his hair theatmosphere dallying,The love in the heart long pent, now loose, now at last tumultuouslybursting,The aria’s meaning, the ears, the soul, swiftly depositing,The strange tears down the cheeks coursing,The colloquy there, the trio, each uttering,The undertone, the savage old mother incessantly crying,To the boy’s soul’s questions sullenly timing, some drown’d secret hissing,To the outsetting bard.
caption: A boy stands joyously at the edge of a grey and rustling shore under a sagging, half-moon. The stars are shining as the winds blow and birds sing. The boy plays in the waves with his bare feet and hair blowing in the wind. His heart is bursting with love and emotion as he listens to a haunting aria. Tears stream down his cheeks as he engages in a silent dialogue with the surrounding natural world, with the angry moans of the sea echoing in the background.

Surrealism. An image of a boy standing on a beach, staring out at the ocean. The moon above him is yellow and drooping. The ocean is choppy, windswept, and sea foam dots the shoreline. The boy is looking up at the sky, his hair tousled by the wind, as a single tear runs down his cheek.

103-029.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-029.text: Demon or bird! (said the boy’s soul,)Is it indeed toward your mate you sing? or is it really to me?For I, that was a child, my tongue’s use sleeping, now I have heard you,Now in a moment I know what I am for, I awake,And already a thousand singers, a thousand songs, clearer, louderand more sorrowful than yours,A thousand warbling echoes have started to life within me, never to die.
caption: A wide-eyed child staring up at a singing bird/demon in the forest. The child's expression changes from curiosity to realization and awakening as they suddenly understand their purpose in life.

The art style is surrealism. The image depicts a young boy standing in front of a being that is half-demon, half-bird, with a beak and blackened wings. The boy's soul questions if the creature is singing to him or to its mate, and as if in answer, a thousand ethereal singers erupt from his chest, filling the air with an echoing melody.

103-030.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-030.text: O you singer solitary, singing by yourself, projecting me,O solitary me listening, never more shall I cease perpetuating you,Never more shall I escape, never more the reverberations,Never more the cries of unsatisfied love be absent from me,Never again leave me to be the peaceful child I was before whatthere in the night,By the sea under the yellow and sagging moon,The messenger there arous’d, the fire, the sweet hell within,The unknown want, the destiny of me.
caption: A solitary singer standing near the sea, singing passionately with a fire burning within. A listener, entranced by the music, absorbs and perpetuates the emotion conveyed by the song. The yellow, sagging moon hangs overhead, as unsatisfied love echoes through the night. The destiny of the listener is forever changed by the haunting melody.

The photograph is set during night time at the beach. In the photograph, there's a single singer standing on the shore singing, projecting their emotions. The viewer, represented by a person sitting and listening to the singer, is unable to escape from the reverberations of the emotions expressed. The setting under the yellow moon and the presence of the unknown destiny and suppressed desires add to the surrealism of the photograph.

103-031.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-031.text: O give me the clue! (it lurks in the night here somewhere,)O if I am to have so much, let me have more!
caption: The picture shows a person in the dark searching for something. It is clear they desire to have more but do not exactly know where to look.

Abstract expressionism. A dark and expansive canvas with erratic bursts of vibrant color that represents the elusive search for a hidden clue in the night. The viewer can feel the desire for something more.

103-032.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-032.text: A word then, (for I will conquer it,)The word final, superior to all,Subtle, sent up--what is it?--I listen;Are you whispering it, and have been all the time, you sea-waves?Is that it from your liquid rims and wet sands?
caption: An individual stands on the shore, listening intently to the sound of the ocean waves. They appear to be seeking a final and superior word from the whispers of the sea.

The picture is a simple one, with an expanse of blue waves rolling towards a sandy beach. In the background, we see a mountain range, and the sky is overcast. The focus of the image, however, is the person standing at the edge of the water, with their head tilted towards the sea, as if listening to a whisper carried by the waves.

103-033.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-033.text: Whereto answering, the sea,Delaying not, hurrying not,Whisper’d me through the night, and very plainly before daybreak,Lisp’d to me the low and delicious word death,And again death, death, death, deathHissing melodious, neither like the bird nor like my arous’d child’s heart,But edging near as privately for me rustling at my feet,Creeping thence steadily up to my ears and laving me softly all over,Death, death, death, death, death.
caption: The picture shows a vast sea under the night sky. The sea is calm and not in a hurry, but it whispers to the observer about death. The word "death" repeats multiple times in a hissing, melodious way. The feeling of death creeps up from the observer's feet and slowly envelops them.
Surrealism. A portrait with a gloomy atmosphere, showing the sea whispering to the person in a dream. Small elongated spirits surround them, hissing the word "death ."

103-034.poem: Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking
103-034.text: Which I do not forget.But fuse the song of my dusky demon and brother,That he sang to me in the moonlight on Paumanok’s gray beach,With the thousand responsive songs at random,My own songs awaked from that hour,And with them the key, the word up from the waves,The word of the sweetest song and all songs,That strong and delicious word which, creeping to my feet,(Or like some old crone rocking the cradle, swathed in sweetgarments, bending aside,)The sea whisper’d me.
caption: A figure stands on a gray beach at night, surrounded by the sounds of a thousand songs. Memories of a song whispered by a demon and the sound of waves crashing on the shore merge into a single, powerful melody. The figure is entranced, with a sweet and delicious feeling surging through them, as if the sea itself is singing to them.

Impressionism. A figure stands on a gray beach, lit by the moonlight. They are surrounded by the sound of a thousand different songs, as they remember being inspired by their dusky demon and brother. The sound of the sea whispers the key word of the sweetest song and all songs, encasing them in a gentle, melodic cocoon.

104-001.poem: As I Ebb’d with the Ocean of Life
104-001.text: 1As I ebb’d with the ocean of life,As I wended the shores I know,As I walk’d where the ripples continually wash you Paumanok,Where they rustle up hoarse and sibilant,Where the fierce old mother endlessly cries for her castaways,I musing late in the autumn day, gazing off southward,Held by this electric self out of the pride of which I utter poems,Was seiz’d by the spirit that trails in the lines underfoot,The rim, the sediment that stands for all the water and all the landof the globe.
caption: A person walking along the shores during autumn, with waves crashing onto the beach. They are lost in thought, captured by the power of nature that surrounds them. The beauty and vastness of the world's water and land is represented in the sediment and rim of the wave lines at their feet.

A photograph of a beach, with leaves rustling around the feet of a person in the foreground. The ocean washes up on the shore, while in the distance the fierce wind can be heard. The picture is taken during the autumn in a moody, impressionistic style.

104-002.poem: As I Ebb’d with the Ocean of Life
104-002.text: Fascinated, my eyes reverting from the south, dropt, to follow thoseslender windrows,Chaff, straw, splinters of wood, weeds, and the sea-gluten,Scum, scales from shining rocks, leaves of salt-lettuce, left by the tide,Miles walking, the sound of breaking waves the other side of me,Paumanok there and then as I thought the old thought of likenesses,These you presented to me you fish-shaped island,As I wended the shores I know,As I walk’d with that electric self seeking types.
caption: A person stands on the beach, looking towards the ocean. The wind is blowing and there are various debris and natural elements scattered around, such as chaff, splinters of wood, and sea-gluten. The sound of waves breaking can be heard in the distance. In the background is the island of Paumanok. The person is deep in thought, contemplating the similarities between these natural elements and seeking to understand their significance.

The picture is a black and white photograph in the candid style, showing a person walking along a beach. The wind has caused small pieces of debris and sea plants to pile up on the shoreline. The person pauses to look at the objects and thinks about the similarities between them, Paumanok visible in the distance.

104-003.poem: As I Ebb’d with the Ocean of Life
104-003.text: 2As I wend to the shores I know not,As I list to the dirge, the voices of men and women wreck’d,As I inhale the impalpable breezes that set in upon me,As the ocean so mysterious rolls toward me closer and closer,I too but signify at the utmost a little wash’d-up drift,A few sands and dead leaves to gather,Gather, and merge myself as part of the sands and drift.
caption: An individual stands on a shore, listening to the mournful sounds of people in distress. The ocean draws closer, mysterious and powerful. The individual accepts their own insignificance in comparison, willing to become a part of the sands and drifts that surround them.

The visual style of the picture can be Impressionism. A person stands at the edge of an ocean, listening to the mournful cries of drowned people. The waves approach as the person becomes one with the sand, on which a few leaves have washed ashore, to be gathered as driftwood.

104-004.poem: As I Ebb’d with the Ocean of Life
104-004.text: O baffled, balk’d, bent to the very earth,Oppress’d with myself that I have dared to open my mouth,Aware now that amid all that blab whose echoes recoil upon me I havenot once had the least idea who or what I am,But that before all my arrogant poems the real Me stands yetuntouch’d, untold, altogether unreach’d,Withdrawn far, mocking me with mock-congratulatory signs and bows,With peals of distant ironical laughter at every word I have written,Pointing in silence to these songs, and then to the sand beneath.
caption: A person is seen with their head down, appearing defeated and crushed. They seem to be struggling with their own identity and questioning their purpose in life. There is a sense of frustration as they realize that their words and actions have yet to reveal the true essence of who they are. Mocking laughter echoes in the distance as they feel like they are not reaching their full potential, and they are left alone to contemplate their thoughts as they stare at the sand below.

Surrealism. A person stands bent and distorted, looking pained and oppressed. Echoes surround them, making them unaware of who they are, while the "real me" stands defiantly untold and unattainable with sounds of mocking laughter in the distance. A symbolic hand points out both towards the world around and beneath them.

104-005.poem: As I Ebb’d with the Ocean of Life
104-005.text: I perceive I have not really understood any thing, not a singleobject, and that no man ever can,Nature here in sight of the sea taking advantage of me to dart uponme and sting me,Because I have dared to open my mouth to sing at all.
caption: A person stands by the sea, looking pensive and contemplative. A bee has just stung them, and they seem to be in pain. The person is singing, but there is a sense that they are not fully understanding everything around them.
Surrealistic. A person standing on a rocky cliff, with the vast sea behind, is depicted as being stung by swirling, darting objects, while their mouth is portrayed as screaming in song.

104-006.poem: As I Ebb’d with the Ocean of Life
104-006.text: 3You oceans both, I close with you,We murmur alike reproachfully rolling sands and drift, knowing not why,These little shreds indeed standing for you and me and all.
caption: A photograph capturing the rhythm of the sea waves crashing against the shore. The sands and drifts seem to be whispering reproachfully, but incomprehensibly. The many little fragments of sand together represent everyone and everything present there.

The photograph is captured in high contrast black and white style. A vast ocean on one side and a desolate beach on the other. The waves and sands are in motion, murmuring similar reproach to each other, while torn pieces of paper scattered around the shoreline represent the fleeting and insignificant nature of life.

104-007.poem: As I Ebb’d with the Ocean of Life
104-007.text: You friable shore with trails of debris,You fish-shaped island, I take what is underfoot,What is yours is mine my father.
caption: A person standing on a rocky beach with scattered debris trailed around. The person is looking at a nearby fish-shaped island in the distance. They seem to be claiming ownership of what they see, as if saying "what is yours is mine my father" to the scenery before them.

Surrealist. A person standing on a rocky shore that crumbles easily, with debris trailing behind them like a comet tail. In the distance is an island that is shaped like a fish, with items strewn chaotically around it. The confusion of property boundaries is symbolized by a hand offering and receiving simultaneously.

104-008.poem: As I Ebb’d with the Ocean of Life
104-008.text: I too Paumanok,I too have bubbled up, floated the measureless float, and beenwash’d on your shores,I too am but a trail of drift and debris,I too leave little wrecks upon you, you fish-shaped island.
caption: An ocean view with a figure in the distance floating on the vast waters, approaching an island of the shape of a fish. The island is dotted with remnants and wreckage of those who have come before.
Postmodern. An abstract composition using oceanic colours; blues and greens. Fragmented pieces of debris are floating in the forefront, while in the background there's an island shaped like a fish.

104-009.poem: As I Ebb’d with the Ocean of Life
104-009.text: I throw myself upon your breast my father,I cling to you so that you cannot unloose me,I hold you so firm till you answer me something.
caption: An emotional picture of a person throwing themselves in the arms of their father, clinging onto him tightly and not letting go until he answers a question of great importance.

A black and white photograph with a young woman crying and holding tightly onto the arm of an elderly man, her face buried in his shoulder while he gently strokes her hair. The style is candid and emotional.

104-010.poem: As I Ebb’d with the Ocean of Life
104-010.text: Kiss me my father,Touch me with your lips as I touch those I love,Breathe to me while I hold you close the secret of the murmuring I envy.
caption: A person with a loving expression on their face leans in to kiss an older gentleman's forehead as he embraces them. The older man appears to be whispering a secret, while the person holds him tightly.

In a style reminiscent of classical paintings, a sorrowful embrace between a father and child. The child, holding onto the father, longing for the secrets of his murmurs, as the father gently kisses his child's forehead.

104-011.poem: As I Ebb’d with the Ocean of Life
104-011.text: 4Ebb, ocean of life, (the flow will return,)Cease not your moaning you fierce old mother,Endlessly cry for your castaways, but fear not, deny not me,Rustle not up so hoarse and angry against my feet as I touch you orgather from you.
caption: A large ocean with waves crashing against the shore, while a person reaches out to touch or gather from the water. The ocean appears to be moaning and angry, yet the person stands fearlessly with determination.

The photograph in monochromatic style features a turbulent ocean with high waves, and the sky is stormy. The photographer has captured a lighthouse in the background, and the sea is crashing against it.

104-012.poem: As I Ebb’d with the Ocean of Life
104-012.text: I mean tenderly by you and all,I gather for myself and for this phantom looking down where we lead,and following me and mine.
caption: A person surrounded by a group of people with a gentle expression on their face. They are looking down at a path that they are leading and the group is following closely behind. A phantom figure is following alongside them.

Surrealist. The painting depicts a figure with outstretched arms, surrounded by various objects and people, all connected by a glowing, golden thread. There is an ethereal, dreamlike quality to the piece.

104-013.poem: As I Ebb’d with the Ocean of Life
104-013.text: Me and mine, loose windrows, little corpses,Froth, snowy white, and bubbles,(See, from my dead lips the ooze exuding at last,See, the prismatic colors glistening and rolling,)Tufts of straw, sands, fragments,Buoy’d hither from many moods, one contradicting another,From the storm, the long calm, the darkness, the swell,Musing, pondering, a breath, a briny tear, a dab of liquid or soil,Up just as much out of fathomless workings fermented and thrown,A limp blossom or two, torn, just as much over waves floating,drifted at random,Just as much for us that sobbing dirge of Nature,Just as much whence we come that blare of the cloud-trumpets,We, capricious, brought hither we know not whence, spread out before you,You up there walking or sitting,Whoever you are, we too lie in drifts at your feet.
caption: The picture shows various objects scattered on the ground. Some appear to be dead or broken, while others are colorful and fragile. They look like they were brought together by the forces of nature, such as storms, tides, and winds. The image evokes a sense of contemplation and reflection, as if inviting the viewer to ponder the mystery of existence and our place in it.

Surrealistic. The foreground shows loose windrows of white bubbles and froth, with various fragments of tufts of straw and sands buoyed in the mix. The background shows a stormy sea with rays of light piercing through the clouds, and above it all, a person overlooking the scene, humming a mournful tune.

105-001.text: Tears! tears! tears!In the night, in solitude, tears,On the white shore dripping, dripping, suck’d in by the sand,Tears, not a star shining, all dark and desolate,Moist tears from the eyes of a muffled head;O who is that ghost? that form in the dark, with tears?What shapeless lump is that, bent, crouch’d there on the sand?Streaming tears, sobbing tears, throes, choked with wild cries;O storm, embodied, rising, careering with swift steps along the beach!O wild and dismal night storm, with wind--O belching and desperate!O shade so sedate and decorous by day, with calm countenance andregulated pace,But away at night as you fly, none looking--O then the unloosen’d ocean,Of tears! tears! tears!
caption: A figure on a white shore, weeping uncontrollably in the dark of night. The only light comes from the tears themselves, which fall onto the sand and are absorbed. The figure is mysterious, with an obscured head and hunched posture, and their cries are tumultuous, with both sobs and screams echoing along the beach. A storm rages around them, as wind howls and waves crash, all while tears continue to fall, representing the vast and uncontrolled emotion within the figure.

A photo in the style of impressionism or expressionism: A figure, head bowed and wrapped in a dark shawl, stands on a white sandy shore in the inky blackness of night. The stormy sea crashes against the shore, as the figure sobs uncontrollably - tears streaming down their face. The scene is filled with feelings of horror, despair, and overwhelming loss.

106-001.text: Thou who hast slept all night upon the storm,Waking renew’d on thy prodigious pinions,(Burst the wild storm? above it thou ascended’st,And rested on the sky, thy slave that cradled thee,)Now a blue point, far, far in heaven floating,As to the light emerging here on deck I watch thee,(Myself a speck, a point on the world’s floating vast.)
caption: A small bird soaring high above the turbulent stormy sea. As the light breaks through the dark clouds, the bird appears as a tiny blue dot far, far above. The viewer of the picture is a mere speck in comparison to the vastness of the world.

An aerial photo with a bird soaring in the sky after having weathered a storm, with storm clouds in the background, and the blue sky above. The bird is a tiny speck in the vastness of the world below. The image is stylized with a blue hue to emphasize the floating, weightless feeling.

106-002.text: Far, far at sea,After the night’s fierce drifts have strewn the shore with wrecks,With re-appearing day as now so happy and serene,The rosy and elastic dawn, the flashing sun,The limpid spread of air cerulean,Thou also re-appearest.
caption: A serene and colorful painting of the sunrise over a calm sea. The shore is littered with wrecks from a fierce night, but the dawn brings a sense of renewal and hope.
The picture depicts a sunrise at sea, with the aftermath of a storm on the shore. The sun is shining brightly and the air is clear as the waves crash against the rocks.

106-003.text: Thou born to match the gale, (thou art all wings,)To cope with heaven and earth and sea and hurricane,Thou ship of air that never furl’st thy sails,Days, even weeks untired and onward, through spaces, realms gyrating,At dusk that lookist on Senegal, at morn America,That sport’st amid the lightning-flash and thunder-cloud,In them, in thy experiences, had’st thou my soul,What joys! what joys were thine!
caption: A magnificent bird soaring through the skies with ease and grace. It challenges the most powerful elements of nature, from the fierce winds to the thunderous storms. Day after day, it travels on and on through various lands, turning and spinning through different worlds. It witnesses the beauty of Senegal at sunset and America at sunrise. It dances freely amid bolts of lightning and the rumble of thunder. Oh, to experience such joy and freedom like this bird!

The picture is done in an abstract expressionist style. Amid the chaos of swirling colors and shapes, a bird with expansive wings takes flight, soaring through space and time, experiencing the wonder and beauty of Senegal at dusk and America at dawn. The image captures the bird's boundless freedom and the overwhelming joy that it experiences in its adventurous journeys.

107-001.text: Aboard at a ship’s helm,A young steersman steering with care.
caption: A close-up of a young person's hands firmly grasping the ship's helm as they steer the ship with great care and focus.
Realistic oil painting. A young sailor with a focused expression standing at the helm of the ship, with light gleaming off the water in the background.

107-002.text: Through fog on a sea-coast dolefully ringing,An ocean-bell--O a warning bell, rock’d by the waves.
caption: A desolate sea-coast shrouded in fog. In the center of the image, an ocean-bell sways against the tumultuous waves, providing an ominous warning.
In a surrealistic style, a giant bell hangs over the stormy ocean, ringing in the fog. The bell swings violently with the motion of the waves.

107-003.text: O you give good notice indeed, you bell by the sea-reefs ringing,Ringing, ringing, to warn the ship from its wreck-place.
caption: A lighthouse standing tall on the rocky shoreline with the sound of a bell ringing out, warning ships of danger ahead.

Seascape photograph with a lighthouse on a rocky coast on the left, a small silhouette of a ship approaching from the right side. The foreground shows waves crashing against rocks, while fog and mist clears to reveal a warning bell perched atop the lighthouse on the left.

107-004.text: For as on the alert O steersman, you mind the loud admonition,The bows turn, the freighted ship tacking speeds away under her gray sails,The beautiful and noble ship with all her precious wealth speedsaway gayly and safe.
caption: A ship sailing on calm waters with its sails up, making a turn in its course. The ship is loaded with valuable cargo and is sailing safely towards its destination. The image suggests a sense of direction, alertness, and success.
Realistic with oceanic hues. A boat's deck takes up the foreground, the ship is in the center anchored in water, tacking towards the horizon under grey sails, with precious cargo onboard.

107-005.text: But O the ship, the immortal ship! O ship aboard the ship!Ship of the body, ship of the soul, voyaging, voyaging, voyaging.
caption: A magnificent ship sailing through a vast ocean, with the body and soul both aboard and journeying on this endless adventure.

The photograph showcases a surreal ship sailing on a vast ocean. The ship is constructed with the human body, and its silhouette contains another ship that symbolizes the soul. The ship is continually on a journey, never stopping.

108-001.text: On the beach at night,Stands a child with her father,Watching the east, the autumn sky.
caption: A serene photograph taken at the beach during night time. A child standing beside her father, both gazing at the beautiful autumn sky towards the eastern horizon.

Realistic landscape scenery with a silhouette of a child and father standing on a beach at night. The child looks towards the sky with a sense of wonder and awe, while the father looks down towards the child with comfort and love.

108-002.text: Up through the darkness,While ravening clouds, the burial clouds, in black masses spreading,Lower sullen and fast athwart and down the sky,Amid a transparent clear belt of ether yet left in the east,Ascends large and calm the lord-star Jupiter,And nigh at hand, only a very little above,Swim the delicate sisters the Pleiades.
caption: A breathtaking night-time view showcasing vertically rising, dark grey clouds into a clear sky with stars shining, and a large, serene Jupiter star dominating the foreground. The delicate Pleiades, closely knitted together, are observable in the near vicinity.

Astro-photography. A black sky, with large black clouds spreading throughout. In the centre, the planet Jupiter shines large and calm, with the Pleiades constellation floating delicately nearby in the transparent clear ether of space.

108-003.text: From the beach the child holding the hand of her father,Those burial-clouds that lower victorious soon to devour all,Watching, silently weeps.
caption: A small child is holding her father's hand on a beach. In the distance, a dark cloud approaches ominously. The child appears solemn, tears streaming down her face.
Impressionistic. A child clutching onto her father's hand at the beach. Dark storm clouds loom in the distance causing the child to cry silently.

108-004.text: Weep not, child,Weep not, my darling,With these kisses let me remove your tears,The ravening clouds shall not long be victorious,They shall not long possess the sky, they devour the stars only inapparition,Jupiter shall emerge, be patient, watch again another night, thePleiades shall emerge,They are immortal, all those stars both silvery and golden shallshine out again,The great stars and the little ones shall shine out again, they endure,The vast immortal suns and the long-enduring pensive moons shallagain shine.
caption: A child weeping, embraced by a loving figure who is wiping away their tears with kisses. Above them, dark clouds consume the sky, but the figure reassures the child that the stars and planets will reemerge - Jupiter, the Pleiades, and countless others that will shine on forever.

The photograph is in black and white. A child on the verge of tears is being comforted by a parent. The parent looks up at a nearly blackened sky as if imploring the heavens to clear up. The stars reemerge, shining brightly and triumphantly over the clouds.

108-005.text: Then dearest child mournest thou only for jupiter?Considerest thou alone the burial of the stars?
caption: A mournful child looking up at a starry night sky, grieving not only for Jupiter, but also for the passing of all the stars.
A dark and moody photorealistic image of a child looking up at the night sky, with clouds illuminated by the stars. The child looks sad and contemplative, with a deep sense of inquiry in their eyes.

108-006.text: Something there is,(With my lips soothing thee, adding I whisper,I give thee the first suggestion, the problem and indirection,)Something there is more immortal even than the stars,(Many the burials, many the days and nights, passing away,)Something that shall endure longer even than lustrous JupiterLonger than sun or any revolving satellite,Or the radiant sisters the Pleiades.
caption: A person whispering into another person's ear, suggesting a profound and immortal concept that transcends the passing of time and even the grandeur of celestial objects.

The picture is in the style of dark dramatic photography with a close-up of a whispering mouth. In the background, there are stars and galaxies, but there is something beyond them that is more immortal and enduring.

109-001.text: The world below the brine,Forests at the bottom of the sea, the branches and leaves,Sea-lettuce, vast lichens, strange flowers and seeds, the thicktangle openings, and pink turf,Different colors, pale gray and green, purple, white, and gold, theplay of light through the water,Dumb swimmers there among the rocks, coral, gluten, grass, rushes,and the aliment of the swimmers,Sluggish existences grazing there suspended, or slowly crawlingclose to the bottom,The sperm-whale at the surface blowing air and spray, or disportingwith his flukes,The leaden-eyed shark, the walrus, the turtle, the hairysea-leopard, and the sting-ray,Passions there, wars, pursuits, tribes, sight in those ocean-depths,breathing that thick-breathing air, as so many do,The change thence to the sight here, and to the subtle air breathedby beings like us who walk this sphere,The change onward from ours to that of beings who walk other spheres.
caption: An underwater world filled with forests made of seaweed, lichens, and strange flowers. The vibrant colors of various sea creatures swimming among the rocks, coral, and grass. The presence of powerful creatures such as the sperm whale, shark, walrus, and stingray. The depiction of passion, wars, and tribes in the depths of the ocean, where beings breathe a thick air. The contrast between this world and the one we walk on, breathing a subtle air, and the possibility of life on other planets.

A fantastical underwater world abundant with life and color, filled with intricate coral and forest-like structures made of sea-lettuce and lichens. Strange and diverse creatures swim through the thick, breathing water alongside the great sperm-whale and predatory sharks, with their passions, wars, and tribes existing in a realm beyond our own. The poem speaks to a timeless idea - that our vision is finite and limited, while strange and wondrous worlds exist just beyond the limits of our perception.

110-001.poem: On the Beach at Night Alone
110-001.text: On the beach at night alone,As the old mother sways her to and fro singing her husky song,As I watch the bright stars shining, I think a thought of the clefof the universes and of the future.
caption: A person sits alone on a beach at night, watching the stars and listening to the sound of the waves. The person is lost in thought, contemplating the vastness of the universe and what the future may hold. In the distance, an old woman sways back and forth as she sings a husky song.

A black and white photograph taken at night on a beach with a silhouette of an old woman swaying to the rhythm of her song as the bright stars shine above her. The photograph captures the mystery of the universe and the unknown future.

110-002.poem: On the Beach at Night Alone
110-002.text: A vast similitude interlocks all,All spheres, grown, ungrown, small, large, suns, moons, planets,All distances of place however wide,All distances of time, all inanimate forms,All souls, all living bodies though they be ever so different, or indifferent worlds,All gaseous, watery, vegetable, mineral processes, the fishes, the brutes,All nations, colors, barbarisms, civilizations, languages,All identities that have existed or may exist on this globe, or any globe,All lives and deaths, all of the past, present, future,This vast similitude spans them, and always has spann’d,And shall forever span them and compactly hold and enclose them.
caption: A circular image with a multitude of shapes and colors representing all living things and inanimate objects. The shapes and colors interlock and blend together to form a single cohesive image, symbolizing the interconnectedness of all things past, present, and future.

Photomontage. A collage of various images that represent all the different living beings and forms on the planet earth, from the smallest to the largest, the living to the inanimate, spanning across all continents, civilizations, and languages, with a vast interlocking web encompassing everything.

111-001.poem: Song for All Seas, All Ships
111-001.text: 1To-day a rude brief recitative,Of ships sailing the seas, each with its special flag or ship-signal,Of unnamed heroes in the ships--of waves spreading and spreadingfar as the eye can reach,Of dashing spray, and the winds piping and blowing,And out of these a chant for the sailors of all nations,Fitful, like a surge.
caption: A painting depicting several ships with different flags sailing in rough seas, splashing waves and strong winds with a noticeable absence of names of heroes. The painting depicts a sense of unity and camaraderie between sailors from all nations.

In the style of impressionism, a wide angle view of the sea, filled with numerous ships sailing in different directions, with flags and ship-signals. The waves are high, with foam splashing, and a strong wind is blowing. The painting conveys the fitful and sudden movements of the ships in the rough sea, with them appearing like unnamed heroes battling through the storm, while a distant chant for all sailors can be heard.

111-002.poem: Song for All Seas, All Ships
111-002.text: Of sea-captains young or old, and the mates, and of all intrepid sailors,Of the few, very choice, taciturn, whom fate can never surprise nordeath dismay.Pick’d sparingly without noise by thee old ocean, chosen by thee,Thou sea that pickest and cullest the race in time, and unitest nations,Suckled by thee, old husky nurse, embodying thee,Indomitable, untamed as thee.
caption: A black and white photograph of a collection of weathered and seasoned sailors standing tall and proud, gazing out at the vast ocean with an air of stoic bravery. The sea is portrayed as a motherly figure that has nurtured and molded these sailors into fearless individuals that have been hand-selected by the ocean itself.

In the style of seafaring art, a depiction of a group of sailors on a ship, some young and some old, with stoic faces showing their fearless nature towards the unpredictability of the sea, and a sense of reverence towards the ocean that handpicks and unites different nations. The sea is embodied as an indomitable and untamed force of nature, depicted as an old, husky nurse suckling on the sailors it has selected.

111-003.poem: Song for All Seas, All Ships
111-003.text: (Ever the heroes on water or on land, by ones or twos appearing,Ever the stock preserv’d and never lost, though rare, enough forseed preserv’d.)
caption: A collection of small, framed portraits that showcase heroic individuals from different walks of life, both military and civilian. In the center lies a seed that, despite its rarity, is carefully preserved for future growth.

Realistic landscape painting. Two people standing in a boat, fishing together on a calm river. In the distance, two figures, possibly farmers, are walking across a field. The foreground contains various plants, some of which have small fruits or seeds.

111-004.poem: Song for All Seas, All Ships
111-004.text: 2Flaunt out O sea your separate flags of nations!Flaunt out visible as ever the various ship-signals!But do you reserve especially for yourself and for the soul of manone flag above all the rest,A spiritual woven signal for all nations, emblem of man elate above death,Token of all brave captains and all intrepid sailors and mates,And all that went down doing their duty,Reminiscent of them, twined from all intrepid captains young or old,A pennant universal, subtly waving all time, o’er all brave sailors,All seas, all ships.
caption: A vast ocean with multiple ships from different nations sailing with their respective flags. However, amidst those flags, one spiritual flag stands out, representing humans who are lifted above death. It is a symbol of all the brave captains, sailors, and mates who lost their lives while doing their duty. This flag is universal, waving subtly over all the brave sailors, ships, seas, and time.

The artwork is a seascape in impressionism style, depicting a panoramic view of various ships displaying their flags. However, amidst them flies one spiritual and ethereal flag, a symbol of courage, bravery and remembrance reaching out to all brave captains and sailors who died on duty, woven from the threads of every intrepid captain's life, an everlasting banner fluttering above all the seas and ships, reminding us of their resilience and sacrifice.

112-001.text: Wild, wild the storm, and the sea high running,Steady the roar of the gale, with incessant undertone muttering,Shouts of demoniac laughter fitfully piercing and pealing,Waves, air, midnight, their savagest trinity lashing,Out in the shadows there milk-white combs careering,On beachy slush and sand spirts of snow fierce slanting,Where through the murk the easterly death-wind breasting,Through cutting swirl and spray watchful and firm advancing,(That in the distance! is that a wreck? is the red signal flaring?)Slush and sand of the beach tireless till daylight wending,Steadily, slowly, through hoarse roar never remitting,Along the midnight edge by those milk-white combs careering,A group of dim, weird forms, struggling, the night confronting,That savage trinity warily watching.
caption: A dark and stormy sea with fierce waves crashing together. The wind howls and laughs like a demon. The midnight sky is illuminated by flashes of white as waves crash onto the beach. In the distance, a red signal flares. A group of shadowy figures struggles against the storm, watching warily as the savage sea rages on.

A dramatic photograph captured in a high contrast black and white style. The wild ocean storm rages on through the night, with furious waves crashing onto the shore while the howling wind shakes the cliffs and blurs the edges of the scene. In the background, a group of silhouetted figures stand watch, their dark forms barely visible in the midst of the chaos.

113-001.text: After the sea-ship, after the whistling winds,After the white-gray sails taut to their spars and ropes,Below, a myriad myriad waves hastening, lifting up their necks,Tending in ceaseless flow toward the track of the ship,Waves of the ocean bubbling and gurgling, blithely prying,Waves, undulating waves, liquid, uneven, emulous waves,Toward that whirling current, laughing and buoyant, with curves,Where the great vessel sailing and tacking displaced the surface,Larger and smaller waves in the spread of the ocean yearnfully flowing,The wake of the sea-ship after she passes, flashing and frolicsomeunder the sun,A motley procession with many a fleck of foam and many fragments,Following the stately and rapid ship, in the wake following.
caption: A ship sails on the ocean with wind blowing its sails. Countless waves rise and rush towards the ship, creating a lively and playful atmosphere. The waves are of different sizes, and they all follow in the wake of the ship, leaving a trail of foam and fragments. The scene is beautiful, especially when viewed under the sun.

A photograph in the style of realism captures a wide-angle view of a vast ocean with a white-gray ship sailing on the surface. Many waves are in motion, carrying and lifting each other in a ceaseless flow towards the ship's track, with bubbling and uneven movements that seem to compete with each other. Behind the ship, the sea's wake churns rapidly, flashing with light under the sun, followed by a procession of many waves with flecks of foam and fragments.

114-001.text: To get betimes in Boston town I rose this morning early,Here’s a good place at the corner, I must stand and see the show.
caption: A person standing at a street corner in Boston, ready to watch a show, having woken up early to do so.
An acrylic painting of a bustling Boston street corner at sunrise. The artist captures the animated movements of the morning commuters gathered around and the excitement of the show of the city.

114-002.text: Clear the way there Jonathan!Way for the President’s marshal--way for the government cannon!Way for the Federal foot and dragoons, (and the apparitionscopiously tumbling.)
caption: A parade with a marching band and military troops. A cannon and apparitions are floating in the air above.
Surreal. A chaotic rollercoaster with bright, bold colors and various apparitions tumbling out of the cart, alongside a convoy of federal foot and dragoons clearing the way.

114-003.text: I love to look on the Stars and Stripes, I hope the fifes will playYankee Doodle.How bright shine the cutlasses of the foremost troops!Every man holds his revolver, marching stiff through Boston town.
caption: A painting showing a group of military personnel in Boston, standing at attention with rifles in hand, as their colorful flag waves overhead. The scene depicts a sense of pride and strength as they march forward while the upbeat tune of Yankee Doodle is played in the background.

Realistic painting. A group of soldiers proudly parading with the American flag fluttering in the wind, while a band plays "Yankee Doodle". The polished blades of their cutlasses gleam brightly in the sun, and every man holds his revolver.

114-004.text: A fog follows, antiques of the same come limping,Some appear wooden-legged, and some appear bandaged and bloodless.
caption: A foggy scene with a group of people walking towards the viewer. Some of them have wooden legs and others have bandages and appear wounded.
Surrealistic. A thick fog looms in the background as a line of antique figurines appear, with some having wooden legs and others appearing wounded and pale.

114-005.text: Why this is indeed a show--it has called the dead out of the earth!The old graveyards of the hills have hurried to see!Phantoms! phantoms countless by flank and rear!Cock’d hats of mothy mould--crutches made of mist!Arms in slings--old men leaning on young men’s shoulders.
caption: A gathering of phantoms from the old graveyards around the hills, coming to witness a show. They appear in great numbers, with cocked hats covered in mold and crutches made of mist. Some are injured, relying on the support of others to lean upon.
Surrealism. An abandoned graveyard being pulled up from the earth, with countless ghostly figures emerging from the mist carrying various battered objects and supporting each other.

114-006.text: What troubles you Yankee phantoms? what is all this chattering ofbare gums?Does the ague convulse your limbs? do you mistake your crutches forfirelocks and level them?
caption: A crowd of ghostly Yankee figures gathered together, holding their mouths open as if in confusion or distress. Some of them are shaking as if with chills or fever, while others appear to be holding their crutches up as if they were guns.

Surrealist. A group of ghostly, transparent Yankees with no jaws, are frozen in conversational poses with elderly walking aids mistaken for muskets. Their ghostly white bodies stand out in a foggy background, and their limbs convulse with ague.

114-007.text: If you blind your eyes with tears you will not see the President’s marshal,If you groan such groans you might balk the government cannon.
caption: A person with tears in their eyes and a person groaning heavily in front of the image of a marshal and a military cannon.

A dark picture depicting the White House in the background. In the foreground, a person is crying and holding their eyes shut while others stand in the distance, resisting the oppressive rule of the government. It is a Impressionistic style.

114-008.text: For shame old maniacs--bring down those toss’d arms, and let yourwhite hair be,Here gape your great grandsons, their wives gaze at them from the windows,See how well dress’d, see how orderly they conduct themselves.
caption: An elderly man with outstretched arms is being told to calm down by two younger individuals. In the background, the great-grandsons are looking out a window, while their wives observe them. The scene depicts a clash of generations, where the older ones seem unruly and emotional, while the younger ones are composed and sophisticated.

This photograph, taken in a vintage style, features elderly men who were once raving madmen, now tamed and dressed in respectable suits, standing with their arms at their sides. Their grandchildren and their wives are looking at them admiringly from the windows of a building.

114-009.text: Worse and worse--can’t you stand it? are you retreating?Is this hour with the living too dead for you?
caption: A person with their hands on their head, looking distressed and overwhelmed by their surroundings. Others are walking by them, but they feel isolated and unsupported.
Surrealistic photography with dark and eerie tones. In the center, a person standing with an expressionless face in a crowd of people who appear to be deteriorating.

114-010.text: Retreat then--pell-mell!To your graves--back--back to the hills old limpers!I do not think you belong here anyhow.
caption: An individual with their back turned to a group of limping people who are retreating back to the hills. The individual shows no inclination to join the limping people and instead finds them to be out of place in the present situation.
The picture is done in the style of surrealist art. It depicts a group of old figures limping and retreating into their graves, while the speaker looks on with a sense of detachment and dismissal.

114-011.text: But there is one thing that belongs here--shall I tell you what itis, gentlemen of Boston?
caption: A speaker standing in front of a serious audience in a conference room, pointing at something out of frame with a mysterious smile on their face.
Minimalistic. An image of an individual in deep thought, with the city of Boston bustling behind them.

114-012.text: I will whisper it to the Mayor, he shall send a committee to England,They shall get a grant from the Parliament, go with a cart to theroyal vault,Dig out King George’s coffin, unwrap him quick from thegraveclothes, box up his bones for a journey,Find a swift Yankee clipper--here is freight for you, black-bellied clipper,Up with your anchor--shake out your sails--steer straight towardBoston bay.
caption: A person with a mischievous expression planning to steal King George's bones from his grave in England, and transport them to Boston on a black clipper ship.

In a vintage or aged style, a black and white illustration of a group of men gathered in a room, with a sinister looking man whispering a secret to the mayor. In the background, a map of England and a red arrow pointing to a royal vault, and a coffin. At the forefront of the image, a clipper ship, with its anchor up, and sails shaking as it heads towards Boston bay.

114-013.text: Now call for the President’s marshal again, bring out the government cannon,Fetch home the roarers from Congress, make another procession,guard it with foot and dragoons.
caption: A large group of people, including politicians and military personnel, gathering in a procession. Cannons and soldiers are present, indicating the importance of the event.
Photomontage. In the foreground, a group of officials holding up a procession. Behind them, a cannon rests in the street. In the background, foot soldiers and dragoons stand guard.

114-014.text: This centre-piece for them;Look, all orderly citizens--look from the windows, women!
caption: A bustling city street scene, where onlookers from windows marvel at a grand centerpiece, possibly a monument or event taking place in the street. The atmosphere is one of orderliness and civic pride, and women are in particular an interested and engaged audience.
The visual style is Realism. The image showcases a grand center-piece, surrounded by tidy, virtuous citizens gazing out of their windows, including a group of women.

114-015.text: The committee open the box, set up the regal ribs, glue those thatwill not stay,Clap the skull on top of the ribs, and clap a crown on top of the skull.You have got your revenge, old buster--the crown is come to its own,and more than its own.
caption: A group of people in a committee room, opening a wooden crate. They are assembling the pieces of a regal skeleton, using glue to hold them together. They then put a skull on top of the ribs and place a crown on the head of the skeleton. The crown symbolizes the attainment of power and the achievement of their goal.

The picture is in a surreal style. A committee is assembling a human skeleton, attaching the regal ribs with glue, placing the skull on top, and finally, a glorious crown is placed atop the skull, symbolizing the achievement of triumphant revenge.

114-016.text: Stick your hands in your pockets, Jonathan--you are a made man fromthis day,You are mighty cute--and here is one of your bargains.
caption: A young man stands confidently with his hands in his pockets, possibly on a city street. He is being hailed as successful and attractive, having made a good deal or bargain.

Pop Art style. A young and handsome Jonathan with his hands in his pockets, looking confident and successful. A speech bubble next to him saying "made man." A large sale tag with "bargain" written on it in bold letters.

115-001.poem: Europe [The 72d and 73d Years of These States]
115-001.text: Suddenly out of its stale and drowsy lair, the lair of slaves,Like lightning it le’pt forth half startled at itself,Its feet upon the ashes and the rags, its hands tight to the throatsof kings.
caption: A figure representing freedom bursts forth from a dark, stagnant cave. The figure is initially startled but quickly gains confidence. The feet of the figure are upon the ashes and rags of oppression, while its hands are tightly wrapped around the throats of kings.
Surrealism. Emerging from a dark lair, a mythical creature with lightning bolts and a human-like form exerts strength upon the throats of kings while standing on ashes and tattered clothing.

115-002.poem: Europe [The 72d and 73d Years of These States]
115-002.text: O hope and faith!O aching close of exiled patriots’ lives!O many a sicken’d heart!Turn back unto this day and make yourselves afresh.
caption: An image of a rising sun shining on a group of people, possibly exiled patriots, who are weary and sick at heart. The sun represents hope and faith, and its light brings renewal and refreshment to those who gaze upon it.
The picture is in a surreal style that depicts a lighted path with the sun setting in the horizon. A group of people forming a circle indicating unity and hope in a world full of despair.

115-003.poem: Europe [The 72d and 73d Years of These States]
115-003.text: And you, paid to defile the People--you liars, mark!Not for numberless agonies, murders, lusts,For court thieving in its manifold mean forms, worming from hissimplicity the poor man’s wages,For many a promise sworn by royal lips and broken and laugh’d at inthe breaking,
caption: A group of people, dressed in fancy clothes, gathered in a luxurious court. They are engaging in various corrupt activities, such as stealing from the poor and making false promises. The subjects of the kingdom are outside, looking in with disapproval and anger.

A political protest photograph in gritty, documentary style, with an angry crowd gathered in a city street with posters and signs, some writing "liar" and others shouting slogans, and in the midst, an arrogant politician being exposed for their corrupt practices.

115-004.poem: Europe [The 72d and 73d Years of These States]
115-004.text: Then in their power not for all these did the blows strike revenge,or the heads of the nobles fall;The People scorn’d the ferocity of kings.
