caption: The painting shows a scene of rebellion where the people have risen up against their rulers. Despite the ferocity of the kings and nobles, the power dynamic has shifted and the people hold the upper hand. No heads have fallen, but the people scorn the kings for their brutality.

Futuristic. In the foreground, a person stands tall and dignified, staring forward in defiance. In the background, a line of decapitated nobles lay strewn on the ground, with a crowd of people gathered, standing and pointing with a mixture of scorn and triumph.

115-005.poem: Europe [The 72d and 73d Years of These States]
115-005.text: But the sweetness of mercy brew’d bitter destruction, and thefrighten’d monarchs come back,Each comes in state with his train, hangman, priest, tax-gatherer,Soldier, lawyer, lord, jailer, and sycophant.
caption: The picture shows multiple monarchs who appear frightened and devastated. Each monarch is accompanied by their entourage, including a hangman, priest, tax-gatherer, soldier, lawyer, lord, jailer, and sycophant. The scene represents a moment of bitter destruction caused by the sweetness of mercy.

Surrealistic art style. An image of frowning monarchs in their respective state regalia (crowns, robes, scepters, etc.) all coming out of a cauldron filled with sweet honey. Behind them are often associated figures - hangman, priest, tax-gatherer, soldier, lawyer, lord, jailer, and sycophant - some of whom are visibly recoiling and terrified.

115-006.poem: Europe [The 72d and 73d Years of These States]
115-006.text: Yet behind all lowering stealing, lo, a shape,Vague as the night, draped interminably, head, front and form, inscarlet folds,Whose face and eyes none may see,Out of its robes only this, the red robes lifted by the arm,One finger crook’d pointed high over the top, like the head of asnake appears.
caption: A mysterious figure wrapped in scarlet robes, its face and eyes concealed. Its arm lifted, with one finger pointing towards the sky like the head of a snake. The figure is surrounded by a dark and eerie atmosphere.

Surrealism. In the foreground, a mysterious shadowy figure draped in red garments. One arm lifted, pointing upwards with a bent finger like the head of a snake, while the face and eyes remain obscured.

115-007.poem: Europe [The 72d and 73d Years of These States]
115-007.text: Meanwhile corpses lie in new-made graves, bloody corpses of young men,The rope of the gibbet hangs heavily, the bullets of princes areflying, the creatures of power laugh aloud,And all these things bear fruits, and they are good.
caption: An image of a dark and gloomy battlefield, with fresh graves dug up and corpses of young soldiers laying in them. In the background, the gallows rope hangs and bullets fired by powerful rulers can be seen flying. The powerful ones laugh loudly at their victories. Yet, even in this grim scenario, there is progress and growth, and some consider it a good thing.

The picture is in a dystopian art style. In the foreground, there are multiple new graves with bloody corpses of young men scattered around. A heavy rope hangs in the background from a wooden gibbet with bullets flying across the sky. The creatures of power are sitting on high pedestals, laughing loudly at the scene beneath them.

115-008.poem: Europe [The 72d and 73d Years of These States]
115-008.text: Those corpses of young men,Those martyrs that hang from the gibbets, those hearts pierc’d bythe gray lead,Cold and motionless as they seem live elsewhere with unslaughter’d vitality.
caption: A black and white image that portrays the bodies of young men hanging from gibbets. Though they appear lifeless, their still hearts continue to beat with a resilient vitality.
Surrealism. The picture portrays a tree with branches that resemble lifeless human bodies hanging from a noose. Despite their apparently dead condition, the tree looks vibrant and full of life.

115-009.poem: Europe [The 72d and 73d Years of These States]
115-009.text: They live in other young men O kings!They live in brothers again ready to defy you,They were purified by death, they were taught and exalted.
caption: A group of young men, standing together and united in their defiance. They have faced death, but their spirits have been purified and they have been taught and exalted. Kings beware, for their strength and determination is not to be underestimated.

With a bold and defiant touch, the artwork shows a group of young men standing tall and proud. They are a brotherhood, united and undaunted by any challenge. The figures are stylized, slightly abstracted, and seem to radiate an inner strength, having been purified and exalted through the fires of death. The overall feeling is powerful and inspiring, with an undercurrent of danger and rebellion.

115-010.poem: Europe [The 72d and 73d Years of These States]
115-010.text: Not a grave of the murder’d for freedom but grows seed for freedom,in its turn to bear seed,Which the winds carry afar and re-sow, and the rains and the snows nourish.
caption: A barren land where a grave once stood, now transformed into a field of green plants reaching towards the sky. The wind gently carries the seeds away, spreading freedom far and wide. The rain and snow provide nourishment, ensuring the seeds grow strong and tall.

Realistic landscape with the foreground focused on a grave site, which then transitions into a field of flowers and trees that stretch as far as the eye can see, emphasizing the cyclical nature of growth and freedom with the wind and rain depicted as key players in this cycle.

115-011.poem: Europe [The 72d and 73d Years of These States]
115-011.text: Not a disembodied spirit can the weapons of tyrants let loose,But it stalks invisibly over the earth, whispering, counseling, cautioning.Liberty, let others despair of you--I never despair of you.
caption: A person holding a sword is powerless against an invisible force that whispers, counsels, and cautions throughout the world. The spirit of liberty is ever present and never to be despaired.

The photograph portrays a black and white city at night. Standing on the rooftops is an invisible figure with an arm outstretched, whispering courage to the people below who are oppressed. The city is dark and gloomy, yet the silhouette of the figure brings hope in the midst of despair.

115-012.poem: Europe [The 72d and 73d Years of These States]
115-012.text: Is the house shut? is the master away?Nevertheless, be ready, be not weary of watching,He will soon return, his messengers come anon.
caption: An anxious and curious person looking out of a window in a dimly lit room. The person is waiting for someone important to return and is attentive to any signs of their arrival.
Magical realism. A depiction of a house at night with its door ajar. The moonlit sky is vibrant with stars and owls fly overhead while a mysterious figure awaits the return of the house's master.

116-001.text: Hold it up sternly--see this it sends back, (who is it? is it you?)Outside fair costume, within ashes and filth,No more a flashing eye, no more a sonorous voice or springy step,Now some slave’s eye, voice, hands, step,A drunkard’s breath, unwholesome eater’s face, venerealee’s flesh,Lungs rotting away piecemeal, stomach sour and cankerous,Joints rheumatic, bowels clogged with abomination,Blood circulating dark and poisonous streams,Words babble, hearing and touch callous,No brain, no heart left, no magnetism of sex;Such from one look in this looking-glass ere you go hence,Such a result so soon--and from such a beginning!
caption: A picture of a person holding up a mirror, showing their reflection. The person in the reflection looks sick and worn out, with no energy or vibrancy left. Their eyes are dull, their voice weak, their steps uneven. They appear unhealthy and sickly, with a diseased body and a poisoned blood stream. This is the result of a life of excess and indulgence, and a warning that this could happen to anyone who follows that path.

The painting depicts a person looking intently at themselves in a mirror. The person's outward appearance is polished and well-dressed, but their reflection shows a grim reality of internal decay and corruption. The style is dark and grotesque, showing the physical consequences of a life of excess and vice.

117-001.text: Lover divine and perfect Comrade,Waiting content, invisible yet, but certain,Be thou my God.
caption: A person sitting calmly with their eyes closed, surrounded by a divine and peaceful aura. It is as if they are waiting for something, but they are content and certain that it will come. Implicitly, they are asking the divine to be their god and companion.
Minimalistic, black and white. A person with open arms in a state of serene waiting, seemingly alone, yet with a feeling of divine companionship.

117-002.text: Thou, thou, the Ideal Man,Fair, able, beautiful, content, and loving,Complete in body and dilate in spirit,Be thou my God.
caption: A picture of a man with a serene expression on his face, with a well-built and attractive physique. He radiates contentment and love from within, and emanates a sense of completeness both in body and spirit, standing out as an ideal example of a perfect human.

Using a surreal style, a human figure with two heads in a white desert, one face expressing emotions such as contentment and love, while the other is strong and able-bodied. The figure represents the ideal man and is set against an infinite, colorful horizon.

117-003.text: O Death, (for Life has served its turn,)Opener and usher to the heavenly mansion,Be thou my God.
caption: A person is standing with arms outstretched, welcoming the arrival of Death as the one who will open the gates to heaven. The person is placing their trust in Death as their God.

Surrealism. A dark, ominous figure with angelic wings stands in a barren land, with a bright and colorful doorway floating in the air behind them. The figure looks kindly at a small, kneeling person in front of them, who appears to be handing over something to the figure.

117-004.text: Aught, aught of mightiest, best I see, conceive, or know,(To break the stagnant tie--thee, thee to free, O soul,)Be thou my God.
caption: A person raising their arms high up looking towards the sky, as if they are seeking something greater than themselves. They are yearning to break free from the mundane and find their true purpose.

The visual style could be surrealism. The picture is of a person staring at a giant knot with a stagnant aura, while the soul is breaking free and embracing a new dawn, with their God guiding and illuminating their path.

117-005.text: All great ideas, the races’ aspirations,All heroisms, deeds of rapt enthusiasts,Be ye my Gods.
caption: An image of a person with outstretched arms, looking up towards the sky, as if worshipping their own personal pantheon of gods. The figures depicted aren't physical beings, but rather nebulous, symbolic representations of people's aspirations and hopes.

The image depicts a collage of people from different races and cultures holding up their hopes and dreams as offerings to a group of larger-than-life heroes. The mood is reverential and awe-inspiring. The visual style is surreal, with a blend of human forms and mythological imagery.

117-006.text: Or Time and Space,Or shape of Earth divine and wondrous,Or some fair shape I viewing, worship,Or lustrous orb of sun or star by night,Be ye my Gods.
caption: A person standing under a starry sky with their arms raised, worshipping the beauty of the universe. The person sees the earth, sun, and stars as divine and wondrous forces that they revere.

Surrealist. A humanoid figure surrounded by an otherworldly landscape, worshipping a cosmic body of stars and/or sun, with the planet Earth depicted in some unusual or fantastical form in the background.

118-001.text: Forms, qualities, lives, humanity, language, thoughts,The ones known, and the ones unknown, the ones on the stars,The stars themselves, some shaped, others unshaped,Wonders as of those countries, the soil, trees, cities, inhabitants,whatever they may be,Splendid suns, the moons and rings, the countless combinations and effects,Such-like, and as good as such-like, visible here or anywhere, standprovided for a handful of space, which I extend my arm andhalf enclose with my hand,That containing the start of each and all, the virtue, the germs of all.
caption: A vast and surreal landscape filled with a variety of elements such as forms, lives, and thoughts. The stars, suns, moons, and rings all come together in a beautiful display of countless combinations and effects. In the distance, there are cities, trees, and inhabitants of unknown origins. All of this immense beauty is contained in a small space that is barely larger than a human hand. This little space is the birthplace of every single element and germ that exists in the world.

This picture is a breathtakingly vast and detailed panoramic view of the universe, brimming with forms, qualities, lives, and countless combinations and effects. It is an awe-inspiring view that provokes wonder and reflection on the meaning of life and the universe.

119-001.text: 1Of these years I sing,How they pass and have pass’d through convuls’d pains, as throughparturitions,How America illustrates birth, muscular youth, the promise, the surefulfilment, the absolute success, despite of people--illustratesevil as well as good,The vehement struggle so fierce for unity in one’s-self,How many hold despairingly yet to the models departed, caste, myths,obedience, compulsion, and to infidelity,How few see the arrived models, the athletes, the Western States, orsee freedom or spirituality, or hold any faith in results,(But I see the athletes, and I see the results of the war gloriousand inevitable, and they again leading to other results.)
caption: A dynamic photograph with a combination of light and dark elements. In the center of the frame, the muscular silhouette of a young athlete symbolizing the birth of America. In the background, a representation of the country's historical struggles to find unity and faith, yet the inevitable success and glorious results that ensue.

In a dynamic and abstract art style, a chaotic and painful birth process is depicted, representing the passing of the years in America. Amidst struggles for unity and the admiration of those fallen before, few see the triumph of freedom and spirituality that leads to inevitable glory and progress.

119-002.text: How the great cities appear--how the Democratic masses, turbulent,willful, as I love them,How the whirl, the contest, the wrestle of evil with good, thesounding and resounding, keep on and on,How society waits unform’d, and is for a while between things endedand things begun,How America is the continent of glories, and of the triumph offreedom and of the Democracies, and of the fruits of society, andof all that is begun,And how the States are complete in themselves--and how all triumphsand glories are complete in themselves, to lead onward,And how these of mine and of the States will in their turn beconvuls’d, and serve other parturitions and transitions,And how all people, sights, combinations, the democratic masses too,serve--and how every fact, and war itself, with all its horrors,serves,And how now or at any time each serves the exquisite transition of death.
caption: The picture is a collage of bustling cityscapes, showcasing the diversity and energy of democratic masses. Society is in an in-between stage, ripe for change and growth. America is portrayed as the land of freedom, democracy, and opportunity, with individual States strengthened by their victories and accomplishments. The picture also depicts the cyclical nature of society and how every occurrence, whether it be a fact, war, or death, serves as a force of transition and change. The visual style may employ a combination of realism and surrealism, utilizing bright colors to symbolize the fervor and dynamism of the democratic masses juxtaposed with the stark reality of society.

Surrealist style. A cityscape at night with Democratic figures filling the streets in a frenzy of movement and noise. Society, half-formed, waits in the balance between chaos and order. The image depicts the wild, but triumphant spirit of America, the states shining forth in their own achievements, but knowing that they are only a step on the journey of the inevitable convulsions that pave the way to further advancement. In the midst of it all, death, a looming presence which frames every life and event, serving as a constant reminder of the delicate nature of existence.

119-003.text: 2Of seeds dropping into the ground, of births,Of the steady concentration of America, inland, upward, toimpregnable and swarming places,Of what Indiana, Kentucky, Arkansas, and the rest, are to be,Of what a few years will show there in Nebraska, Colorado, Nevada,and the rest,(Or afar, mounting the Northern Pacific to Sitka or Aliaska,)Of what the feuillage of America is the preparation for--and of whatall sights, North, South, East and West, are,Of this Union welded in blood, of the solemn price paid, of theunnamed lost ever present in my mind;Of the temporary use of materials for identity’s sake,Of the present, passing, departing--of the growth of completer menthan any yet,Of all sloping down there where the fresh free giver the mother, theMississippi flows,Of mighty inland cities yet unsurvey’d and unsuspected,Of the new and good names, of the modern developments, ofinalienable homesteads,Of a free and original life there, of simple diet and clean andsweet blood,Of litheness, majestic faces, clear eyes, and perfect physique there,Of immense spiritual results future years far West, each side of theAnahuacs,Of these songs, well understood there, (being made for that area,)Of the native scorn of grossness and gain there,(O it lurks in me night and day--what is gain after all to savagenessand freedom?)
caption: This visual style would be an abstract painting with many colors that blend together, representing the merging of America's different regions. The painting would contain images of the Midwest, the West Coast, and the Northern Pacific, as well as representations of the many different peoples and cultures that make up the country. It would be a celebration of the diversity and unity of America, and the potential for growth and progress in the years to come.

This picture portrays America's growth and expansion from the depths of the soil. In the foreground, there are states like Indiana, Kentucky, and Arkansas while Nebraska, Colorado, and Nevada loom in the distance. The Mississippi River is a vital presence, and the people are strong, resilient and working toward their dreams.

120-001.poem: When I Heard the Learn’d Astronomer
120-001.text: When I heard the learn’d astronomer,When the proofs, the figures, were ranged in columns before me,When I was shown the charts and diagrams, to add, divide, and measure them,When I sitting heard the astronomer where he lectured with muchapplause in the lecture-room,How soon unaccountable I became tired and sick,Till rising and gliding out I wander’d off by myself,In the mystical moist night-air, and from time to time,Look’d up in perfect silence at the stars.
caption: An image showing a lecture hall filled with people, with a projection of charts and diagrams. The main figure, feeling disenchanted and restless, leaves the lecture hall and enjoys the mystical beauty of the starry sky alone.

Realism. The image shows a crowded lecture hall filled with people gathered to hear an astronomer deliver a lecture, while a person in the back row is getting restless and bored. The next picture shows that same person leaving the lecture hall and wandering outside into the night where they look up at the stars in perfect silence.

121-001.text: Only themselves understand themselves and the like of themselves,As souls only understand souls.
caption: Two individuals staring deeply into each other's eyes, with a profound sense of understanding and connection between them. Their gaze reflects a spiritual and emotional intimacy that only those who share a similar essence can truly comprehend.

Abstract Expressionism. A representation of two similar but unique amorphous figures, mirroring each other's shapes and movements, with their eyes and body language conveying understanding and recognition.

122-001.text: O me! O life! of the questions of these recurring,Of the endless trains of the faithless, of cities fill’d with the foolish,Of myself forever reproaching myself, (for who more foolish than I,and who more faithless?)Of eyes that vainly crave the light, of the objects mean, of thestruggle ever renew’d,Of the poor results of all, of the plodding and sordid crowds I seearound me,Of the empty and useless years of the rest, with the rest me intertwined,The question, O me! so sad, recurring--What good amid these, O me, O life?
caption: A person stands in a crowded city, surrounded by foolish and faithless people. They look sad, and their eyes seem to be searching for something, but they cannot find it. They see a never-ending struggle to survive and to find meaning in life. The person is filled with self-doubt and questions the point of it all - what good is there to be found in this life filled with emptiness and despair?

Photography through the perspective of a train window, with the city passing by filled with people carrying on with their daily lives. The photographer capturing a melancholic scene that prompts the question: "What good amid these, O me, O life?"

122-002.text: Answer.That you are here--that life exists and identity,That the powerful play goes on, and you may contribute a verse.
caption: A lone figure standing at the edge of a cliff, overlooking a vast and breathtaking landscape. The figure acknowledges their existence and feels empowered to add their own contributions to the world.
Black and white photograph of a busy street with people all around. The focus is on a single person, who stands out amongst the crowd, staring directly at the camera.

123-001.text: All you are doing and saying is to America dangled mirages,You have not learn’d of Nature--of the politics of Nature you havenot learn’d the great amplitude, rectitude, impartiality,You have not seen that only such as they are for these States,And that what is less than they must sooner or later lift off fromthese States.
caption: An illustration of a person standing on the edge of a cliff, holding out a mirage-like illusion of America. Behind them, a vast landscape of nature stretches out towards the horizon. But the person's focus is solely on the illusion and they fail to recognize the impartiality and greatness of nature. This lack of understanding will cause them to be separated from the states, unless they learn to appreciate and integrate with the natural world.

A photograph in black and white with a dark, stormy sky looming above a rocky coastline, the waves crashing violently against the shore. The ominous atmosphere shows the unpredictable power of nature, unlike the insubstantial promises and falsehoods of politics.

124-001.text: I sit and look out upon all the sorrows of the world, and upon alloppression and shame,I hear secret convulsive sobs from young men at anguish withthemselves, remorseful after deeds done,I see in low life the mother misused by her children, dying,neglected, gaunt, desperate,I see the wife misused by her husband, I see the treacherous seducerof young women,I mark the ranklings of jealousy and unrequited love attempted to behid, I see these sights on the earth,I see the workings of battle, pestilence, tyranny, I see martyrs andprisoners,I observe a famine at sea, I observe the sailors casting lots whoshall be kill’d to preserve the lives of the rest,I observe the slights and degradations cast by arrogant persons uponlaborers, the poor, and upon negroes, and the like;All these--all the meanness and agony without end I sitting look out upon,See, hear, and am silent.
caption: A somber image of a person sitting and observing the various the sorrows and sufferings that exist in the world. Young men in anguish, a neglected mother, a mistreated wife, and a deceitful seducer. The ugliness of jealousy and unrequited love is present. The person sees battles, diseases, and tyranny. They bear witness to martyrs and prisoners. A group of sailors deliberating who will be sacrificed to save the others. And finally, the oppressive actions of arrogant individuals towards those who are less privileged. Despite all this, the person sits in silence, observing and reflecting on the world around them.

The picture is in black and white, with a bleak and somber atmosphere. A person sits with a blank expression, looking out into the distance with a view of different scenes of oppression, sorrow, desperation, and death - a woman dying and neglected, a mother misused by her children, battles, famine, prisoners, and the ranklings of jealousy, all ignored in silence.

125-001.text: What you give me I cheerfully accept,A little sustenance, a hut and garden, a little money, as Irendezvous with my poems,A traveler’s lodging and breakfast as journey through the States,--why should I be ashamed to own such gifts? why to advertise for them?For I myself am not one who bestows nothing upon man and woman,For I bestow upon any man or woman the entrance to all the gifts ofthe universe.
caption: A person standing outside a humble hut with a small garden, holding a wrapped package given to them by a passerby. The person looks grateful, acknowledging that they receive little sustenance and money, but they are content because their true rendezvous is with their art -- poetry. The person questions why they should be ashamed of these gifts or even advertise for them, for they know they are not given nothing in return as they bestow upon any man or woman the entrance to all the gifts of the universe.

In the style of Impressionism. A person walks through a garden and towards a small hut, with a basket of food in hand. The sun is barely up, and in the distance, various landscapes sprawl out for miles.

126-001.text: Skirting the river road, (my forenoon walk, my rest,)Skyward in air a sudden muffled sound, the dalliance of the eagles,The rushing amorous contact high in space together,The clinching interlocking claws, a living, fierce, gyrating wheel,Four beating wings, two beaks, a swirling mass tight grappling,In tumbling turning clustering loops, straight downward falling,Till o’er the river pois’d, the twain yet one, a moment’s lull,A motionless still balance in the air, then parting, talons loosing,Upward again on slow-firm pinions slanting, their separate diverse flight,She hers, he his, pursuing.
caption: A pair of eagles are locked in an intense embrace high in the sky. They spin and fall, their claws and wings interlocked, until finally they separate and fly off in different directions.

The photograph is taken from a distance and shows two eagles engaged in a tussle high up in the air. They fly with fierce intensity, interlocking their claws, and moving in a circular motion. They fall together and stabilize, but eventually fly separately. The photograph is captured in black and white, giving it an old-fashioned feel.

127-001.text: Roaming in thought over the Universe, I saw the little that is Goodsteadily hastening towards immortality,And the vast all that is call’d Evil I saw hastening to merge itselfand become lost and dead.
caption: An image of a vast universe with a clear divide - on one side, a small but steady stream leading towards immortality, and on the other side, a vast and overwhelming collection of darkness and negativity disappearing into nothingness.

This is a surrealist photograph. The image is divided into two halves - one side showcasing the beauty and prosperity, with lush trees, green grass, and gorgeous natural landscapes. The other half shows death, decay, and destruction with industrial wasteland, smokestacks, and abandoned buildings, all eventually leading to a single merge point that seems to represent the eventuality of the universe.

128-001.text: Through the ample open door of the peaceful country barn,A sunlit pasture field with cattle and horses feeding,And haze and vista, and the far horizon fading away.
caption: A wide open door of a peaceful country barn reveals a vast sunlit pasture field with cattle and horses grazing. The atmosphere is filled with a hazy quality, and the horizon in the distance, fading out of view.

This would be a pastoral landscape photograph with a soft focus and gentle natural lighting. The forefront of the image would be of a big country barn, a field of cattle and horses in the background as well as the distant horizon alluding to the vastness of nature.

129-001.text: Silent and amazed even when a little boy,I remember I heard the preacher every Sunday put God in his statements,As contending against some being or influence.
caption: An image of a little boy sitting in a church, with a preacher at the pulpit. The boy appears to be in awe while the preacher passionately makes a stance against some being or influence.

A black and white photograph of a young boy standing in a church with a solemn, contemplative expression. The preacher in the foreground gestures passionately, while the congregation sits in pews behind them.

130-001.text: On a flat road runs the well-train’d runner,He is lean and sinewy with muscular legs,He is thinly clothed, he leans forward as he runs,With lightly closed fists and arms partially rais’d.
caption: A fit and athletic runner speeds down a flat road. His muscular legs are prominent and his thin clothing cling to his body. Leaning forward and partially raising his arms, he runs with tightly closed fists.

Futurist photography. A runner in motion on a white, seamless background. Their athletic build and taut legs create a sense of speed and velocity. The runner's forward stance and closed fists suggest intense focus and determination.

131-001.text: Women sit or move to and fro, some old, some young,The young are beautiful--but the old are more beautiful than the young.
caption: A group of women sitting and moving around. Some are young and lovely, while others are old and radiate even more beauty than the younger ones.

A black and white photo featuring women of different ages sitting or moving around in a candid and unposed way. The lighting highlights the wrinkles and imperfections on the older women's faces, making them stand out and appear more beautiful than the young.

132-001.text: I see the sleeping babe nestling the breast of its mother,The sleeping mother and babe--hush’d, I study them long and long.
caption: A peaceful and serene picture of a sleeping mother and her baby nestled in her arms. The observer is studying the picture intently.
The photographic style would be candid. A mother cradling their sleeping baby; the mother's eyes are also shut, and the two are at peace, bathed in soft light.

133-001.book: BOOK XXX.  WHISPERS OF HEAVENLY DEATH
133-001.text: As I sit with others at a great feast, suddenly while the music is playing,To my mind, (whence it comes I know not,) spectral in mist of awreck at sea,Of certain ships, how they sail from port with flying streamers andwafted kisses, and that is the last of them,Of the solemn and murky mystery about the fate of the President,Of the flower of the marine science of fifty generations founder’doff the Northeast coast and going down--of the steamship Arcticgoing down,Of the veil’d tableau-women gather’d together on deck, pale, heroic,waiting the moment that draws so close--O the moment!
caption: The photograph is surreal and impressionistic. A dinner is taking place with guests seated when suddenly a haunting image appears tantalizing the mind. The image is that of a stormy sea, misty with crashing waves and distressed ships. In the fore is a monumental and heart-wrenching scene in which an ocean liner is going down. The haunting image is veiled with a group of women, pale from fear and waiting for the moment where they will have to face their fate.

The picture is reminiscent of a surreal dream. There are people sitting together at a table with a grand feast spread out in front of them. The music is playing and suddenly, out of nowhere, a ghostly image of a wrecked ship on a stormy sea appears in one person's mind. There are flying streamers and wafted kisses, all while the people on a steamship Arctic seem to be going down. There are women in heroic poses gathered together on a veiled tableau, waiting for the moment that is drawing so close.

133-002.book: BOOK XXX.  WHISPERS OF HEAVENLY DEATH
133-002.text: A huge sob--a few bubbles--the white foam spirting up--and then thewomen gone,Sinking there while the passionless wet flows on--and I nowpondering, Are those women indeed gone?Are souls drown’d and destroy’d so?Is only matter triumphant?
caption: Realism. A turbulent ocean with white, foamy waves crashing in with a splash. Three women have just submerged within the waves, leaving nothing behind but bubbles. In the foreground, a lone figure ponders their fate.
Photojournalistic. A broken down raft in the water with splashing waves surrounding it. Two life preservers floating nearby. There is a sense of loss and confusion in the scene.

134-001.text: A mask, a perpetual natural disguiser of herself,Concealing her face, concealing her form,Changes and transformations every hour, every moment,Falling upon her even when she sleeps.
caption: A picture of a person wearing a mask, which changes frequently. The mask is concealing the person's true identity and constantly changing even as they sleep.

In a surrealist style, a woman whose face and body are made of fabrics - masks andcloaks - that whirl around her, obscuring any glimpse of her true identity. The fabrics form a fluid and ever-changing pattern, regardless of whether she's awake or asleep.

135-001.book: BOOK XXX.  WHISPERS OF HEAVENLY DEATH
135-001.text: As I sit with others at a great feast, suddenly while the music is playing,To my mind, (whence it comes I know not,) spectral in mist of awreck at sea,Of certain ships, how they sail from port with flying streamers andwafted kisses, and that is the last of them,Of the solemn and murky mystery about the fate of the President,Of the flower of the marine science of fifty generations founder’doff the Northeast coast and going down--of the steamship Arcticgoing down,Of the veil’d tableau-women gather’d together on deck, pale, heroic,waiting the moment that draws so close--O the moment!
caption: The style is abstract expressionism. A large painting with different colors blending into each other. It shows a feast in progress with a shipwreck depicted as a misty and foggy scene. The painting has different darker elements, such as death and the mysteries of the ocean. Women huddle together on a ship, awaiting their fate with a sense of heroism.

Surrealist. A group of diners are set against a cloudy seascape, and in the midst of playing music a vision emerges of a shipwreck. Ships with flying streamers go down in spectral mist, a symbol of the tragic losses of marine science over fifty generations. In the foreground, a tableau of heroic women on a ship's deck waits, anxious yet ready for the moment that draws so close.

135-002.book: BOOK XXX.  WHISPERS OF HEAVENLY DEATH
135-002.text: A huge sob--a few bubbles--the white foam spirting up--and then thewomen gone,Sinking there while the passionless wet flows on--and I nowpondering, Are those women indeed gone?Are souls drown’d and destroy’d so?Is only matter triumphant?
caption: Photograph in high-contrast black and white, a strong ocean wave crashes ashore with loud force. The waves recede and leave behind an empty shoreline. The emptiness is contrasted by a group of people standing at the edge of the water, contemplating the power of the wave.

The image is of a turbulent sea, with a few bubbles breaking the surface and white foam spraying around. In the distance, two women are sinking down. The focus is on pondering the idea of the women's souls being destroyed by the force of the sea, while water continues to flow unfeeling. The visual style is expressionistic with rough brushstrokes and muted colors.

136-001.text: Gliding o’er all, through all,Through Nature, Time, and Space,As a ship on the waters advancing,The voyage of the soul--not life alone,Death, many deaths I’ll sing.
caption: A vast, dynamic landscape with a ship sailing through it. Above the ship, we see a faint, transparent soul traveling beyond life and into the many deaths that follow.

The picture is presented in surrealist style. The painting presents a figure gliding on a ship through a dark blue sea, surrounded by the vast expanse of time and space, and the hidden voyages of the soul, depicting the concept of death and many lives.

137-001.poem: Hast Never Come to Thee an Hour
137-001.text: Hast never come to thee an hour,A sudden gleam divine, precipitating, bursting all these bubbles,fashions, wealth?These eager business aims--books, politics, art, amours,To utter nothingness?
caption: A person standing with a surprised expression on their face, while all the distractions of their life - wealth, politics, relationships - burst into bubbles around them, disappearing into nothingness. From above, a divine light is shining down upon them.

Abstract expressionism. A violent, almost chaotic array of colors and shapes covering a large canvas, with a bright and intense burst of light in the center, surrounded by smaller and more delicate bubbles, fashion items and luxury objects that seem to fade away into the void.

138-001.book: BOOK XXX.  WHISPERS OF HEAVENLY DEATH
138-001.text: As I sit with others at a great feast, suddenly while the music is playing,To my mind, (whence it comes I know not,) spectral in mist of awreck at sea,Of certain ships, how they sail from port with flying streamers andwafted kisses, and that is the last of them,Of the solemn and murky mystery about the fate of the President,Of the flower of the marine science of fifty generations founder’doff the Northeast coast and going down--of the steamship Arcticgoing down,Of the veil’d tableau-women gather’d together on deck, pale, heroic,waiting the moment that draws so close--O the moment!
caption: The artwork is a surreal depiction of a feast, with a ghostly apparition of a shipwreck hovering in the misty background. The scene is crowded with people who gather around a surreal tableau. Amongst them are women who look brave and pale, waiting for an event that is about to happen any moment now.

The photorealistic painting depicts a festive banquet with a band playing in the background. Suddenly, the image transforms to spectral visions of shipwrecks, with flying streamers and wafted kisses, and the finality of their disappearance. The painting then details the tragic events leading to the fate of the President, followed by women on board a steamship, waiting for the tragic end that is imminent.

138-002.book: BOOK XXX.  WHISPERS OF HEAVENLY DEATH
138-002.text: A huge sob--a few bubbles--the white foam spirting up--and then thewomen gone,Sinking there while the passionless wet flows on--and I nowpondering, Are those women indeed gone?Are souls drown’d and destroy’d so?Is only matter triumphant?
caption: Photorealistic. A violent ocean with towering waves and a few bubbles on its surface. In the distance, several women are struggling to keep their heads above the water, while the narrator is standing on the shore, deep in thought.

This picture is captured in black and white with a large wave rolling over a group of women, their forms now obscure under the tumultuous water. The viewer is left to ponder if their souls were also destroyed as only the matter of the water appears triumphant.

139-001.text: I see in you the estuary that enlarges and spreads itself grandly asit pours in the great sea.
caption: An image of a river merging into the vast sea. The convergence of water symbolizes a grand and bountiful transformation.

A wide-angle shot of an estuary with a river rapidly flowing into the sea with breathtaking scenery. The colors of the sky and the water complement each other reflecting the beauty of the natural world.

140-001.text: Locations and times--what is it in me that meets them all, wheneverand wherever, and makes me at home?Forms, colors, densities, odors--what is it in me that correspondswith them?
caption: An image depicting a person in various locations and times, surrounded by diverse forms, colors, densities, and odors. The person appears to be comfortable and at home in every setting, suggesting a deep connection with the world around them.

This image is a surreal interpretation of the human perception of reality. It consists of multiple locations, various times, and different forms depicted in a dreamlike manner through overlapping and melting shapes, colors, and textures. A sense of curiosity and wonder is conveyed in the image.

141-001.text: A thousand perfect men and women appear,Around each gathers a cluster of friends, and gay children andyouths, with offerings.
caption: A large gathering of happy people with adults, children and teenagers all mingling together in groups around a central figure, surrounded by offerings from their loved ones.

This picture has a surrealistic style, featuring a bright and colorfully patterned forest with a clearing in the center where hundreds of people, young and old alike, are gathered in small groups with presents and smiling faces, creating a cheerful and lively atmosphere.

142-001.poem: To The States [To Identify the 16th, 17th, or 18th Presidentiad]
142-001.text: Why reclining, interrogating? why myself and all drowsing?What deepening twilight-scum floating atop of the waters,Who are they as bats and night-dogs askant in the capitol?What a filthy Presidentiad! (O South, your torrid suns! O North,your arctic freezings!)Are those really Congressmen? are those the great Judges? is thatthe President?Then I will sleep awhile yet, for I see that these States sleep, forreasons;(With gathering murk, with muttering thunder and lambent shoots weall duly awake,South, North, East, West, inland and seaboard, we will surely awake.)
caption: An eerie image of a city at dusk with dark clouds gathering overhead. There are shapes in the distance that look like bats and dogs, and in the center is a group of people who may be congressmen, great judges, or even the president, all covered in a layer of filth. The states are depicted as sleeping, but a storm is brewing and it's only a matter of time until they all awaken together.

Photomontage style. A chaotic scene with twilight sky, city skyline in the background, and animals scattered throughout. In the forefront, political figures such as judges and Congressmen are featured with a disgusted expression on their faces. In the center, the President is depicted as filthy and unclean, with a dark storm brewing behind them. Finally, the piece ends by showing hope and light with flashes of lighting and thunder clouds.

143-001.poem: First O Songs for a Prelude
143-001.text: First O songs for a prelude,Lightly strike on the stretch’d tympanum pride and joy in my city,How she led the rest to arms, how she gave the cue,How at once with lithe limbs unwaiting a moment she sprang,(O superb! O Manhattan, my own, my peerless!O strongest you in the hour of danger, in crisis! O truer than steel!)How you sprang--how you threw off the costumes of peace withindifferent hand,How your soft opera-music changed, and the drum and fife were heardin their stead,How you led to the war, (that shall serve for our prelude, songs ofsoldiers,)How Manhattan drum-taps led.
caption: A picture of a city with a proud and joyful atmosphere. The city led others to war, and the people are depicted with lithe limbs, swiftly and confidently moving towards battle. The atmosphere changes from peaceful to intense with the introduction of drum and fife music. The people are ready and have thrown off the costumes of peace with indifference. The scene serves as a prelude to a song about soldiers and is inspired by the sound of Manhattan drum-taps.

The image is a dramatic and powerful black and white photograph with sharp lines and contrast. It depicts a city skyline with a figure of a person, symbolizing New York City, standing tall and proud. The person is positioned in the center and with their arms raised, as if conducting an orchestra of war, and behind them, soldiers are marching in unison, their faces resolved.

143-002.poem: First O Songs for a Prelude
143-002.text: Forty years had I in my city seen soldiers parading,Forty years as a pageant, till unawares the lady of this teeming andturbulent city,Sleepless amid her ships, her houses, her incalculable wealth,With her million children around her, suddenly,At dead of night, at news from the south,Incens’d struck with clinch’d hand the pavement.
caption: A bustling city with soldiers parading for forty years, until a sudden disturbance awakens its lady. The lady, in the midst of her ships, houses, and wealth, erupts in anger at news from the south, striking the pavement with a clenched hand.

Street photography style. A busy city with soldiers parading on the streets for forty years. Suddenly, in the dead of night, the lady of the city heard news from the south, and amidst her wealth and millions of children, she clenched her hand and struck the pavement in anger.

143-003.poem: First O Songs for a Prelude
143-003.text: A shock electric, the night sustain’d it,Till with ominous hum our hive at daybreak pour’d out its myriads.
caption: A dark and stormy night with a beehive in the foreground, illuminated by lightning. At daybreak, countless bees swarm out of the hive with an ominous hum.
Surrealist. A desolate landscape with a beehive glowing with electric shock. The hive is surrounded by bees that are streaming out and hovering ominously in the early morning light.

143-004.poem: First O Songs for a Prelude
143-004.text: From the houses then and the workshops, and through all the doorways,Leapt they tumultuous, and lo! Manhattan arming.
caption: A bustling street scene in Manhattan with people pouring out of houses and workshops, all with a sense of urgency and purpose. The atmosphere is charged with the energy of a city mobilizing for some important event.

The picture shows a chaotic scene of people running out of their houses and workshops, filling the streets of Manhattan with a sense of urgency and anticipation. The visual style is impressionism, with bold brushstrokes and vibrant colors evoking the movement and energy of the bustling city.

143-005.poem: First O Songs for a Prelude
143-005.text: To the drum-taps prompt,The young men falling in and arming,The mechanics arming, (the trowel, the jack-plane, the blacksmith’shammer, tost aside with precipitation,)The lawyer leaving his office and arming, the judge leaving the court,The driver deserting his wagon in the street, jumping down, throwingthe reins abruptly down on the horses’ backs,The salesman leaving the store, the boss, book-keeper, porter, all leaving;Squads gather everywhere by common consent and arm,The new recruits, even boys, the old men show them how to wear theiraccoutrements, they buckle the straps carefully,Outdoors arming, indoors arming, the flash of the musket-barrels,The white tents cluster in camps, the arm’d sentries around, thesunrise cannon and again at sunset,Arm’d regiments arrive every day, pass through the city, and embarkfrom the wharves,(How good they look as they tramp down to the river, sweaty, withtheir guns on their shoulders!How I love them! how I could hug them, with their brown faces andtheir clothes and knapsacks cover’d with dust!)The blood of the city up-arm’d! arm’d! the cry everywhere,The flags flung out from the steeples of churches and from all thepublic buildings and stores,The tearful parting, the mother kisses her son, the son kisses his mother,(Loth is the mother to part, yet not a word does she speak to detain him,)The tumultuous escort, the ranks of policemen preceding, clearing the way,The unpent enthusiasm, the wild cheers of the crowd for their favorites,The artillery, the silent cannons bright as gold, drawn along,rumble lightly over the stones,(Silent cannons, soon to cease your silence,Soon unlimber’d to begin the red business;)All the mutter of preparation, all the determin’d arming,The hospital service, the lint, bandages and medicines,The women volunteering for nurses, the work begun for in earnest, nomere parade now;War! an arm’d race is advancing! the welcome for battle, no turning away!War! be it weeks, months, or years, an arm’d race is advancing towelcome it.
caption: A scene of a bustling city with people of all walks of life dropping what they are doing to arm themselves for war. Young men and mechanics grabbing whatever tools they can find, lawyers and judges leaving their work behind, and salesmen and bookkeepers abandoning their stores. Everyone congregates to arm themselves with the new recruits and old men showing the boys how to properly wear their equipment. All around the city, tents cluster, flags flung out from public buildings and stores, and cannons rolled out silently. The city is filled with unpent enthusiasm and cheers for the upcoming battle as preparations for the wounded begin in earnest, and women volunteer to help as nurses. The city is arming, and no one is turning away from what is to come.

Surrealism. A group of people drop what they are doing and begin to arm themselves with whatever is on hand - a trowel, a jack-plane, a blacksmith’s hammer. Squads gather everywhere and arm themselves with a sense of urgency.  Men, young and old leave their jobs, their families and homes to hurry along to the riverfront, where the blood of the city is up-arm'd, ready to commence the red business.

143-006.poem: First O Songs for a Prelude
143-006.text: Mannahatta a-march--and it’s O to sing it well!It’s O for a manly life in the camp.
caption: A bustling city street filled with people marching forward. A lone figure stands out, dressed in military attire, embodying the spirit of a manly life in the camp.
Street photography style. A group of people are marching through the city streets with colorful banners and flags. They seem energetic and ready for action.

143-007.poem: First O Songs for a Prelude
143-007.text: And the sturdy artillery,The guns bright as gold, the work for giants, to serve well the guns,Unlimber them! (no more as the past forty years for salutes forcourtesies merely,Put in something now besides powder and wadding.)
caption: A group of soldiers is standing beside their artillery, gazing at the majestic guns with pride. The guns are shiny and large, like those of giants. They prepare to use them not just for ceremonial salutes but for more significant purposes.

Military-style photograph. A row of bright gold artillery guns with their carriages, appearing sturdily on display. One can sense a hint of seriousness in the air, a challenging image that suggests they are ready for anything.

143-008.poem: First O Songs for a Prelude
143-008.text: And you lady of ships, you Mannahatta,Old matron of this proud, friendly, turbulent city,Often in peace and wealth you were pensive or covertly frown’d amidall your children,But now you smile with joy exulting old Mannahatta.
caption: An elderly woman wearing a crown, the personification of the city of Mannahatta, with a backdrop of ships and a bustling city. Her face shows a mix of emotions - sometimes pensive or stern among her people when there was peace and prosperity, but now she is smiling and jubilant among the chaos and excitement of the city.

With a pop art style, the city of Mannahatta is illustrated as a matron. She is depicted with her many children, sometimes sad and sometimes angry. But now, with her city prosperous, she grins with glee.

144-001.text: Arm’d year--year of the struggle,No dainty rhymes or sentimental love verses for you terrible year,Not you as some pale poetling seated at a desk lisping cadenzas piano,But as a strong man erect, clothed in blue clothes, advancing,carrying rifle on your shoulder,With well-gristled body and sunburnt face and hands, with a knife inthe belt at your side,As I heard you shouting loud, your sonorous voice ringing across thecontinent,Your masculine voice O year, as rising amid the great cities,Amid the men of Manhattan I saw you as one of the workmen, thedwellers in Manhattan,Or with large steps crossing the prairies out of Illinois and Indiana,Rapidly crossing the West with springy gait and descending the Allghanies,Or down from the great lakes or in Pennsylvania, or on deck alongthe Ohio river,Or southward along the Tennessee or Cumberland rivers, or atChattanooga on the mountain top,Saw I your gait and saw I your sinewy limbs clothed in blue, bearingweapons, robust year,Heard your determin’d voice launch’d forth again and again,Year that suddenly sang by the mouths of the round-lipp’d cannon,I repeat you, hurrying, crashing, sad, distracted year.
caption: The image shows a strong, rugged man wearing a blue outfit and carrying a rifle on his shoulder. He has a well-toned body with hands and face sunburnt from hard work. His belt carries a sharp knife. He has a loud and commanding voice that echoes across the continent. He's seen crossing the vast prairies, descending mountain tops and sailing along rivers. He's also witnessed shouting fiercely on the battlefield, determined to fight for his cause. The picture is full of energy and portrays a year of struggle, with its hurrying, crashing, and sad moments.

Realism style. A man with a rifle on his shoulder and a knife in his belt, clothed in blue clothes, advancing. His well-gristled body and sunburnt face and hands revealing he is a strong, tough workman who has been outdoors for too long. His masculine voice is heard loud and clear, shouting determinedly as he rapidly crosses from the West Coast to the East Coast and climbs up mountains in between, launching forth again and again.

145-001.text: Beat! beat! drums!--blow! bugles! blow!Through the windows--through doors--burst like a ruthless force,Into the solemn church, and scatter the congregation,Into the school where the scholar is studying;Leave not the bridegroom quiet--no happiness must he have now withhis bride,Nor the peaceful farmer any peace, ploughing his field or gatheringhis grain,So fierce you whirr and pound you drums--so shrill you bugles blow.
caption: A chaotic scene with soldiers bursting into a church and a school, interrupting the congregation and the students. A bride and groom are separated and a farmer's peaceful life is disrupted. The sound of drums and bugles are loud and deafening.

A painting, done in the style of Expressionism, depicts the chaos of war in a romanticized way. Through the use of vivid colors and thick, bold brushstrokes, a scene is created where drums and bugles blare as they burst through churches' windows, doors, and schools- disrupting all aspects of everyday life. The visual image captures the ferocity of the instruments and the destruction they wreak.

145-002.text: Beat! beat! drums!--blow! bugles! blow!Over the traffic of cities--over the rumble of wheels in the streets;Are beds prepared for sleepers at night in the houses? no sleepersmust sleep in those beds,No bargainers’ bargains by day--no brokers or speculators--wouldthey continue?Would the talkers be talking? would the singer attempt to sing?Would the lawyer rise in the court to state his case before the judge?Then rattle quicker, heavier drums--you bugles wilder blow.
caption: The picture shows soldiers marching through a city, accompanied by the loud and jarring sounds of drums and bugles. The commotion and noise disrupt the normal functioning of the city. There is no rest for those who usually sleep at night, and no business transactions can take place. Even those who usually talk or sing are silenced by the overwhelming presence of the marching army. The sounds of the drums and bugles grow louder and more chaotic.
The chaotic bustle of a city street at the beginning of a parade. The frenzy of the instruments drowns out all other sounds, as if nothing else matters in that moment.

145-003.text: Beat! beat! drums!--blow! bugles! blow!Make no parley--stop for no expostulation,Mind not the timid--mind not the weeper or prayer,Mind not the old man beseeching the young man,Let not the child’s voice be heard, nor the mother’s entreaties,Make even the trestles to shake the dead where they lie awaiting thehearses,So strong you thump O terrible drums--so loud you bugles blow.
caption: A chaotic battlefield with soldiers charging forward, surrounded by dust and smoke. The sound of drums and bugles are deafening, drowning out the cries and pleas of innocent bystanders. Even the dead are shaken on their makeshift biers. The scene is one of destruction and terror.

The picture is a chaotic battle with a sepia tone. Soldiers furiously fight with drums beating and bugles blowing. The air is full of smoke and dust, the ground full of dead bodies with trestles shaking beneath them.

146-001.poem: From Paumanok Starting I Fly Like a Bird
146-001.text: From Paumanok starting I fly like a bird,Around and around to soar to sing the idea of all,To the north betaking myself to sing there arctic songs,To Kanada till I absorb Kanada in myself, to Michigan then,To Wisconsin, Iowa, Minnesota, to sing their songs, (they are inimitable;)Then to Ohio and Indiana to sing theirs, to Missouri and Kansas andArkansas to sing theirs,To Tennessee and Kentucky, to the Carolinas and Georgia to sing theirs,To Texas and so along up toward California, to roam accepted everywhere;To sing first, (to the tap of the war-drum if need be,)The idea of all, of the Western world one and inseparable,And then the song of each member of these States.
caption: A picture of a bird in flight with a map of the United States in the background. The bird is shown flying across the country, visiting various states and absorbing the unique qualities and culture of each one. The final image shows the bird singing, with the idea of the Western world as one united concept, before transitioning into a song that represents each individual state.

The photograph features a bird's eye view of a journey starting from Paumanok (Long Island) going up north to sing arctic songs and absorb the idea of Canada, and then the journey continues south to sing the songs of each State, including the tapping of war drums if needed, while celebrating the idea of unity in the Western world. The photograph style is aerial or panoramic.

147-001.poem: Song of the Banner at Daybreak
147-001.text: Poet:O A new song, a free song,Flapping, flapping, flapping, flapping, by sounds, by voices clearer,By the wind’s voice and that of the drum,By the banner’s voice and child’s voice and sea’s voice and father’s voice,Low on the ground and high in the air,On the ground where father and child stand,In the upward air where their eyes turn,Where the banner at daybreak is flapping.
caption: A picture of a flag waving in the wind while a father and child stand with their eyes turned towards it. The sounds of voices, drums, and the sea can be heard in the background. The scene is both grounded and elevated.
Street art. A colorful banner hangs in the foreground, while a drummer beats his drum in the background. In the sky, a flock of birds soar and a father and child look up with wonder.

147-002.poem: Song of the Banner at Daybreak
147-002.text: Words! book-words! what are you?Words no more, for hearken and see,My song is there in the open air, and I must sing,With the banner and pennant a-flapping.
caption: A person standing in an open field with a banner and pennant waving in the wind, ready to sing their song to the world without the need for words on a page.

The photograph depicts a musician standing outside in a field, singing out loud with the wind blowing the banner and pennant around him. The background is a beautiful landscape of mountains and sky. The style is vibrant and dynamic, using vivid colors and strong contrasts.

147-003.poem: Song of the Banner at Daybreak
147-003.text: I’ll weave the chord and twine in,Man’s desire and babe’s desire, I’ll twine them in, I’ll put in life,I’ll put the bayonet’s flashing point, I’ll let bullets and slugs whizz,(As one carrying a symbol and menace far into the future,Crying with trumpet voice, Arouse and beware! Beware and arouse!)I’ll pour the verse with streams of blood, full of volition, full of joy,Then loosen, launch forth, to go and compete,With the banner and pennant a-flapping.
caption: A painter has portrayed the war scene with men and babies blending in. The painting displays the live bullets and life with swords flashing. The intention is to ring the alarm for the future with the trumpet's voice. The joyous verse is flowing with streams of blood but with poise and spirit. The painting shows a banner and pennant that are in motion, ready to compete.
Surrealist. An image of a blood-red sea with guns and bayonets scattered throughout. A trumpet hovers above the sea and interwoven throughout are symbols of life, desire, and competition.

147-004.poem: Song of the Banner at Daybreak
147-004.text: Pennant:Come up here, bard, bard,Come up here, soul, soul,Come up here, dear little child,To fly in the clouds and winds with me, and play with the measureless light.
caption: An image of a pennant waving in the wind, attached to a high post on a green hill. A bard, a soul, and a little child are depicted flying in the clouds with the measureless light.
Surrealistic. A giant, ethereal figure with wings reaching down to a small child, lifting them up towards the sky. A bard stands next to them with arms outstretched.

147-005.poem: Song of the Banner at Daybreak
147-005.text: Child:Father what is that in the sky beckoning to me with long finger?And what does it say to me all the while?
caption: A father and his child standing in wonder, gazing up at the sky. The child points up with curiosity while the father looks on with a smile. The beckoning figure in the sky remains a mystery, but their imagination runs wild with possible messages it might have for them.
Surrealist. A child stands below a cloudy sky with a long, bony finger reaching down to the child from the sky. The child stares up in wonder and curiosity.

147-006.poem: Song of the Banner at Daybreak
147-006.text: Father:Nothing my babe you see in the sky,And nothing at all to you it says--but look you my babe,Look at these dazzling things in the houses, and see you the money-shops opening,And see you the vehicles preparing to crawl along the streets with goods;These, ah these, how valued and toil’d for these!How envied by all the earth.
caption: A father pointing to a bustling cityscape, filled with glittering skyscrapers and busy vehicles. The father explains the importance of money, possessions, and status to his child while they watch the world go by.

The visual style is street photography. An infant in a stroller looks at a busy street with many commercial buildings on either side. People hurry about, going in and out of shops, loading and unloading trucks, all apparently captivated by the material wealth to be found in the city, while the baby is blissfully unaware.

147-007.poem: Song of the Banner at Daybreak
147-007.text: Poet:Fresh and rosy red the sun is mounting high,On floats the sea in distant blue careering through its channels,On floats the wind over the breast of the sea setting in toward land,The great steady wind from west or west-by-south,Floating so buoyant with milk-white foam on the waters.
caption: A panoramic picture of the ocean with the sun rising and reflecting off the water. The wind is blowing towards the land, causing white foam to appear on the surface of the blue water.

With a seascape style, the image captures the rising sun illuminating the ocean and creating white caps. In the distance, a sailing vessel glides on the blue sea, propelled by the steady wind blowing from the west.

147-008.poem: Song of the Banner at Daybreak
147-008.text: But I am not the sea nor the red sun,I am not the wind with girlish laughter,Not the immense wind which strengthens, not the wind which lashes,Not the spirit that ever lashes its own body to terror and death,But I am that which unseen comes and sings, sings, sings,Which babbles in brooks and scoots in showers on the land,Which the birds know in the woods mornings and evenings,And the shore-sands know and the hissing wave, and that banner and pennant,Aloft there flapping and flapping.
caption: A beautiful landscape with a blue sky, mountains, and a river flowing. Birds are chirping and the waves are crashing on the shore. The wind is blowing softly and there is a sense of peace and tranquility.
Surrealist. An ethereal figure, surrounded by babbling brooks and showering rain. Birds are perched on trees amidst a beautiful landscape, with a flag waving in the distance.

147-009.poem: Song of the Banner at Daybreak
147-009.text: Child:O father it is alive--it is full of people--it has children,O now it seems to me it is talking to its children,I hear it--it talks to me--O it is wonderful!O it stretches--it spreads and runs so fast--O my father,It is so broad it covers the whole sky.
caption: A child gazing at a vibrant, bustling cityscape with wonder in their eyes. The city appears alive, full of people and children. It seems to communicate with them, stretching and spreading as far as the eye can see, covering the whole sky.

Using impressionism as the art style, the picture shows a child with wide open eyes, looking up at the sky. Sun shines through a tree with leaves, and people are gathered together enjoying nature. The child seems to listen in on an animated conversation, as if the adults are sharing secrets with him.

147-010.poem: Song of the Banner at Daybreak
147-010.text: Father:Cease, cease, my foolish babe,What you are saying is sorrowful to me, much ’t displeases me;Behold with the rest again I say, behold not banners and pennants aloft,But the well-prepared pavements behold, and mark the solid-wall’d houses.
caption: A young child pointing upwards with an expression of enthusiasm as their father looks on with concern. The father places his hands on the child's shoulders and gestures towards the sturdy, well-built structures in the distance.

In the style of Realism, the picture shows a father with a concerned expression on his face trying to console his child who is saying something that makes him unhappy. There are no banners or flags in sight, but rather the focus is on the well-constructed pavements and sturdy houses.

147-011.poem: Song of the Banner at Daybreak
147-011.text: Banner and Pennant:Speak to the child O bard out of Manhattan,To our children all, or north or south of Manhattan,Point this day, leaving all the rest, to us over all--and yet we knownot why,For what are we, mere strips of cloth profiting nothing,Only flapping in the wind?
caption: A pennant and a banner waving in the wind on top of a tall building in Manhattan. The scene represents patriotism and speaks to children about how a piece of cloth cannot change the world, but it can represent ideas and values.

The visual style is surrealism. A poetic, illuminated banner and pennant floating in the sky above Manhattan. Children from the North, South, East, and West all gather below, looking up in wonder at the seemingly living strips of cloth, each feeling inexplicably drawn to their message of unity despite not understanding why.

147-013.poem: Song of the Banner at Daybreak
147-013.text: Poet:I hear and see not strips of cloth alone,I hear the tramp of armies, I hear the challenging sentry,I hear the jubilant shouts of millions of men, I hear Liberty!I hear the drums beat and the trumpets blowing,I myself move abroad swift-rising flying then,I use the wings of the land-bird and use the wings of the sea-bird,and look down as from a height,I do not deny the precious results of peace, I see populous citieswith wealth incalculable,I see numberless farms, I see the farmers working in their fields or barns,I see mechanics working, I see buildings everywhere founded, goingup, or finish’d,I see trains of cars swiftly speeding along railroad tracks drawn bythe locomotives,I see the stores, depots, of Boston, Baltimore, Charleston, New Orleans,I see far in the West the immense area of grain, I dwell awhile hovering,I pass to the lumber forests of the North, and again to the Southernplantation, and again to California;Sweeping the whole I see the countless profit, the busy gatherings,earn’d wages,See the Identity formed out of thirty-eight spacious and haughtyStates, (and many more to come,)See forts on the shores of harbors, see ships sailing in and out;Then over all, (aye! aye!) my little and lengthen’d pennant shapedlike a sword,Runs swiftly up indicating war and defiance--and now the halyardshave rais’d it,Side of my banner broad and blue, side of my starry banner,Discarding peace over all the sea and land.
caption: A picture of a bird's-eye view of the United States, with many different scenes depicted. There are soldiers marching, jubilant crowds, and the American flag waving high. There are bustling cities and farms with hardworking farmers. Trains and ships of commerce move across the country. Finally, a banner with a sword shape unfurls, indicating war and defiance.

Photomontage. Various landscapes and cityscapes illustrating the growth and prosperity of America, connected by the movement of the central figure, who travels from place to place to witness the triumphs of industry, agriculture, and transportation. Finally, the figure raises a flag that signifies war and defiance, anticipating the conflict that will test the unity and identity of the nation.

147-014.poem: Song of the Banner at Daybreak
147-014.text: Banner and Pennant:Yet louder, higher, stronger, bard! yet farther, wider cleave!No longer let our children deem us riches and peace alone,We may be terror and carnage, and are so now,Not now are we any one of these spacious and haughty States, (norany five, nor ten,)Nor market nor depot we, nor money-bank in the city,But these and all, and the brown and spreading land, and the minesbelow, are ours,And the shores of the sea are ours, and the rivers great and small,And the fields they moisten, and the crops and the fruits are ours,Bays and channels and ships sailing in and out are ours--while we over all,Over the area spread below, the three or four millions of squaremiles, the capitals,The forty millions of people,--O bard! in life and death supreme,We, even we, henceforth flaunt out masterful, high up above,Not for the present alone, for a thousand years chanting through you,This song to the soul of one poor little child.
caption: A grand and expansive landscape featuring mountains, rivers, and oceans with ships sailing in and out. The image depicts ownership of land, crops, and resources, with the people and areas belonging to the narrator. The image is meant to convey strength and supremacy, to be celebrated for a thousand years.

A photograph with the American flag waving high in the sky at full mast. The photo shows diverse landscapes across the United States, including rivers, farmland, bustling cities, and mountains. It conveys the message that the country belongs to all its citizens and that the people are the ones who make the nation great, not just the geography or infrastructure.

147-015.poem: Song of the Banner at Daybreak
147-015.text: Child:O my father I like not the houses,They will never to me be any thing, nor do I like money,But to mount up there I would like, O father dear, that banner I like,That pennant I would be and must be.
caption: A child standing in front of tall, grand buildings with a sad expression. The child looks up to a distant mountain with a determined expression and points at a flag on the mountain top that they want to be. The child's father stands behind them, listening.
Using a minimalist style, the image depicts a young child daydreaming of a flag fluttering in the wind atop a mountain with a distant view of cityscape, overlooking houses and money left far below.

147-016.poem: Song of the Banner at Daybreak
147-016.text: Father:Child of mine you fill me with anguish,To be that pennant would be too fearful,Little you know what it is this day, and after this day, forever,It is to gain nothing, but risk and defy every thing,Forward to stand in front of wars--and O, such wars!--what have youto do with them?With passions of demons, slaughter, premature death?
caption: A father stands behind his child, who is looking off into the distance with fear and confusion on their face. The father appears anguished as he warns the child of the dangers of going to war. The scene is dark and ominous, with images of demonic passions, slaughter, and premature death looming in the background.
Expressionist. A father's face twisted in anguish, while clutching his child's hand. In the background, an abstract representation of war and destruction, with demons and blood-like imagery.

147-017.poem: Song of the Banner at Daybreak
147-017.text: Banner:Demons and death then I sing,Put in all, aye all will I, sword-shaped pennant for war,And a pleasure new and ecstatic, and the prattled yearning of children,Blent with the sounds of the peaceful land and the liquid wash of the sea,And the black ships fighting on the sea envelop’d in smoke,And the icy cool of the far, far north, with rustling cedars and pines,And the whirr of drums and the sound of soldiers marching, and thehot sun shining south,And the beach-waves combing over the beach on my Eastern shore,and my Western shore the same,And all between those shores, and my ever running Mississippi withbends and chutes,And my Illinois fields, and my Kansas fields, and my fields of Missouri,The Continent, devoting the whole identity without reserving an atom,Pour in! whelm that which asks, which sings, with all and the yield of all,Fusing and holding, claiming, devouring the whole,No more with tender lip, nor musical labial sound,But out of the night emerging for good, our voice persuasive no more,Croaking like crows here in the wind.
caption: A chaotic scene featuring different elements such as war, children playing, peaceful landscapes, ships fighting, cold north, sun shining south, beach waves, and marching soldiers. The continent is consuming and fusing everything together, with no reserve. The scene appears dark and harsh as the voice emerges croaking like crows in the wind.

A dramatic, surrealist painting filled with chaotic images of death and war, contrasted with serene landscapes such as beaches, fields, and forests, and culminating in an overwhelming, all-encompassing depiction of the entire continent, capturing all its beauty and destruction in one fateful moment.

147-018.poem: Song of the Banner at Daybreak
147-018.text: Poet:My limbs, my veins dilate, my theme is clear at last,Banner so broad advancing out of the night, I sing you haughty and resolute,I burst through where I waited long, too long, deafen’d and blinded,My hearing and tongue are come to me, (a little child taught me,)I hear from above O pennant of war your ironical call and demand,Insensate! insensate! (yet I at any rate chant you,) O banner!Not houses of peace indeed are you, nor any nor all theirprosperity, (if need be, you shall again have every one of thosehouses to destroy them,You thought not to destroy those valuable houses, standing fast,full of comfort, built with money,May they stand fast, then? not an hour except you above them and allstand fast;)O banner, not money so precious are you, not farm produce you, northe material good nutriment,Nor excellent stores, nor landed on wharves from the ships,Not the superb ships with sail-power or steam-power, fetching andcarrying cargoes,Nor machinery, vehicles, trade, nor revenues--but you as henceforthI see you,Running up out of the night, bringing your cluster of stars,(ever-enlarging stars,)Divider of daybreak you, cutting the air, touch’d by the sun,measuring the sky,(Passionately seen and yearn’d for by one poor little child,While others remain busy or smartly talking, forever teachingthrift, thrift;)O you up there! O pennant! where you undulate like a snake hissingso curious,Out of reach, an idea only, yet furiously fought for, risking bloodydeath, loved by me,So loved--O you banner leading the day with stars brought from the night!Valueless, object of eyes, over all and demanding all--(absoluteowner of all)--O banner and pennant!I too leave the rest--great as it is, it is nothing--houses, machinesare nothing--I see them not,I see but you, O warlike pennant! O banner so broad, with stripes,sing you only,Flapping up there in the wind.
caption: A picture of a majestic banner waving at the break of dawn. The banner symbolizes something greater than material possessions or structures, as it represents a call to battle and a willingness to risk everything for its cause. Despite its abstractness, the banner holds immense value and is passionately revered by a single child. The banner is the only thing that truly matters, flapping proudly in the wind.

The photograph is in black and white, with an image of a flag with broad stripes and many stars, fluttering high in the sky. The flag stands above everything else, and its image is both all-encompassing and overwhelming, as if it were the only important thing in the world. The viewer cannot help but be drawn to its powerful, symbolic presence, as it shines like a beacon in the dark.

148-001.poem: Rise O Days from Your Fathomless Deeps
148-001.text: 1Rise O days from your fathomless deeps, till you loftier, fiercer sweep,Long for my soul hungering gymnastic I devour’d what the earth gave me,Long I roam’d amid the woods of the north, long I watch’d Niagara pouring,I travel’d the prairies over and slept on their breast, I cross’dthe Nevadas, I cross’d the plateaus,I ascended the towering rocks along the Pacific, I sail’d out to sea,I sail’d through the storm, I was refresh’d by the storm,I watch’d with joy the threatening maws of the waves,
caption: A montage of travels and adventures featuring a person delving into the depths of nature's wonders. From roaming through the northern woods to watching Niagara falls, crossing the Nevadas and plateaus, ascending rocks near the Pacific, sailing through the storm and being awed by the power of the ocean waves.

The picture is a series of snapshots showing a person's journey and their awe-inspiring experiences. The snapshots have been edited with Instagram's "Valencia" filter, which makes them slightly dark and vintage-like. The photos include Niagara Falls, the vast prairies, the towering rocks of the Pacific, and a stormy sea.

148-002.poem: Rise O Days from Your Fathomless Deeps
148-002.text: I mark’d the white combs where they career’d so high, curling over,I heard the wind piping, I saw the black clouds,Saw from below what arose and mounted, (O superb!
