167-006.text: It shall be customary in the houses and streets to see manly affection,The most dauntless and rude shall touch face to face lightly,The dependence of Liberty shall be lovers,The continuance of Equality shall be comrades.
caption: A vibrant and inclusive city scene with people of all genders and backgrounds engaging in expressed and genuine displays of affection. The norms of society have shifted to allow and encourage this behavior, promoting love and friendship as key values in creating a harmonious community.

Realistic. A photo of two men embracing in a street with other people around. The image portrays love and affection between men and the importance of unity and friendship in fighting for freedom and equality.

167-007.poem: Over the Carnage Rose Prophetic a Voice
167-007.text: These shall tie you and band you stronger than hoops of iron,I, ecstatic, O partners! O lands! with the love of lovers tie you.
caption: A group of people are holding hands and embracing each other tightly. They look ecstatic and joyful, with a picturesque background of vast landscapes. Their gestures symbolize an unbreakable bond, stronger than iron.
Surrealist. Two figures intertwining, their limbs appear as hoops of iron, with the land and sky merging to form a dreamlike background, symbolizing the strength and passion of their love.

167-008.poem: Over the Carnage Rose Prophetic a Voice
167-008.text: (Were you looking to be held together by lawyers?Or by an agreement on a paper? or by arms?Nay, nor the world, nor any living thing, will so cohere.)
caption: A scattered puzzle that cannot be pieced together by legal documents or any physical embrace. The world and its inhabitants cannot be bound together in this way.

Using the abstract art style, the picture displays disconnected figures of lawyers, paper sheets with contracts, and people embracing each other, all floating chaotically. None of them able to connect and create a cohesive image, symbolizing that neither law, paper, nor physical touch can hold anyone together.

168-001.poem: I Saw Old General at Bay
168-001.text: I saw old General at bay,(Old as he was, his gray eyes yet shone out in battle like stars,)His small force was now completely hemm’d in, in his works,He call’d for volunteers to run the enemy’s lines, a desperate emergency,I saw a hundred and more step forth from the ranks, but two or threewere selected,I saw them receive their orders aside, they listen’d with care, theadjutant was very grave,I saw them depart with cheerfulness, freely risking their lives.
caption: An old General stands tall with a determined look on his face, his gray eyes shining like stars in the midst of battle. His small army is now surrounded by the enemy. He desperately calls for volunteers to break through the enemy lines. Over a hundred soldiers step forward but only two or three are chosen. These brave individuals listen intensely to their orders given by the adjutant. They depart with cheerfulness, ready to risk their lives for the greater good.

A realistic wartime photograph. General and his small group of soldiers are cornered in their base surrounded by the enemy. The General is calling for volunteers to break the enemy's lines. A hundred soldiers step forward, but only two or three are selected, and they receive their life threatening mission instructions from an adjutant who looks very grave.

169-001.text: While my wife at my side lies slumbering, and the wars are over long,And my head on the pillow rests at home, and the vacant midnight passes,And through the stillness, through the dark, I hear, just hear, thebreath of my infant,There in the room as I wake from sleep this vision presses upon me;The engagement opens there and then in fantasy unreal,The skirmishers begin, they crawl cautiously ahead, I hear theirregular snap! snap!I hear the sounds of the different missiles, the short t-h-t! t-h-t!of the rifle-balls,I see the shells exploding leaving small white clouds, I hear thegreat shells shrieking as they pass,The grape like the hum and whirr of wind through the trees,(tumultuous now the contest rages,)All the scenes at the batteries rise in detail before me again,The crashing and smoking, the pride of the men in their pieces,The chief-gunner ranges and sights his piece and selects a fuse ofthe right time,After firing I see him lean aside and look eagerly off to note the effect;Elsewhere I hear the cry of a regiment charging, (the young colonelleads himself this time with brandish’d sword,)I see the gaps cut by the enemy’s volleys, (quickly fill’d up, no delay,)I breathe the suffocating smoke, then the flat clouds hover lowconcealing all;Now a strange lull for a few seconds, not a shot fired on either side,Then resumed the chaos louder than ever, with eager calls andorders of officers,While from some distant part of the field the wind wafts to my earsa shout of applause, (some special success,)And ever the sound of the cannon far or near, (rousing even indreams a devilish exultation and all the old mad joy in thedepths of my soul,)And ever the hastening of infantry shifting positions, batteries,cavalry, moving hither and thither,(The falling, dying, I heed not, the wounded dripping and redheed not, some to the rear are hobbling,)Grime, heat, rush, aide-de-camps galloping by or on a full run,With the patter of small arms, the warning s-s-t of the rifles,(these in my vision I hear or see,)And bombs bursting in air, and at night the vari-color’d rockets.
caption: A man is lying in bed with his wife sleeping beside him. In the silence, he hears the breath of his infant. He envisions a battlefield where the skirmishers cautiously crawl forward and the soldiers fight. He imagines the sounds of different weapons and the sight of shells exploding. He sees the pride of the soldiers as they fire their weapons and eagerly watch the effect. He hears the calls of officers and the sound of victory in the distance. The man feels the devilish exultation and joy of war deep within his soul. The chaos of the battle rages on and on with the movement of soldiers and the sound of bombs bursting in the air.

Surrealism. In the center, a man is sleeping with a baby adjacent to him. Behind them, there is a chaotic and scattered battle scene with cannons and soldiers, and thick smoke filling the air while bombs and rockets explode in the distance.

170-001.text: Who are you dusky woman, so ancient hardly human,With your woolly-white and turban’d head, and bare bony feet?Why rising by the roadside here, do you the colors greet?
caption: An old and weathered, but dignified woman with a white headwrap and bare feet is standing by the roadside, holding out a bunch of colorful flowers.

The image features a monochromatic photograph of an elderly woman with a turban, which covers hair as white as wool, standing barefoot by the side of the road. She holds out her hand and greets the cars with a warm smile, as if she is saying hello to familiar friends.

170-002.text: (’Tis while our army lines Carolina’s sands and pines,Forth from thy hovel door thou Ethiopia com’st to me,As under doughty Sherman I march toward the sea.)
caption: A proud African American coming out of their humble home to join the march of the army led by Sherman towards the sea, amid the sandy and pine-filled landscape of the Carolina region.

A black and white photograph in a documentary-style showing a woman from a rural African-American community coming outside of her hut. In the background, there are American soldiers marching toward the sea in the midst of the Civil War.

170-003.text: Me master years a hundred since from my parents sunder’d,A little child, they caught me as the savage beast is caught,Then hither me across the sea the cruel slaver brought.
caption: A lonely figure with a solemn expression, standing on a shoreline with a slaver ship in the distance. The image conveys feelings of separation, captivity, and despair.
Realistic. A painting of a young child being taken from their parents by wildlife trappers, next to a sea where a slave ship waits.

170-004.text: No further does she say, but lingering all the day,Her high-borne turban’d head she wags, and rolls her darkling eye,And courtesies to the regiments, the guidons moving by.
caption: A woman with a high turban nods and curtsies to the passing regiments with marching guidons while rolling her dark eyes all day.
Illustrated in a vintage style, a regally dressed woman stands on a busy street corner, wagging her head and rolling her eyes as soldiers and their flags pass by, acknowledging them with a curtsy.

170-005.text: What is it fateful woman, so blear, hardly human?Why wag your head with turban bound, yellow, red and green?Are the things so strange and marvelous you see or have seen?
caption: An old woman with a turban, her face is wrinkled and appears tired. She tilts her head as if seeing something strange and unexplainable. The turban is decorated with yellow, red and green colors, adding some vibrance to the picture.

An abstract portrait of a woman with blurred edges, her face twisted into an uncomfortable grimace, wearing a brightly colored turban with shades of yellow, red, and green. The background is filled with surreal, otherworldly images, conveying a sense of strange and wondrous experiences.

171-001.text: Not youth pertains to me,Nor delicatesse, I cannot beguile the time with talk,Awkward in the parlor, neither a dancer nor elegant,In the learn’d coterie sitting constrain’d and still, for learninginures not to me,Beauty, knowledge, inure not to me--yet there are two or three thingsinure to me,I have nourish’d the wounded and sooth’d many a dying soldier,And at intervals waiting or in the midst of camp,Composed these songs.
caption: An older person, rough around the edges, who doesn't quite fit in with the upper-class society. However, their strength lies in their ability to care for the wounded, specifically soldiers, and they find solace in creating music during times of waiting or in the midst of chaos.

Documentary. An image of an aged but strong figure, neither physically attractive nor refined, sitting at a hospital bedside, tending the wounded with a face full of concern and care. Behind them, you see armies in the background on break, singing songs of comfort and encouragement.

172-001.text: Race of veterans--race of victors!Race of the soil, ready for conflict--race of the conquering march!(No more credulity’s race, abiding-temper’d race,)Race henceforth owning no law but the law of itself,Race of passion and the storm.
caption: A powerful and determined army made up of veteran soldiers and victorious warriors. The soldiers are battle-ready and embarking on a conquering march. They are strong-willed and temperate with unshakable beliefs. They reject blind faith and instead have a passionate and stormy drive to succeed.

The image consists of a photograph of a diverse group of individuals of all ages gathered in a field. They embody the spirit of the veteran, the victor, and the conqueror. They are determined, focused, and exhibit an intense passion for their cause. The photograph is in a gritty urban style, with deep blues and greys to convey the emotion and energy of the group.

173-001.text: World take good notice, silver stars fading,Milky hue ript, wet of white detaching,Coals thirty-eight, baleful and burning,Scarlet, significant, hands off warning,Now and henceforth flaunt from these shores.
caption: A chaotic, fiery scene with crimson hues dominating the foreground. The silvery stars in the background are gradually fading away, and the white milky way has been ripped and torn. The environment is hazardous, with 38 flaming coals warning any viewers to keep a safe distance. An unmistakable, bold gesture serves as a clear sign for all to keep away from these shores.

Surrealistic. A desolate beach with a stormy sky above. In the foreground, cold silver and white colors are being torn away, revealing a fiery, reddish-orange underlayer. A sign, unrecognizable from this distance, stands as a warning.

174-001.text: O tan-faced prairie-boy,Before you came to camp came many a welcome gift,Praises and presents came and nourishing food, till at last amongthe recruits,You came, taciturn, with nothing to give--we but look’d on each other,When lo! more than all the gifts of the world you gave me.
caption: In the picture, a group of young men are gathered in a military camp. Each recruit brings gifts and nourishing food to share, except for one young man with a tan complexion who remains quiet and keeps to himself. However, the other recruits quickly realize that his presence alone is the greatest gift of all.

Realistic Painted Portrait. A young man with a tan complexion, a group of people behind him giving gifts and compliments. He accepts their gifts silently, but it is the connection made between him and another man that transcends all the material offerings.

175-001.text: Look down fair moon and bathe this scene,Pour softly down night’s nimbus floods on faces ghastly, swollen, purple,On the dead on their backs with arms toss’d wide,Pour down your unstinted nimbus sacred moon.
caption: A full moon illuminating a scene of death. Lifeless bodies are scattered on the ground, their faces displaying pain and purple discoloration. The moonlight serves as a sacred blessing to the deceased.

This picture is dimly lit by the moon's light, where we see a group of lifeless bodies lying on their backs with their arms stretched. Their faces show signs of a struggle or torture, giving them a ghastly and swollen appearance. The scene is eerie yet calm, casting a spell on the viewer with the moon's unstinted nimbus. This image is a dark form of landscape photography.

176-001.text: Word over all, beautiful as the sky,Beautiful that war and all its deeds of carnage must in time beutterly lost,That the hands of the sisters Death and Night incessantly softlywash again, and ever again, this solid world;For my enemy is dead, a man divine as myself is dead,I look where he lies white-faced and still in the coffin--I draw near,Bend down and touch lightly with my lips the white face in the coffin.
caption: A person stands over a white casket with a serene expression. The harsh realities of war have left him with a heavy heart, but he finds comfort in the beauty of the sky. He kneels to say goodbye and honor his foe with a gesture of reverence.
Realistic Art style. A vast, majestic sky with clouds forming various shapes dominates the picture. In the foreground, a sorrowful man stands, kissing the forehead of a dead man in a coffin.

177-001.poem: How Solemn As One by One [Washington City, 1865]
177-001.text: How solemn as one by one,As the ranks returning worn and sweaty, as the men file by where stand,As the faces the masks appear, as I glance at the faces studying the masks,(As I glance upward out of this page studying you, dear friend,whoever you are,)How solemn the thought of my whispering soul to each in the ranks,and to you,I see behind each mask that wonder a kindred soul,O the bullet could never kill what you really are, dear friend,Nor the bayonet stab what you really are;The soul! yourself I see, great as any, good as the best,Waiting secure and content, which the bullet could never kill,Nor the bayonet stab O friend.
caption: An image of soldiers returning from war, tired and sweaty, with masks on their faces. The speaker ponders the soul within each soldier and every person, including the viewer. Despite the dangers of war, the soul remains unbreakable - it is what truly defines us as individuals.

The visual style is black and white photojournalism. The picture shows rows of soldiers walking past with their faces covered by masks, in agony and fatigue. The speaker reflects on how despite the masks and war wounds, he sees kindred souls and the indestructible nature of the human spirit.

178-001.poem: As I Lay with My Head in Your Lap Camerado
178-001.text: As I lay with my head in your lap camerado,The confession I made I resume, what I said to you and the open airI resume,I know I am restless and make others so,I know my words are weapons full of danger, full of death,For I confront peace, security, and all the settled laws, tounsettle them,I am more resolute because all have denied me than I could ever havebeen had all accepted me,I heed not and have never heeded either experience, cautions,majorities, nor ridicule,And the threat of what is call’d hell is little or nothing to me,And the lure of what is call’d heaven is little or nothing to me;Dear camerado! I confess I have urged you onward with me, and stillurge you, without the least idea what is our destination,Or whether we shall be victorious, or utterly quell’d and defeated.
caption: A person lying with their head on someone's lap, looking up at the open sky above. One person seems to be confessing to the other, while they both appear to be deep in thought. The confession seems to make the speaker more determined to challenge authority and not be bothered by the consequences. The destination of their journey is unknown, but the companionship and the journey itself are more important than success or failure.

Photography style: Black and White portrait. The picture shows a person laying with their head in another person's lap. In the person's eyes, there is a reflection of unsettlement and turmoil as they confess their restlessness and desire to unsettle the status quo.

179-001.text: Delicate cluster! flag of teeming life!Covering all my lands--all my seashores lining!Flag of death! (how I watch’d you through the smoke of battle pressing!How I heard you flap and rustle, cloth defiant!)Flag cerulean--sunny flag, with the orbs of night dappled!Ah my silvery beauty--ah my woolly white and crimson!Ah to sing the song of you, my matron mighty!My sacred one, my mother.
caption: A blooming flower with a mix of blue cerulean and sunny colors. It has a tender appearance but also a hint of danger, like it symbolizes both life and death. Its beauty is irresistible and it represents a source of comfort and strength, like a mother figure.

In the style of surrealism, an amalgamation of a botanical garden and a seascape is depicted. An enormous flower serves as a colorful flag, standing tall amidst smoke and the battles it has bravely withstood. The flower is a silver and crimson matron, a source of life and beauty, but it is also deathly, filling both the sea and the shore.

180-001.text: Did you ask dulcet rhymes from me?Did you seek the civilian’s peaceful and languishing rhymes?Did you find what I sang erewhile so hard to follow?Why I was not singing erewhile for you to follow, to understand--noram I now;(I have been born of the same as the war was born,The drum-corps’ rattle is ever to me sweet music, I love well themartial dirge,With slow wail and convulsive throb leading the officer’s funeral;)What to such as you anyhow such a poet as I? therefore leave my works,And go lull yourself with what you can understand, and with piano-tunes,For I lull nobody, and you will never understand me.
caption: A picture of a person playing a drum with a solemn expression on their face. Soldiers in military attire can be seen in the background. The viewer may not understand the intensity and meaning behind the music, but the musician plays on regardless.

The picture is painted with expressionism style. A person is standing, reaching out, and singing with an intense expression on their face. In the background, there is a military funeral procession with mourners procession along with drums and horns. Another group of people in civilian attire stand in contrast, watching without understanding, simply listening to soft piano music.

181-001.text: Lo, Victress on the peaks,Where thou with mighty brow regarding the world,(The world O Libertad, that vainly conspired against thee,)Out of its countless beleaguering toils, after thwarting them all,Dominant, with the dazzling sun around thee,Flauntest now unharm’d in immortal soundness and bloom--lo, inthese hours supreme,No poem proud, I chanting bring to thee, nor mastery’s rapturous verse,But a cluster containing night’s darkness and blood-dripping wounds,And psalms of the dead.
caption: A triumphant woman stands atop a mountain peak, looking out into the world with a mighty expression. Despite the world's attempts to defeat her, she stands unscathed in the brightness of the sun. The picture reflects a sense of victory and strength, with a touch of darkness and the memory of those who have been lost.

Surrealist. A giant, statue-like figure with a mighty brow stands atop a mountain peak, the world below it in chaos, looking out at the dazzling sun. The figure is surrounded by darkness and wounds while holding a cluster of blood-dripping flowers, with a haunting choir of the dead providing an eerie background music.

182-001.poem: Spirit Whose Work Is Done [Washington City, 1865]
182-001.text: Spirit whose work is done--spirit of dreadful hours!Ere departing fade from my eyes your forests of bayonets;Spirit of gloomiest fears and doubts, (yet onward ever unfalteringpressing,)Spirit of many a solemn day and many a savage scene--electric spirit,That with muttering voice through the war now closed, like atireless phantom flitted,Rousing the land with breath of flame, while you beat and beat the drum,Now as the sound of the drum, hollow and harsh to the last,reverberates round me,As your ranks, your immortal ranks, return, return from the battles,As the muskets of the young men yet lean over their shoulders,As I look on the bayonets bristling over their shoulders,As those slanted bayonets, whole forests of them appearing in thedistance, approach and pass on, returning homeward,Moving with steady motion, swaying to and fro to the right and left,Evenly lightly rising and falling while the steps keep time;Spirit of hours I knew, all hectic red one day, but pale as death next day,Touch my mouth ere you depart, press my lips close,Leave me your pulses of rage--bequeath them to me--fill me withcurrents convulsive,Let them scorch and blister out of my chants when you are gone,Let them identify you to the future in these songs.
caption: A dark and haunting picture of a spirit of war, whose work is done. Images of forests of bayonets and savage scenes are represented by blurred shapes in the background. The spirit is depicted as an electric force, flitting through the war and rousing the land with breaths of flame. The picture captures the return of the immortal ranks from battle, muskets leaned over their shoulders, bayonets bristling in the distance. The steps of the soldiers are captured in their steady movement, swaying to and fro to the right and left. The spirit is depicted as leaving pulses of rage, scorching and blistering the chants that remain, while identifying itself to the future through the songs.

The photograph is in black and white and has a gritty texture. In the foreground, a mass of bayonets protrude from the frame. In the middle-ground, ghostly soldiers march forward, with the impression that they are returning from war. The backdrop is filled with trees, presenting a sense of a forest.

183-001.text: Adieu O soldier,You of the rude campaigning, (which we shared,)The rapid march, the life of the camp,The hot contention of opposing fronts, the long manœuvre,Red battles with their slaughter, the stimulus, the strong terrific game,Spell of all brave and manly hearts, the trains of time through youand like of you all fill’d,With war and war’s expression.
caption: An image of a soldier in uniform, with a rugged and experienced look on their face. In the background, there are scenes of war and battles, with explosions and smoke. The soldier is standing tall, representing the bravery and strength of all soldiers who have fought in wars throughout history.

In an impressionist style, a painting depicts two soldiers, one with a sad and emotional expression hugging the other, who appears to be leaving for war. The painting portrays the excitement, fear, and the brutality of war all at once, evoking emotions of bravery and despair.

183-002.text: Adieu dear comrade,Your mission is fulfill’d--but I, more warlike,Myself and this contentious soul of mine,Still on our own campaigning bound,Through untried roads with ambushes opponents lined,Through many a sharp defeat and many a crisis, often baffled,Here marching, ever marching on, a war fight out--aye here,To fiercer, weightier battles give expression.
caption: A person waving goodbye to their companion who has completed their mission, but the person is still on their own journey. They are traveling on untested terrain with obstacles and enemies, facing defeats and crises, but they are determined to continue the fight. The expression on their face is fierce and determined, as they prepare for even more difficult battles ahead.

The picture is done in graffiti style, featuring two soldiers with their backs facing each other. One soldier has a victorious and confident expression, walking away from the other who still looks determined and ready for the next fight. The latter soldier turns towards a path that is full of challenges and oppositions while the victorious one is walking towards a heavier and more significant battle.

184-001.text: Turn O Libertad, for the war is over,From it and all henceforth expanding, doubting no more, resolute,sweeping the world,Turn from lands retrospective recording proofs of the past,From the singers that sing the trailing glories of the past,From the chants of the feudal world, the triumphs of kings, slavery, caste,Turn to the world, the triumphs reserv’d and to come--give up thatbackward world,Leave to the singers of hitherto, give them the trailing past,But what remains remains for singers for you--wars to come are for you,(Lo, how the wars of the past have duly inured to you, and the warsof the present also inure;)Then turn, and be not alarm’d O Libertad--turn your undying face,To where the future, greater than all the past,Is swiftly, surely preparing for you.
caption: A figure stands in the center of a crossroad, with paths stretching out in all directions. The figure looks back at the paths behind them, filled with the remnants of the past - kings, slavery, and caste. With a resolute expression, the figure turns their face towards the future, where greater triumphs and battles await.

The picture is minimalist with an abstract style. It starts with a figure walking away from the past, towards the horizon. The figure has a resolute expression and is leaving behind the chants of an old world. In the distance, there is a faint albeit bright speck representing a promising future.

185-001.poem: To the Leaven’d Soil They Trod
185-001.text: To the leaven’d soil they trod calling I sing for the last,(Forth from my tent emerging for good, loosing, untying the tent-ropes,)In the freshness the forenoon air, in the far-stretching circuitsand vistas again to peace restored,To the fiery fields emanative and the endless vistas beyond, to theSouth and the North,To the leaven’d soil of the general Western world to attest my songs,To the Alleghanian hills and the tireless Mississippi,To the rocks I calling sing, and all the trees in the woods,To the plains of the poems of heroes, to the prairies spreading wide,To the far-off sea and the unseen winds, and the sane impalpable air;And responding they answer all, (but not in words,)The average earth, the witness of war and peace, acknowledges mutely,The prairie draws me close, as the father to bosom broad the son,The Northern ice and rain that began me nourish me to the end,But the hot sun of the South is to fully ripen my songs.
caption: A panoramic view of a vast, expansive landscape with mountains, fields, and forests stretching as far as the eye can see. The sun shines brightly in the clear blue sky, illuminating the area with its warmth. The silhouette of a lone figure can be seen in the distance, standing amidst the flora and fauna. The land, the trees, and the elements seem to respond to the presence of the figure, acknowledging them without words. The image captures the beauty and grandeur of nature, and the unspoken bond between man and the environment.

The picture is composed of sprawling natural vistas that stretch out far beyond the horizon. It includes the Alleghanian hills, endless fiery fields, tireless rivers, trees, woods and prairies, and the unseen sea. The picture details the general Western world, the far-lived soil that has a witness to war and peace, and the elements that began the life's journey of the narrator that will continue to nourish his great songs.

186-001.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-001.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-001.text: 1When lilacs last in the dooryard bloom’d,And the great star early droop’d in the western sky in the night,I mourn’d, and yet shall mourn with ever-returning spring.
caption: A melancholic scene is depicted with a star in the sky and lilacs in bloom near a doorway. The scene elicits a feeling of mourning that is associated with the coming of spring, which will serve as a reminder of the loss that has been experienced.

The photograph showcases twilight scenery as the lilacs bloom in the dooryard, and a bright, shining star descends in the blue-purple night sky. It imbues a sense of desolation, which is carried on by the cyclic nature of spring.

186-002.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-002.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-002.text: Ever-returning spring, trinity sure to me you bring,Lilac blooming perennial and drooping star in the west,And thought of him I love.
caption: A colorful painting with lilac flowers in full bloom and a bright star setting in the western sky, evoking feelings of returning spring and love.

The image is a soft-focus, impressionistic-style view of a field in bright, sun-drenched springtime. In the foreground, a lilac bush is blooming, while in the background, the sun is setting over the horizon. The atmosphere is calm and serene, capturing the essence of spring, with a hint of nostalgia for a loved one.

186-003.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-003.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-003.text: 2O powerful western fallen star!O shades of night--O moody, tearful night!O great star disappear’d--O the black murk that hides the star!O cruel hands that hold me powerless--O helpless soul of me!O harsh surrounding cloud that will not free my soul.
caption: A lone figure stands in a dark, moody night with their arms tied down by unseen hands. The sky is obscured by clouds, and a bright star has disappeared, leaving a sense of despair and hopelessness.

This image would be in the style of a dark and moody photograph. The picture would show a person struggling to break free of suffocating clouds that engulf them. In the background, a star fades away as tears stream down the person's face.

186-005.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-005.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-005.text: 3In the dooryard fronting an old farm-house near the white-wash’d palings,Stands the lilac-bush tall-growing with heart-shaped leaves of rich green,With many a pointed blossom rising delicate, with the perfume strong I love,With every leaf a miracle--and from this bush in the dooryard,With delicate-color’d blossoms and heart-shaped leaves of rich green,A sprig with its flower I break.
caption: A depiction of a rustic setting with a weathered farm-house in the foreground. A tall lilac-bush stands in front of the house, with heart-shaped leaves of rich green and pointed blossoms of delicate hue. The strong aroma of the lilac fills the air, making it a favorite. A single sprig has been broken off from the bush, with its delicate-colored and heart-shaped flowers retained as a souvenir.

This photograph, in a countryside style, features an old white farm-house with a tall and rich green lilac-bush standing proudly in front of it. The bush is full of perfectly symmetrical, pointed blossoms that emit a strong perfume. In this photograph, a sprig has been plucked from the bush, complete with a delicate and colorful blossom and a heart-shaped leaf.

186-006.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-006.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-006.text: 4In the swamp in secluded recesses,A shy and hidden bird is warbling a song.
caption: A small bird perched on a branch in the middle of a dense swamp. The bird is singing a beautiful and melodious tune.

Photorealistic with a focus on the details of a swampy forest. In the foreground, there is a subtle glimpse of a shy bird perched on a branch. A ray of light shines on the bird creating a focal point to draw the viewer's attention.

186-007.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-007.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-007.text: Solitary the thrush,The hermit withdrawn to himself, avoiding the settlements,Sings by himself a song.
caption: A picture of a thrush perched on a tree branch singing a song in solitude away from any human settlements.
Realistic oil painting. A solitary thrush perched on a tree branch in an open field, singing a song. The background reveals a quiet landscape devoid of human settlements.

186-008.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-008.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-008.text: Song of the bleeding throat,Death’s outlet song of life, (for well dear brother I know,If thou wast not granted to sing thou wouldst surely die.)
caption: An image of a person singing with blood dripping from their throat, symbolizing the raw and intense emotions conveyed by the song. The person appears to be on the verge of death but finds solace in the knowledge that music is the essence of their life.

In the style of abstract expressionism, a painting that depicts a red painted throat with streaks of black representing blood. The throat is surrounded by a chaotic background of various colors representing life and death.

186-009.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-009.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-009.text: 5Over the breast of the spring, the land, amid cities,Amid lanes and through old woods, where lately the violets peep’dfrom the ground, spotting the gray debris,Amid the grass in the fields each side of the lanes, passing theendless grass,Passing the yellow-spear’d wheat, every grain from its shroud in thedark-brown fields uprisen,Passing the apple-tree blows of white and pink in the orchards,Carrying a corpse to where it shall rest in the grave,Night and day journeys a coffin.
caption: A long, winding road that passes through many different landscapes, from vibrant cities to old, mossy forests. The journey passes fields of tall grass and golden wheat, and orchards with blooming apple trees. The journey ends with the solemn procession of a coffin being carried to its final resting place.

Realism. A coffin travels through different terrains, from cities to old woods, with the landscape changing from violets to yellow wheat to apple blossoms. It's carried through lanes and fields before it finally reaches a grave, the journey occurring both day and night.

186-010.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-010.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-010.text: 6Coffin that passes through lanes and streets,Through day and night with the great cloud darkening the land,With the pomp of the inloop’d flags with the cities draped in black,With the show of the States themselves as of crape-veil’d women standing,With processions long and winding and the flambeaus of the night,With the countless torches lit, with the silent sea of faces and theunbared heads,With the waiting depot, the arriving coffin, and the sombre faces,With dirges through the night, with the thousand voices rising strongand solemn,With all the mournful voices of the dirges pour’d around the coffin,The dim-lit churches and the shuddering organs--where amid theseyou journey,With the tolling tolling bells’ perpetual clang,Here, coffin that slowly passes,I give you my sprig of lilac.
caption: A funeral procession moving through the city under a dark cloudy sky. The roads and buildings are draped in black and flags are displayed. Men and women wearing veils line the streets. The procession includes many torches and is accompanied by dirges and tolling bells. Amid this solemn scene, the speaker offers a single sprig of lilac to the passing coffin.

The picture has a dark and somber atmosphere with a long procession of mourners following a coffin draped in flags through the city streets. The city itself swathed in black, mourns the passing of a great person. A solitary figure offers a sprig of lilac among thousands of unbared heads beneath torch-lit darkness, the only light coming from the dim-lit churches and the shuddering organs.

186-011.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-011.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-011.text: 7(Nor for you, for one alone,Blossoms and branches green to coffins all I bring,For fresh as the morning, thus would I chant a song for you O saneand sacred death.
caption: An image of blossoming branches with green leaves that gradually turn into a line of coffins. In the foreground, there is a figure joyfully singing, looking towards a bright morning sky.

In the style of a chiaroscuro portrait- A fresh and green tree branch, beautifully alive, that reaches towards a coffin lying on the ground. The dark shadows of death and light of the living intertwine, portraying a sacred and sane death.

186-012.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-012.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-012.text: All over bouquets of roses,O death, I cover you over with roses and early lilies,But mostly and now the lilac that blooms the first,Copious I break, I break the sprigs from the bushes,With loaded arms I come, pouring for you,For you and the coffins all of you O death.)
caption: A bouquet of various flowers, predominantly lilacs, being placed onto a coffin or grave as a form of tribute to death. The person holding the flowers has gathered so many that their arms are full, and they are overflowing with emotions while performing this gesture.

The photo is dark and moody, with the subject's back facing the camera as they hover over a coffin filled with roses, lilies, and lilacs. Flowers are wrapped around the subject's arms as they pour petals over the casket. The focus is on the vivid, stark beauty of the flowers in contrast to the solemnity of death. The style is reminiscent of chiaroscuro photography.

186-013.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-013.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-013.text: 8O western orb sailing the heaven,Now I know what you must have meant as a month since I walk’d,As I walk’d in silence the transparent shadowy night,As I saw you had something to tell as you bent to me night after night,As you droop’d from the sky low down as if to my side, (while theother stars all look’d on,)As we wander’d together the solemn night, (for something I know notwhat kept me from sleep,)As the night advanced, and I saw on the rim of the west how full youwere of woe,As I stood on the rising ground in the breeze in the cool transparent night,As I watch’d where you pass’d and was lost in the netherward blackof the night,As my soul in its trouble dissatisfied sank, as where you sad orb,Concluded, dropt in the night, and was gone.
caption: A person standing on a hill, gazing up at the western sky at night. The moon hangs low in the sky, and the person feels that it wants to tell them something. They watch together for a while, as the night grows deeper and the stars look on. The moon seems full of sadness as it drops lower and lower towards the horizon. The person remains standing in the cool, transparent night until the moon disappears, feeling troubled and dissatisfied.

The photograph resembles a dark, mysterious night sky with the silhouette of a western orb as its focal point. The appearance of the moon, bent and full of sorrow as it approaches the viewer, is juxtaposed with the other, apathetic stars. The image induces feelings of solitude and contemplation, with a hint of despair.

186-014.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-014.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-014.text: 9Sing on there in the swamp,O singer bashful and tender, I hear your notes, I hear your call,I hear, I come presently, I understand you,But a moment I linger, for the lustrous star has detain’d me,The star my departing comrade holds and detains me.
caption: A serene swamp with a lone singer. A bright star shining in the distance is drawing the singer's attention.

The style is impressionistic. A quiet swamp with tall grass and trees in the background. A figure off in the distance, while a bright star in the sky seems to be holding them in place until they are ready to leave.

186-015.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-015.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-015.text: 10O how shall I warble myself for the dead one there I loved?And how shall I deck my song for the large sweet soul that has gone?And what shall my perfume be for the grave of him I love?
caption: A person is standing in front of a grave, holding a bouquet of flowers, with a look of sadness on their face as they remember the sweet soul that they loved.

Surrealist. A figure with a shattered torso and a mournful expression, surrounded by an enormous wave of smoke-like substance that emanates from its body. The figure's hands are outstretched, and flowers of every color rain down.

186-016.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-016.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-016.text: Sea-winds blown from east and west,Blown from the Eastern sea and blown from the Western sea, tillthere on the prairies meeting,These and with these and the breath of my chant,I’ll perfume the grave of him I love.
caption: A vast prairie landscape with strong winds blowing from both east and west. The wind carries the essence of the ocean and the person's song, as they stand over the grave of their beloved, paying tribute to their memory.

A surrealistic image of winds blowing from the East and West, from the ocean to the prairies, uniting in a vortex. The winds carry the dreamlike essence of Walt Whitman's love and his verse, which infuse and perfume the air around a solitary grave.

186-017.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-017.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-017.text: 11O what shall I hang on the chamber walls?And what shall the pictures be that I hang on the walls,To adorn the burial-house of him I love?Pictures of growing spring and farms and homes,With the Fourth-month eve at sundown, and the gray smoke lucid and bright,With floods of the yellow gold of the gorgeous, indolent, sinkingsun, burning, expanding the air,With the fresh sweet herbage under foot, and the pale green leavesof the trees prolific,In the distance the flowing glaze, the breast of the river, with awind-dapple here and there,With ranging hills on the banks, with many a line against the sky,and shadows,And the city at hand with dwellings so dense, and stacks of chimneys,And all the scenes of life and the workshops, and the workmenhomeward returning.
caption: A collection of paintings depicting scenes of nature, such as fields, farms, and trees in springtime. The paintings also feature the beauty of the evening sky as the sun sets and the decorative smoke that fills the air. Additionally, the pictures showcase the river with hills on the banks and the surrounding bustling city with its various workshops and workers returning home after a long day's work.

Realistic. A large wall piece that depicts a country landscape with farms and homes, the sun is setting and the smoke is wispy and soft. In the foreground, there are tall grasses and pale green leaves on the trees. The background has a winding river and rolling hills with scattered houses in the distance.

186-018.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-018.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-018.text: 12Lo, body and soul--this land,My own Manhattan with spires, and the sparkling and hurrying tides,and the ships,The varied and ample land, the South and the North in the light,Ohio’s shores and flashing Missouri,And ever the far-spreading prairies cover’d with grass and corn.
caption: A panoramic view of Manhattan with tall spires, surrounded by flowing sparkling water and ships on the horizon. In the distance, vast open prairies filled with grass and corn can be seen. The scene incorporates various regions including the South, the North, Missouri, and Ohio.

Landscape photography in the realist style. A panoramic view showcasing New York City's Manhattan skyline with striking spires supplemented by the shimmering currents of its coastal waterways; a collage of urban and rural scenes featuring the flourishing Midwest cornfields and the captivating coastline along the Ohio and Missouri rivers.

186-019.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-019.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-019.text: Lo, the most excellent sun so calm and haughty,The violet and purple morn with just-felt breezes,The gentle soft-born measureless light,The miracle spreading bathing all, the fulfill’d noon,The coming eve delicious, the welcome night and the stars,Over my cities shining all, enveloping man and land.
caption: A series of landscape pictures showing the sun rising with calm and confidence, followed by the gentle morning breeze and beautiful bright light that fills the day. The evening twilight and the stars twinkling in the night sky, shining over cities and symbolizing the enveloping nature of mankind and the land.

This picture is a mix of natural landscape and cityscape. The sun dominates the center of the picture, surrounded by violet and purple hues, with the gentle light penetrating every corner. The picture continues with a city that looks unrecognizable with a human form, bathed in the same light, making everything look like a perfect kaleidoscope of colors. In the distant sky, the stars shine bright, painting the welcoming night.

186-020.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-020.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-020.text: 13Sing on, sing on you gray-brown bird,Sing from the swamps, the recesses, pour your chant from the bushes,Limitless out of the dusk, out of the cedars and pines.
caption: A gray-brown bird stands on a branch, singing a melody at dusk. The backdrop is a swamp with bushes, cedars, and pines.
Nature photography in warm, earthy tones. A brown bird perched on a branch, singing its sweet melody as the sun sets behind it. Trees and bushes surround it, completing the natural aesthetic.

186-021.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-021.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-021.text: Sing on dearest brother, warble your reedy song,Loud human song, with voice of uttermost woe.
caption: A person is singing passionately with their mouth wide open, expressing great sorrow through their voice.
A dark, somber and expressionistic painting of a man with his mouth open wide in song. He is singing with utmost sorrow and pain, his voice evoking a sense of desolation and longing.

186-022.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-022.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-022.text: O liquid and free and tender!O wild and loose to my soul--O wondrous singer!You only I hear--yet the star holds me, (but will soon depart,)Yet the lilac with mastering odor holds me.
caption: A person standing in a serene forest area, with a river flowing nearby. They seem to feel free and are enjoying the wilderness. A star is visible in the sky and the fragrance of the nearby flowers is overwhelming.

In Impressionist style, a lone figure stands in a purple field with a sparkling starry night sky above. The figure reaches towards the sky with one hand, while the other hand holds a fragrant lilac flower, with a look of joy and wonder on their face.

186-023.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-023.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-023.text: 14Now while I sat in the day and look’d forth,In the close of the day with its light and the fields of spring, andthe farmers preparing their crops,In the large unconscious scenery of my land with its lakes and forests,In the heavenly aerial beauty, (after the perturb’d winds and the storms,)Under the arching heavens of the afternoon swift passing, and thevoices of children and women,The many-moving sea-tides, and I saw the ships how they sail’d,And the summer approaching with richness, and the fields all busywith labor,And the infinite separate houses, how they all went on, each withits meals and minutia of daily usages,And the streets how their throbbings throbb’d, and the cities pent--lo, then and there,Falling upon them all and among them all, enveloping me with the rest,Appear’d the cloud, appear’d the long black trail,And I knew death, its thought, and the sacred knowledge of death.
caption: The picture shows a landscape with fields of crops being prepared by farmers under the beautiful sky of a spring afternoon. There are lakes, forests, and the sea nearby. The cities have bustling streets and the houses have their own daily routines. Suddenly, a dark cloud appears and a long black trail looms in the distance. The image conveys a sense of impending death and the sacred knowledge that comes with it.

Postmodern. A composite of different scenes and elements, including a farmer plowing a field, children playing, women working, ships sailing, the busy city streets, and the infinite separate houses. A black cloud looms over everything, symbolizing the inevitability of death.

186-024.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-024.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-024.text: Then with the knowledge of death as walking one side of me,And the thought of death close-walking the other side of me,And I in the middle as with companions, and as holding the hands ofcompanions,I fled forth to the hiding receiving night that talks not,Down to the shores of the water, the path by the swamp in the dimness,To the solemn shadowy cedars and ghostly pines so still.
caption: A person stands in the middle of two shadows, one representing the knowledge of death and the other the thought of death. The person holds hands with the shadows and runs away to a dark, peaceful place filled with trees and water.

The visual style is dark and ethereal. In the center of the image stands a solitary figure, his left side cloaked in darkness, and his right side illuminated by the faint glow of his own mortality. He walks through a misty swamp, flanked by towering cedars and pines that blend into the misty sky.

186-025.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-025.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-025.text: And the singer so shy to the rest receiv’d me,The gray-brown bird I know receiv’d us comrades three,And he sang the carol of death, and a verse for him I love.
caption: Three comrades are being welcomed by a shy singer bird with gray-brown feathers. The bird is singing a sorrowful song about death, while one of the comrades listens with a special affection for the melody.
A large, shy singer with his body turned away from two other figures. A small, gray-brown bird on a branch extending towards the singer. In the background, a sunset and a graveyard.

186-026.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-026.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-026.text: From deep secluded recesses,From the fragrant cedars and the ghostly pines so still,Came the carol of the bird.
caption: In the midst of the peaceful and quiet forest, a bird sings a beautiful and soothing melody. The trees surrounding the bird are fragrant cedars and ghostly pines.
Nature photography in a vibrant forest. Rays of light pierce through the trees casting shadows on the ground, as a bird perches on a branch and chirps a beautiful melody.

186-027.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-027.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-027.text: And the charm of the carol rapt me,As I held as if by their hands my comrades in the night,And the voice of my spirit tallied the song of the bird.
caption: A person standing with their eyes closed, in the middle of the night, surrounded by a group of friends holding hands as they all listen to the beautiful melody of a carol. The person's soul connects with the song just as a bird sings along.

Using a postmodern art style, picture depicts a group of people holding hands under a starry night sky, as one person's spirit joins in with a bird's song, creating a sense of unity between the group and nature.

186-028.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-028.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-028.text: Come lovely and soothing death,Undulate round the world, serenely arriving, arriving,In the day, in the night, to all, to each,Sooner or later delicate death.
caption: A serene image depicting death as a peaceful presence that moves gently and gracefully around the world. The image shows everyone, regardless of age, gender, or social status, being visited by death sooner or later.

The photo has a sombre tone, a long shot of a person's back as they stand at the edge of a cliff overlooking the ocean. The sun is setting, and the light is warm, but there is an overall feeling of peace, as if the person is ready for what is to come.

186-029.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-029.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-029.text: Prais’d be the fathomless universe,For life and joy, and for objects and knowledge curious,And for love, sweet love--but praise! praise! praise!For the sure-enwinding arms of cool-enfolding death.
caption: A universe with arms that seem to embrace everything within it. The arms are cool to the touch, creating a sense of calm and peace. The universe has a joyful and curious energy, but there is also a dark element present in the form of death, which is portrayed as a comforting embrace.

Surrealism. A lush and vibrant forest scene filled with life but also instances of death and decay. Vines and branches embrace and entangle one another, symbolizing the "sure-enwinding arms of cool-enfolding death."

186-030.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-030.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-030.text: Dark mother always gliding near with soft feet,Have none chanted for thee a chant of fullest welcome?Then I chant it for thee, I glorify thee above all,I bring thee a song that when thou must indeed come, come unfalteringly.
caption: A solemn figure with a gentle glide, approaching from the shadows. The figure is overlooked and unnoticed, and the artist wishes to make them feel welcomed with a song. The figure is glorified and the song invites the figure to approach with confidence.

The photograph would be dark and moody. A mother figure in a flowing dress, always present but unseen. The photograph conveys a feeling of both comfort and unease, with a sense of inevitability looming in the background.

186-031.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-031.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-031.text: Approach strong deliveress,When it is so, when thou hast taken them I joyously sing the dead,Lost in the loving floating ocean of thee,Laved in the flood of thy bliss O death.
caption: An image of a woman, strong and powerful, approaching with open arms. She is surrounded by a blissful, floating ocean, where the souls of the dead are joyously singing and lost in her embrace. Death is not feared, but welcomed and embraced as a blissful release.

With a surreal style, a figure in white robe approaches a group of people who are lifted from the ground and emanate a bright aura. As the figure takes the people, they are transformed into white birds and fly away into a peaceful horizon.

186-032.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-032.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-032.text: From me to thee glad serenades,Dances for thee I propose saluting thee, adornments and feastings for thee,And the sights of the open landscape and the high-spread shy are fitting,And life and the fields, and the huge and thoughtful night.
caption: The image consists of a person joyfully offering dances and celebration to another, surrounded by beautiful landscapes and the vast open sky. The scenes depict the richness of life and nature.

Impressionistic. A field with flowers and a blue sky, a figure playing music on a guitar, dancing around them. In the distance, there's a feast set up under a tree, with twinkling lights, surrounded by rolling hills and mountains, over which the night sky is just starting to set in.

186-033.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-033.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-033.text: The night in silence under many a star,The ocean shore and the husky whispering wave whose voice I know,And the soul turning to thee O vast and well-veil’d death,And the body gratefully nestling close to thee.
caption: A serene night with a starry sky above and an empty beach. The waves whisper gently creating a peaceful atmosphere. A person stands on the shore, contemplating death, while their body is at peace and comforted by it.

This is a photograph captured in a low-light setting, showing a vast and glistening ocean. The foamy waves of the water break quietly and whisper gently to the shore. In the foreground, someone is sitting alone on the beach, their body huddled and taking shelter in the cold night, while their eyes gaze into the vast expanse of the ocean, contemplating the mysteries of life and death.

186-034.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-034.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-034.text: Over the tree-tops I float thee a song,Over the rising and sinking waves, over the myriad fields and theprairies wide,Over the dense-pack’d cities all and the teeming wharves and ways,I float this carol with joy, with joy to thee O death.
caption: A bird's-eye view of a vast and diverse landscape with a figure depicted as music notes hovering over it all. The figure appears joyful and is offering a song to an unseen entity.

The visual style could be impressionistic. A person floating above different landscapes, ranging from forests and fields to cities and wharves. They sing a joyful tune while death (personified or represented as an entity) is present, creating a contrast between the cheerful mood of the singer and the somber presence of death.

186-035.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-035.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-035.text: 15To the tally of my soul,Loud and strong kept up the gray-brown bird,With pure deliberate notes spreading filling the night.
caption: A silhouette of a gray-brown bird perched on a branch, singing loudly and filling up the dark night with its pure and deliberate notes. The image captures the soulful essence of the moment.
Photorealistic. A gray-brown bird perched on a branch under a starry night sky, singing loudly and strongly with pure, deliberate notes that fill the air.

186-036.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-036.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-036.text: Loud in the pines and cedars dim,Clear in the freshness moist and the swamp-perfume,And I with my comrades there in the night.
caption: A group of people standing in a dimly lit pine forest. The freshness of the night air and the smell of the swamps surrounding them.
Impressionistic. A dark forest with tall pine and cedar trees. The moon casts a cool light and the air is thick with swampy aromas. Figures of men can be seen in the shadows.

186-037.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-037.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-037.text: While my sight that was bound in my eyes unclosed,As to long panoramas of visions.
caption: An open-eyed face with a background of vast and extensive panoramas of different visions.
With a dreamlike and surreal style, the picture displays a set of eyes starting to open up, revealing vast and surreal landscapes, panoramically stretched out before them.

186-038.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-038.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-038.text: And I saw askant the armies,I saw as in noiseless dreams hundreds of battle-flags,Borne through the smoke of the battles and pierc’d with missiles I saw them,And carried hither and yon through the smoke, and torn and bloody,And at last but a few shreds left on the staffs, (and all in silence,)And the staffs all splinter’d and broken.
caption: A panoramic view of a battlefield, with hundreds of battle flags floating in the air amidst the smoke of the battle. The flags are being fiercely attacked by missiles. The flags are seen being carried in different directions by soldiers, with many of them being torn and bloodied. Gradually, the flags start to disappear, leaving only a few tattered shreds hanging from their broken staffs in complete silence.

In the style of an oil painting, a dark, moody battlefield where hundreds of billowing flags have been shot down and destroyed during war, reduced to a few torn and bloody shreds hanging off broken staffs, all in utter silence.

186-039.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-039.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-039.text: I saw battle-corpses, myriads of them,And the white skeletons of young men, I saw them,I saw the debris and debris of all the slain soldiers of the war,But I saw they were not as was thought,They themselves were fully at rest, they suffer’d not,The living remain’d and suffer’d, the mother suffer’d,And the wife and the child and the musing comrade suffer’d,And the armies that remain’d suffer’d.
caption: A desolate landscape with countless corpses strewn about. In the foreground, a group of grieving loved ones suffering from the loss of those who perished in battle. Despite the carnage, the dead now rest peacefully in contrast to the living who continue to suffer.

Style: Impressionism

A scene of a war field, with piles of corpses and skeletons scattered around, amidst debris and remnants of the war. Amongst the chaos, it becomes clear that the dead soldiers are at peace, while the war continues to haunt the living- soldiers, mothers, wives and children, and comrades, all perpetually suffering.

186-040.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-040.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-040.text: 16Passing the visions, passing the night,Passing, unloosing the hold of my comrades’ hands,Passing the song of the hermit bird and the tallying song of my soul,Victorious song, death’s outlet song, yet varying ever-altering song,As low and wailing, yet clear the notes, rising and falling,flooding the night,Sadly sinking and fainting, as warning and warning, and yet againbursting with joy,Covering the earth and filling the spread of the heaven,As that powerful psalm in the night I heard from recesses,Passing, I leave thee lilac with heart-shaped leaves,I leave thee there in the door-yard, blooming, returning with spring.
caption: A figure is shown walking away from a group of friends into the night. As they walk, they hear the song of a hermit bird and their soul joins in with a victorious song. The notes of their song vary, sometimes low and wailing but other times bursting with joy, filling the earth and sky. As they continue walking into the distance, they leave behind a blooming lilac with heart-shaped leaves, promising to return with spring.

Surrealism. A person's hand unclasping from a group of other hands, the night sky in the background, a bird perched on the extended hand singing. The person and bird walking away from the group towards a bright, blooming lilac bush with heart-shaped leaves.

186-041.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-041.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-041.text: I cease from my song for thee,From my gaze on thee in the west, fronting the west, communing with thee,O comrade lustrous with silver face in the night.
caption: A figure stands in the foreground, looking towards the west where the sun is setting. The figure stops singing and gazes at the silver-faced moon in the night sky.
Surrealism. A figure is turning away from a beautiful sunset in the West to face a silver-masked comrade with a beaming smile, surrounded by the dark night.

186-042.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
186-042.poem: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d
186-042.text: Yet each to keep and all, retrievements out of the night,The song, the wondrous chant of the gray-brown bird,And the tallying chant, the echo arous’d in my soul,With the lustrous and drooping star with the countenance full of woe,With the holders holding my hand nearing the call of the bird,Comrades mine and I in the midst, and their memory ever to keep, forthe dead I loved so well,For the sweetest, wisest soul of all my days and lands--and this forhis dear sake,Lilac and star and bird twined with the chant of my soul,There in the fragrant pines and the cedars dusk and dim.
caption: A forest scene with a gray-brown bird perched on a branch. The sky is filled with stars and a single star with a sad expression catches the viewer's attention. A group of friends hold hands and stand together, their souls entranced by the bird's song. The lilac flowers and the pine trees are also intertwined with the melody. The picture is a memory, a tribute to the people the viewer once loved and lost.

The picture is a beautiful shot of the forest at dusk, with a group of friends gathered around a grave. The focus is on a beautiful lilac in the foreground, intertwined with the song of a beautiful grey-brown bird, the twinkle of a star, and the memories of all the souls they have loved and lost. The visual style is impressionism.

187-001.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
187-001.text: O Captain! my Captain! our fearful trip is done,The ship has weather’d every rack, the prize we sought is won,The port is near, the bells I hear, the people all exulting,While follow eyes the steady keel, the vessel grim and daring;But O heart! heart! heart!O the bleeding drops of red,Where on the deck my Captain lies,Fallen cold and dead.
caption: A group of sailors standing solemnly on the deck of a ship. They have completed their treacherous voyage and have arrived at their destination. The sailors appear to be looking towards the shore where they can hear the ringing of bells and see people celebrating. However, their joy is dampened by the realization that their captain has fallen and is lying lifeless on the deck in a pool of blood.

The visual style is impressionistic depicting a ship approaching a port with cheering crowds on the dockside and the sound of tolling bells. In the foreground, the figure of the captain is shown falling on a deck, surrounded by bleeding drops of red.

187-002.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
187-002.text: O Captain! my Captain! rise up and hear the bells;Rise up--for you the flag is flung--for you the bugle trills,For you bouquets and ribbon’d wreaths--for you the shores a-crowding,For you they call, the swaying mass, their eager faces turning;Here Captain! dear father!This arm beneath your head!It is some dream that on the deck,You’ve fallen cold and dead.
caption: A group of people standing on the shore, looking out to sea with a flag flying at half-mast. The group is holding flowers and decorated wreaths, and a bugle is being played. In the foreground, a person is holding the head of someone who has passed away, possibly a captain. The people are calling out to him, trying to bring him back to life.

Surrealist art style. A figure of a captain laying with a person holding their head, looking into the distance. Bells are in the background and flowers surround the captain. They appear lifeless, like a dream of the person holding them.

187-003.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
187-003.text: My Captain does not answer, his lips are pale and still,My father does not feel my arm, he has no pulse nor will,The ship is anchor’d safe and sound, its voyage closed and done,From fearful trip the victor ship comes in with object won;Exult O shores, and ring O bells!But I with mournful tread,Walk the deck my Captain lies,Fallen cold and dead.
caption: A somber image of a ship returning to port after a challenging journey. The captain is lying on the deck, lifeless, while the narrator mourns his loss. The victory of the ship's safe return is bittersweet with the death of their leader.
Realism. A sailor standing in grief and disbelief on the deck of a ship with the captain's lifeless body in his arms, while others celebrate victory on the shore.

188-001.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
188-001.text: Hush’d be the camps to-day,And soldiers let us drape our war-worn weapons,And each with musing soul retire to celebrate,Our dear commander’s death.
caption: A solemn image of soldiers lowering their weapons, standing in silence. They all bow their heads in mourning, paying tribute to their commander who has passed away.
An atmospheric and moody photograph in black and white. A group of soldiers standing solemnly with their weapons draped, as they pay respect to their fallen leader.

188-002.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
188-002.text: No more for him life’s stormy conflicts,Nor victory, nor defeat--no more time’s dark events,Charging like ceaseless clouds across the sky.But sing poet in our name,
caption: An aged man sitting calmly on a bench with a peaceful expression on his face. A turbulent sky in the background represents the storms of life he has left behind. A young poet stands beside him, ready to continue the legacy of storytelling.

Using the modern minimalist style, the picture depicts a serene view of the ocean, with a person seated facing the water. The person seems to be in deep contemplation, unmoved and unaffected by the raging waves and stormy clouds above them, while a delicate tune escapes the person's lips.

188-003.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
188-003.text: Sing of the love we bore him--because you, dweller in camps, know it truly.
caption: A group of soldiers standing in a circle with their hands placed over their hearts, representing their love and respect for someone they have lost.

The photograph is captured in the street photography genre. It shows a group of soldiers gathered around one of their comrades. They have their arms around each other's shoulders and appear to be singing with joy on their faces. Their camaraderie is palpable.

188-004.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
188-004.text: As they invault the coffin there,Sing--as they close the doors of earth upon him--one verse,For the heavy hearts of soldiers.
caption: A group of soldiers standing around a newly dug grave site. They hold their heads down in mourning as the casket is slowly lowered. One soldier sings a song to comfort the others as they place dirt on the coffin, saying their final goodbyes.

In a brooding, monochromatic style, the camera focuses on a group of soldiers gathered around a grave site. As they mournfully lower the coffin, they begin to sing a verse in unison, their sorrow weighing heavily on their hearts.

189-001.book: BOOK XXII.  MEMORIES OF PRESIDENT LINCOLN
189-001.poem: This Dust Was Once the Man
189-001.text: This dust was once the man,Gentle, plain, just and resolute, under whose cautious hand,Against the foulest crime in history known in any land or age,Was saved the Union of these States.
caption: An image of a humble but determined man made out of dust. This man saved the Union of the States against a terrible crime.

The photograph has a subtle sepia tone and is of a dusty monument set against a clear blue sky. The camera is at ground level looking up at the towering statue of a man with a gentle expression, dressed in plain clothes, emanating a sense of resilience and justice. The monument is dedicated to the Union that has been rescued by him against the worst crime in history.

190-001.text: By blue Ontario’s shore,As I mused of these warlike days and of peace return’d, and thedead that return no more,A Phantom gigantic superb, with stern visage accosted me,Chant me the poem, it said, that comes from the soul of America,chant me the carol of victory,And strike up the marches of Libertad, marches more powerful yet,And sing me before you go the song of the throes of Democracy.
caption: A person is standing on the shore of Lake Ontario lost in thought about war and peace. Suddenly, a tall and imposing phantom figure appears before them. The phantom gestures for the person to summon the soul of America through a poem. They demand a song of victory and call for the powerful marches of freedom to be played. Finally, before the person leaves, the phantom demands to hear the song of democratic struggles.

With an impressionistic style, a person stands at the blue Ontario's shore, looking out at the water while lost in thought about the war and peaceful times. Suddenly, a giant ghost with a solemn expression appears before them, demanding they chant a victorious poem that embodies America's spirit of freedom and democracy before they depart.

190-002.text: (Democracy, the destin’d conqueror, yet treacherous lip-smiles everywhere,And death and infidelity at every step.)
caption: A picture of a victorious democracy, but with hidden deception and dishonesty lurking at every turn, with a looming threat of death and betrayal.

Postmodernist. A blurry image of a nondescript character holding a flag with a black background, while an obscured figure with hands outstretched lurks in the shadows. In the foreground, a variety of unsettling symbols and signs of decay.

190-003.text: 2A Nation announcing itself,I myself make the only growth by which I can be appreciated,I reject none, accept all, then reproduce all in my own forms.
caption: An image of a nation represented by a colorful and diverse garden. A lone figure within the garden, representing the poetic voice, is growing and expanding in appreciation of all, taking in and embracing the variety of forms around them.
Hypnotic art style. A silhouette of a hand in the foreground, with the background filled with shapes and forms of various sizes and colors, all blending together in a beautiful dance.

190-004.text: A breed whose proof is in time and deeds,What we are we are, nativity is answer enough to objections,We wield ourselves as a weapon is wielded,We are powerful and tremendous in ourselves,We are executive in ourselves, we are sufficient in the variety ofourselves,We are the most beautiful to ourselves and in ourselves,We stand self-pois’d in the middle, branching thence over the world,From Missouri, Nebraska, or Kansas, laughing attacks to scorn.
caption: A powerful and self-sufficient group standing confidently in the center and branching out to the world. They are proud of their heritage and achievements and can withstand any attack with laughter and scorn.

The photograph is black and white, highlighting the significant contrasts. The image displays a group of diverse people confidently standing together: smiling, poised, and looking optimistic. The group stands in the midst of an open land branching across the world, emanating positivity and independence.

190-005.text: Nothing is sinful to us outside of ourselves,Whatever appears, whatever does not appear, we are beautiful orsinful in ourselves only.
caption: The picture shows a person standing in front of a mirror, and the reflection of the person in the mirror is split into two halves. One half reflects beauty, and the other half reflects sinfulness. The background of the mirror is a blur, symbolizing the outside world that has no bearing on the individual's fundamental nature.

Abstract art, with a central figure in the midst of a swirling, colorful vortex, representing the self. There are images on the periphery of the painting representing the external world, some beautiful and others more sinister, but all ultimately irrelevant to the central figure.

190-006.text: (O Mother--O Sisters dear!If we are lost, no victor else has destroy’d us,It is by ourselves we go down to eternal night.)
caption: A desolate and dark painting with a lone figure standing in the center, surrounded by shadows. The figure's posture suggests that they have accepted their fate and have taken responsibility for their own downfall. In the background, there are faint silhouettes of their mother and sisters, watching on helplessly.
In a dark, melancholic setting, a woman stands alone, surrounded by shadows as she contemplates her fate. Two other feminine figures are visible in the distance, consoling and embracing each other.

190-007.text: 3Have you thought there could be but a single supreme?There can be any number of supremes--one does not countervailanother any more than one eyesight countervails another, orone life countervails another.
caption: Two people, standing on opposite sides of a scale, each holding their own individual set of eyes and a beating heart. The scale balances perfectly, representing the idea that no one person's perspective or life outweighs or diminishes another's.

The visual style would be surrealism. The picture depicts multiple suns in the sky, all of them shining equally bright. Each sun has a unique color and shape, but they are in harmony with each other instead of competing.

190-008.text: All is eligible to all,All is for individuals, all is for you,No condition is prohibited, not God’s or any.
caption: A picture of a large open beach with plenty of free space. People of all ages and backgrounds enjoying the sand, sun, and water with a sense of freedom and lack of restrictions in the atmosphere.
In minimalist, bold font on a stark background, "ALL is FOR ALL." The image is filled with various symbols of inclusivity and diversity, such as a circle of hands of different skin tones.

190-009.text: All comes by the body, only health puts you rapport with the universe.
caption: A person connected to the universe through good health, demonstrating the importance of the body in achieving this state of balance.

Surrealism. A person is holding a large world in their hands. Their body is made of puzzle pieces, and the shapes of the puzzle pieces are reflected in the world they hold. The pieces of the puzzle fit perfectly together, creating a sense of harmony and rapport with the universe.

190-010.text: Produce great Persons, the rest follows.
caption: A person holding a seed and planting it in soil. From the soil, a large tree grows with many people underneath its branches.

Style: Minimalistic. 

A plain, white background with a person standing in the center. The person looks confident and accomplished.

190-011.text: 4Piety and conformity to them that like,Peace, obesity, allegiance, to them that like,I am he who tauntingly compels men, women, nations,Crying, Leap from your seats and contend for your lives!
