The form has an ironic half-smile, like a ghost from a story, and appears to be made of natural elements from the earth, sun, and stars.

In a photo-realistic style, a towering human made of clouds, stars and earth looms over a fashionable, learned and wealthy crowd gathered in the foreground. The phantom ghost figure in a hunting shirt, wielding a rifle and looking down upon the scene with an ironic smile.

318-001.text: Ah, not this marble, dead and cold:Far from its base and shaft expanding--the round zones circling,comprehending,Thou, Washington, art all the world’s, the continents’ entire--notyours alone, America,Europe’s as well, in every part, castle of lord or laborer’s cot,Or frozen North, or sultry South--the African’s--the Arab’s in his tent,Old Asia’s there with venerable smile, seated amid her ruins;(Greets the antique the hero new? ’tis but the same--the heirlegitimate, continued ever,The indomitable heart and arm--proofs of the never-broken line,Courage, alertness, patience, faith, the same--e’en in defeatdefeated not, the same:)Wherever sails a ship, or house is built on land, or day or night,Through teeming cities’ streets, indoors or out, factories or farms,Now, or to come, or past--where patriot wills existed or exist,Wherever Freedom, pois’d by Toleration, sway’d by Law,Stands or is rising thy true monument.
caption: A photorealistic image of a colossal statue towering high above the ground, representing a heroic figure of Washington. The statue overlooks a vast view of the continents of America and Europe, including dwellings of various cultures and eras - from castles to laborers’ cottages, from frozen North to sultry South, and even amid ancient Asia’s ruins. It’s as if the statue’s commanding presence unites all those cultures and embraces all humanity, past, present, and future. This symbol of unity embodies indomitable traits of courage, alertness, patience, and faith - the characteristics that persist throughout history regardless of victory or defeat. Places of growth and progress, such as bustling cities, factories, farms, or homes, which were built and flourished under the banner of Freedom, Toleration, and Law, all bask under the statue’s nurturing gazes.

Photomontage. In this photomontage, a vast landscape is shown, with iconic structures from around the world blending into each other to form a cohesive image. At the centre, a statue of George Washington stands tall, representing the embodiment of freedom and democracy that unites people from all corners of the world.

319-001.poem: Of That Blithe Throat of Thine
319-001.text: Of that blithe throat of thine from arctic bleak and blank,I’ll mind the lesson, solitary bird--let me too welcome chilling drifts,E’en the profoundest chill, as now--a torpid pulse, a brain unnerv’d,Old age land-lock’d within its winter bay--(cold, cold, O cold!)These snowy hairs, my feeble arm, my frozen feet,For them thy faith, thy rule I take, and grave it to the last;Not summer’s zones alone--not chants of youth, or south’s warm tides alone,But held by sluggish floes, pack’d in the northern ice, the cumulusof years,These with gay heart I also sing.
caption: The picture is painted in a realistic style and depicts a solitary bird joyfully singing against a backdrop of a cold, bleak, snow-covered landscape. In front of the bird is a figure, whose snowy hair and frail body suggest old age. Though this figure is clearly affected by the cold, they too are singing along with the bird, celebrating and embracing the profound chill of winter. The image conveys a sense of resilience and perseverance in the face of life's challenges.

The image is in a minimalistic, abstract art style. It shows a solitary bird singing into the cold, bleak arctic wind. There is an aged person standing in the snow, holding onto their walking cane, welcoming the winter's intense cold with a contented smile on their face.

320-001.text: What hurrying human tides, or day or night!What passions, winnings, losses, ardors, swim thy waters!What whirls of evil, bliss and sorrow, stem thee!What curious questioning glances--glints of love!Leer, envy, scorn, contempt, hope, aspiration!Thou portal--thou arena--thou of the myriad long-drawn lines and groups!(Could but thy flagstones, curbs, facades, tell their inimitable tales;Thy windows rich, and huge hotels--thy side-walks wide;)Thou of the endless sliding, mincing, shuffling feet!Thou, like the parti-colored world itself--like infinite, teeming,mocking life!Thou visor’d, vast, unspeakable show and lesson!
caption: The picture depicted is a photograph with a gritty realism. In the center of the picture there is an image of a bustling city street corner during the night with all kind of people moving quickly among each other. There are faces filled with different emotions such as passion, love, lust, hate, envy, despair, and hope. The background is filled with towering buildings, huge hotels, and opulent windows. The sidewalks are wide with endless sliding, mincing and shuffling feet. It depicts a world filled with infinite, teeming, and mocking life. The picture is a show and lesson of the mesmerizing whirls of evil, bliss, and sorrow that are found in the heart of city life.

Photography style: Street photography.

A bustling city street scene in black and white. Crowds of people, with diverse expressions and emotions. Each face tells a unique story, from love and hope to leer and contempt in the never-ending hustle and bustle of life.

321-001.poem: To Get the Final Lilt of Songs
321-001.text: To get the final lilt of songs,To penetrate the inmost lore of poets--to know the mighty ones,Job, Homer, Eschylus, Dante, Shakespere, Tennyson, Emerson;To diagnose the shifting-delicate tints of love and pride and doubt--to truly understand,To encompass these, the last keen faculty and entrance-price,Old age, and what it brings from all its past experiences.
caption: The visual style for this picture could be impressionistic. The image could show someone reading a book with a serene look on their face, surrounded by floating, colorful musical notes and words from the poets mentioned in the stanza. These words and notes could overlap and blend together, representing the delicate tints of love, pride, and doubt. In the background, an elderly person could be featured, representing old age and its wisdom.

In a impressionistic style, an elderly figure stands over a chaotic array of books and papers, searching for the meaning behind the written word. Vague shapes of famous poets and authors surround the figure in a colorful, swirling blur, with tones of love, pride, and doubt shifting and changing around them.

322-001.text: Far back, related on my mother’s side,Old Salt Kossabone, I’ll tell you how he died:(Had been a sailor all his life--was nearly 90--lived with hismarried grandchild, Jenny;House on a hill, with view of bay at hand, and distant cape, andstretch to open sea;)The last of afternoons, the evening hours, for many a year hisregular custom,In his great arm chair by the window seated,(Sometimes, indeed, through half the day,)Watching the coming, going of the vessels, he mutters to himself--And now the close of all:One struggling outbound brig, one day, baffled for long--cross-tidesand much wrong going,At last at nightfall strikes the breeze aright, her whole luck veering,And swiftly bending round the cape, the darkness proudly entering,cleaving, as he watches,“She’s free--she’s on her destination”--these the last words--whenJenny came, he sat there dead,Dutch Kossabone, Old Salt, related on my mother’s side, far back.
caption: Realism is the style. An old sailor, sitting in his great armchair gazing out the window at the view of the bay, distant cape, and open sea. In a house on a hill with his grandchild Jenny, he waits for the vessels to come and go, sometimes muttering to himself. One day, after watching a struggling outbound brig for a long time, the brig finally catches the right wind and heads toward its destination, and the old sailor utters his final words: "She's free - she's on her destination." The sailor dies as Jenny enters, and the last of the afternoons come to an end.

Photograph taken in the late afternoon showing Old Salt Kossabone, a 90-year-old sailor, seated in his great armchair by the window, with a view of the bay and the open sea. His eyes are fixed on a struggling outbound brig, which had been trying to cross turbulent waters all day, and his last words "She's free - she's on her destination" as he watches the ship finally head towards its destination.

323-001.text: As down the stage again,With Spanish hat and plumes, and gait inimitable,Back from the fading lessons of the past, I’d call, I’d tell and own,How much from thee! the revelation of the singing voice from thee!(So firm--so liquid-soft--again that tremulous, manly timbre!The perfect singing voice--deepest of all to me the lesson--trialand test of all:)How through those strains distill’d--how the rapt ears, the soul ofme, absorbingFernando’s heart, Manrico’s passionate call, Ernani’s, sweet Gennaro’s,I fold thenceforth, or seek to fold, within my chants transmuting,Freedom’s and Love’s and Faith’s unloos’d cantabile,(As perfume’s, color’s, sunlight’s correlation:)From these, for these, with these, a hurried line, dead tenor,A wafted autumn leaf, dropt in the closing grave, the shovel’d earth,To memory of thee.
caption: The style of the picture reflects a blend of Renaissance and Baroque art. The image portrays a performer on stage wearing a Spanish hat with plumes, moving with an impeccable grace that captivates the audience. In the background, a tapestry of images from the performer's past fades in and out of view. The viewer is somehow aware that the figure on stage is our protagonist. Despite the masquerade, we see the performer's true soul in the manifestation of their voice. The voice is like a revelation that is so firm yet so fluid, ringing with a manly timbre that creates a powerful impression on the listener. Its deep and powerful qualities emanate from the very essence of the performer, who feels every note in their soul. The picture shows how the music of famous operas, such as Fernando, Manrico, Ernani, and Gennaro's, transcends time and space, reaching out to touch others. The music carries with it the message of the three tenants: Freedom, Love, and Faith, which transform through the singer's voice. In the end, the frailty of his mortality juxtaposes the performer's enduring legacy.

The photograph is a close-up of a Spanish-dressed person with a hat and feathers, on a stage. Their expressions and postures convey inimitable grace and confidence. The backdrop is a fading memory of past lessons, and the person wants to call, tell and own how much they have learned from someone whose revelation of the singing voice touched their deepest soul. The person’s singing voice is firm, liquid soft, and a test of all. The photograph conveys how the person seeks to fold freedom, love, and faith’s unloosed melodies within their chants, and their voice resonates with the strains of the heart, the soul, and the embodiment of autumn, life, and death.

324-001.text: Nothing is ever really lost, or can be lost,No birth, identity, form--no object of the world.Nor life, nor force, nor any visible thing;Appearance must not foil, nor shifted sphere confuse thy brain.Ample are time and space--ample the fields of Nature.The body, sluggish, aged, cold--the embers left from earlier fires,The light in the eye grown dim, shall duly flame again;The sun now low in the west rises for mornings and for noons continual;To frozen clods ever the spring’s invisible law returns,With grass and flowers and summer fruits and corn.
caption: The painting has a surreal art style. It depicts the vastness of time and space. There is a figurative representation of the cycle of life and death. The image shows the natural elements like grass, flowers, and the sun- a symbol of continuity. The painting shows the embers left from earlier fires, which signifies an unsigned life force that transitions from one life to another. Speaking to the viewer symbolically, the painting reminds the viewer to remember that while objects may appear lost, they are not truly gone.
A photograph taken in hyperrealistic style of a withered leaf in winter next to a fresh, green leaf in the early days of spring. It signifies that nothing is lost because growth is an eternal cycle.

325-001.text: A song, a poem of itself--the word itself a dirge,Amid the wilds, the rocks, the storm and wintry night,To me such misty, strange tableaux the syllables calling up;Yonnondio--I see, far in the west or north, a limitless ravine, withplains and mountains dark,I see swarms of stalwart chieftains, medicine-men, and warriors,As flitting by like clouds of ghosts, they pass and are gone in thetwilight,(Race of the woods, the landscapes free, and the falls!No picture, poem, statement, passing them to the future:)Yonnondio! Yonnondio!--unlimn’d they disappear;To-day gives place, and fades--the cities, farms, factories fade;A muffled sonorous sound, a wailing word is borne through the airfor a moment,Then blank and gone and still, and utterly lost.
caption: The visual style of the image is that of a surrealistic painting. In the center of the image is a word "Yonnondio" hovering above a ravine, with mountains and plains on either side. On the sides of the ravine, there are swarms of Native American chieftains, medicine-men, and warriors passing by like clouds of ghosts. The landscape behind them shows the races of the woods, the falls, and other landscapes that are free. In the foreground, there's a muffled sonorous sound, a wailing word that disappears, with cities, farms, and factories fading out.

A black-and-white, surreal photograph of a rugged landscape in the midst of a stormy night. The ghostly images of Native American warriors and medicine-men appear and disappear like fleeting apparitions. The photo represents the fading memory of indigenous peoples in our cities, farms, and factories.

326-001.text: Ever the undiscouraged, resolute, struggling soul of man;(Have former armies fail’d? then we send fresh armies--and fresh again;)Ever the grappled mystery of all earth’s ages old or new;Ever the eager eyes, hurrahs, the welcome-clapping hands, the loudapplause;Ever the soul dissatisfied, curious, unconvinced at last;Struggling to-day the same--battling the same.
caption: This picture has an intense visual style, like that of a political propaganda poster. It displays a figure of a person with an unrelenting, determined aura. His fist is raised in a symbol of unwavering strength and power. There is a vast and seemingly endless backdrop representing the mystery of all earth's ages, old and new. His eyes are fixed forward while a crowd eagerly follows him. The crowds are cheering with hands clapping in applause, and their faces express satisfaction but the main figure looks unsatisfied and unconvinced. It is a powerful representation of a man struggling through the ages, still battling with the same determination and resoluteness.

In a dramatic monochromatic style, an energetic human figure stands heroically with their fist up in the air, surrounded by silhouettes of ancient and modern soldiers with banners, all symbolizing the timeless, unrelenting struggle and curiosity of the human soul throughout history.

327-001.text: My science-friend, my noblest woman-friend,(Now buried in an English grave--and this a memory-leaf for her dear sake,)Ended our talk--“The sum, concluding all we know of old or modernlearning, intuitions deep,“Of all Geologies--Histories--of all Astronomy--of Evolution,Metaphysics all,“Is, that we all are onward, onward, speeding slowly, surely bettering,“Life, life an endless march, an endless army, (no halt, but it isduly over,)“The world, the race, the soul--in space and time the universes,“All bound as is befitting each--all surely going somewhere.”
caption: The visual style is impressionism. The picture shows a grave with flowers on top of it, a sun setting behind trees framed in the background, and a winding path in the distance. The fading sun casts a golden-orange haze over the land.

Realistic art style. A woman is shown buried in an English grave. The image portrays all aspects of human knowledge: geology, history, astronomy, metaphysics, and evolution. It depicts life as an endless march, and the universe is bound to a place, time, and purpose.

328-001.poem: Small the Theme of My Chant
328-001.text: Small the theme of my Chant, yet the greatest--namely, One’s-Self--a simple, separate person. That, for the use of the New World, I sing.Man’s physiology complete, from top to toe, I sing. Not physiognomy alone,nor brain alone, is worthy for the Muse;--I say the Form completeis worthier far. The Female equally with the Male, I sing.Nor cease at the theme of One’s-Self. I speak the word of themodern, the word En-Masse.My Days I sing, and the Lands--with interstice I knew of hapless War.(O friend, whoe’er you are, at last arriving hither to commence, Ifeel through every leaf the pressure of your hand, which I return.And thus upon our journey, footing the road, and more than once, andlink’d together let us go.)
caption: The style is Impressionism. An expansive landscape with branches of trees at the top, flowing down to an image of a small, separate person in a field. The person is the focus, and there are multiple images of them in different positions, depicting the physiology of Man from top to toe. The images of the Females are interspersed with those of the Males. In the background, there is an image of a war, with a narrow path separating the two scenes. Two figures are holding hands, walking on this path together.

The image depicts a human body, both male and female, from head to toe. The image shows the human form as complete and worthy of artistic expression. In the midst of the image, there are spaces that suggest the human experience, including war. Two people, walking together, are present at the edge of the image.

329-001.text: Old farmers, travelers, workmen (no matter how crippled or bent,)Old sailors, out of many a perilous voyage, storm and wreck,Old soldiers from campaigns, with all their wounds, defeats and scars;Enough that they’ve survived at all--long life’s unflinching ones!Forth from their struggles, trials, fights, to have emerged at all--in that alone,True conquerors o’er all the rest.
caption: The picture is drawn in a realistic style. A group of elderly people - farmers, travelers, workmen, sailors, and soldiers - are standing together. They all appear worn down and weathered from years of hard work, fighting wars, and surviving storms at sea. Yet, their expressions are determined and strong, as if they've overcome everything that's come their way. The overall message seems to be one of resilience and triumph in the face of struggle.

Realism style. A portrait that captures the faces of old farmers, travelers, workmen, old sailors and soldiers who have survived many perilous voyages, storms, campaigns, and fights. Despite many defeats and scars, they have emerged as true conquerors in the battle of life.

330-001.poem: The United States to Old World Critics
330-001.text: Here first the duties of to-day, the lessons of the concrete,Wealth, order, travel, shelter, products, plenty;As of the building of some varied, vast, perpetual edifice,Whence to arise inevitable in time, the towering roofs, the lamps,The solid-planted spires tall shooting to the stars.
caption: The visual style is modern and abstract. The image shows a busy, dynamic cityscape with towering skyscrapers made of steel and glass. People are hurrying about, each engaged in different activities, such as shopping, boarding planes, and working. In the center of the city is a massive, never-ending construction project, with cranes and scaffolding reaching to the skies. The image conveys the idea of progress, growth, and the building of a powerful, prosperous society.

Photorealistic. A vibrant cityscape with towering skyscrapers, billboards, busy streets, and flashing lights. The image depicts the everyday hustle and bustle of a modern urban landscape, where endless buildings and products symbolize a massive, perpetual edifice that stands the test of time.

331-001.text: That coursing on, whate’er men’s speculations,Amid the changing schools, theologies, philosophies,Amid the bawling presentations new and old,The round earth’s silent vital laws, facts, modes continue.
caption: The picture shows a top-down view of a massive, round earth, rotating slowly. It is surrounded by countless schools of thought and philosophies, represented by different colored clouds and ribbons. Despite the chaos, the earth and its natural laws remain undisturbed and serene. The style of the picture is a surreal blend of abstract and realistic elements.

Surrealism. A detailed depiction of a man's head with different schools, philosophies and theories being presented on one side, and the silent and vital natural laws existing on the other. The changing and bawling presentations are depicted as loud and distorted.

332-001.text: Thanks in old age--thanks ere I go,For health, the midday sun, the impalpable air--for life, mere life,For precious ever-lingering memories, (of you my mother dear--you,father--you, brothers, sisters, friends,)For all my days--not those of peace alone--the days of war the same,For gentle words, caresses, gifts from foreign lands,For shelter, wine and meat--for sweet appreciation,(You distant, dim unknown--or young or old--countless, unspecified,readers belov’d,We never met, and neer shall meet--and yet our souls embrace, long,close and long;)For beings, groups, love, deeds, words, books--for colors, forms,For all the brave strong men--devoted, hardy men--who’ve forwardsprung in freedom’s help, all years, all landsFor braver, stronger, more devoted men--(a special laurel ere I go,to life’s war’s chosen ones,The cannoneers of song and thought--the great artillerists--theforemost leaders, captains of the soul:)As soldier from an ended war return’d--As traveler out of myriads,to the long procession retrospective,Thanks--joyful thanks!--a soldier’s, traveler’s thanks.
caption: The artwork is done in a Renaissance style. The painting features an elderly man sitting in a chair outside his home. The bright midday sun warms his face and the breeze gently moves his white hair. His face shows contentment and gratitude as he gazes out, taking in the beauty around him. The memories of his loved ones come flooding back; his mother, father, brothers, sisters, and friends. The painting depicts the various components that made his life complete, including books, art, music, colors, and forms. In the background, a procession of brave soldiers, travelers, and artists of every age and nationality stride forward. Though they may never meet in person, their souls embrace in unity.

The photograph is a montage of memories of a person's life, showing various moments of joy and gratitude. The style is a modern, abstract dreamlike montage, with overlapping and blurry images of family, friends, landscapes, foreign lands, books, and artworks, all coming together to create a collage of a life well-lived.

333-001.text: The two old, simple problems ever intertwined,Close home, elusive, present, baffled, grappled.By each successive age insoluble, pass’d on,To ours to-day--and we pass on the same.
caption: The visual style is impressionist. It features two intertwining, complex knots with a house shaped in the center. They are surrounded by ephemeral figures grappling with each other. The knots are passed down through generations, baffling and challenging each one.

Surreal. Two hands entwined with numerous knots, trying to solve each other, yet they are constantly in a struggle without resolution. It is a metaphorical representation of continuous, impossible struggles that are passed on from generation to generation.

334-001.text: And who art thou? said I to the soft-falling shower,Which, strange to tell, gave me an answer, as here translated:I am the Poem of Earth, said the voice of the rain,Eternal I rise impalpable out of the land and the bottomless sea,Upward to heaven, whence, vaguely form’d, altogether changed, andyet the same,I descend to lave the drouths, atomies, dust-layers of the globe,And all that in them without me were seeds only, latent, unborn;And forever, by day and night, I give back life to my own origin,and make pure and beautify it;(For song, issuing from its birth-place, after fulfilment, wandering,Reck’d or unreck’d, duly with love returns.)
caption: The visual style is impressionistic. A misty and dreamy forest with a light rain falling. A faint and distant voice can be heard over the sound of the rain. The voice says, "I am the Poem of Earth". Bright colors highlight beauty and purity of nature as flowers bloom and life springs forth.

The image is a rain shower falling on the earth, giving life and nourishment to the planet. The rain describes itself as the Poem of Earth, rising up from the land and sea, and then falling back to the earth to make it pure and beautiful. The picture is in a romantic style, with soft and dreamlike colors.

335-001.poem: Soon Shall the Winter’s Foil Be Here
335-001.text: Soon shall the winter’s foil be here;Soon shall these icy ligatures unbind and melt--A little while,And air, soil, wave, suffused shall be in softness, bloom andgrowth--a thousand forms shall riseFrom these dead clods and chills as from low burial graves.
caption: The visual style is impressionistic. A barren and cold winter scene with snow and ice covering the ground and trees. Suddenly, the ice begins to unbind and melt, revealing the soft earth beneath. Life emerges as plants and flowers bloom, transforming the landscape into an explosion of colors and shapes. The rebirth of spring is captured in a fleeting moment.
A macro shot of an icy winter landscape. Slowly, everything is melting. As it thaws, new plant life forms intricately sprout and slowly prosper.

335-002.poem: Soon Shall the Winter’s Foil Be Here
335-002.text: Thine eyes, ears--all thy best attributes--all that takes cognizanceof natural beauty,Shall wake and fill. Thou shalt perceive the simple shows, thedelicate miracles of earth,Dandelions, clover, the emerald grass, the early scents and flowers,The arbutus under foot, the willow’s yellow-green, the blossomingplum and cherry;With these the robin, lark and thrush, singing their songs--theflitting bluebird;For such the scenes the annual play brings on.
caption: Impressionistic. The painting showcases an array of colors from various landscapes, including bright fields of green clover and dandelions, dotted with the delicate hues of plum and cherry blossoms in the foreground. The sound of songbirds, like the robin, lark, and thrush, echo throughout the painting, while a cheerful bluebird flits in the background. The scene is dominated by the beautiful natural beauty and serene surroundings, which seem to awaken all the senses of the beholder.

The picture is in the style of impressionism. It shows a field full of vibrant colored flowers, with trees and bushes teeming with life. Birds, including a robin, lark, thrush, and bluebird, are singing and flying around the flowers. The sun is shining brightly, and you can almost feel the fresh scent of spring in the air.

336-001.text: While not the past forgetting,To-day, at least, contention sunk entire--peace, brotherhood uprisen;For sign reciprocal our Northern, Southern hands,Lay on the graves of all dead soldiers, North or South,(Nor for the past alone--for meanings to the future,)Wreaths of roses and branches of palm.
caption: The visual style is a realist portrait. Two open hands, one from the North and one from the South, laying wreaths of roses and palm branches on a grave. There is a serene, peaceful atmosphere with hints of the past but a focus on brotherhood and unity.

Realism style; A photograph with a blurred background of two hands joined together palm to palm. The hands are are laid on the graves of all dead soldiers in the graveyard, the hands adorned with wreaths of roses and branches of palms.

337-001.text: Amid these days of order, ease, prosperity,Amid the current songs of beauty, peace, decorum,I cast a reminiscence--(likely ’twill offend you,I heard it in my boyhood;)--More than a generation since,A queer old savage man, a fighter under Washington himself,(Large, brave, cleanly, hot-blooded, no talker, rather spiritualistic,Had fought in the ranks--fought well--had been all through theRevolutionary war,)Lay dying--sons, daughters, church-deacons, lovingly tending him,Sharping their sense, their ears, towards his murmuring, half-caught words:“Let me return again to my war-days,To the sights and scenes--to forming the line of battle,To the scouts ahead reconnoitering,To the cannons, the grim artillery,To the galloping aides, carrying orders,To the wounded, the fallen, the heat, the suspense,The perfume strong, the smoke, the deafening noise;Away with your life of peace!--your joys of peace!Give me my old wild battle-life again!”
caption: Realistic, with a historical war painting aesthetic. An old, wounded Revolutionary War fighter lies on his bed and his distraught family and church group stands by his side. The fighter is in a deep reminiscent state, yearning for the intense battle he once lived for. In his mind, he's transported back to the brutal battlefields with sights of the line of battle and reconnoitering scouts, and sounds of cannons, artillery, and galloping aides carrying out orders. His face is blissful, away from today's peace-loving society.

Realistic portrait. An aging veteran lies nestled in the comfort of his bed, surrounded by his sons, daughters, and kind church-deacons, tending to his physical needs in his last moments. In his final murmurs, he recounts his days as a warrior under George Washington, vividly describing the sights and sounds of war in great detail as his family listens intently.

338-001.text: Have you learn’d lessons only of those who admired you, and weretender with you, and stood aside for you?Have you not learn’d great lessons from those who reject you, andbrace themselves against you? or who treat you with contempt,or dispute the passage with you?
caption: A gritty and edgy picture portraying a figure standing tall amidst a blurred and hostile crowd. The figure looks determined and self-assured while the faces around them are contorted with anger and contempt. The picture contrasts light and dark colors to highlight the resilience of the central figure even in the face of rejection and adversity.

In gritty street art style; a lone figure, facing a line of people who are standing with their arms crossed and showing no interest, while other figures stand in the background with concerned expressions.

339-001.text: Shot gold, maroon and violet, dazzling silver, emerald, fawn,The earth’s whole amplitude and Nature’s multiform power consign’dfor once to colors;The light, the general air possess’d by them--colors till now unknown,No limit, confine--not the Western sky alone--the high meridian--North, South, all,Pure luminous color fighting the silent shadows to the last.
caption: The picture is abstract, painted in the style of the expressionist movement. It's heavily layered in gold, maroon and violet, with dazzling silver, emerald, and fawn accenting nature's power. It alludes to the world's vast color spectrum, with colors that have not yet been discovered. The colors are portrayed fighting with the shadows to the last ray of light.

Using abstract expressionism, a painting full of contrasting shades of gold, maroon, violet, silver, emerald, and fawn, invoking the immensity of the earth and power of nature. The vivid colors of the painting battle against the silent shadows, with no limit or boundary, covering every direction of the viewer's perspective.

340-001.text: Down on the ancient wharf, the sand, I sit, with a new-comer chatting:He shipp’d as green-hand boy, and sail’d away, (took some sudden,vehement notion;)Since, twenty years and more have circled round and round,While he the globe was circling round and round, --and now returns:How changed the place--all the old land-marks gone--the parents dead;(Yes, he comes back to lay in port for good--to settle--has awell-fill’d purse--no spot will do but this;)The little boat that scull’d him from the sloop, now held in leash I see,I hear the slapping waves, the restless keel, the rocking in the sand,I see the sailor kit, the canvas bag, the great box bound with brass,I scan the face all berry-brown and bearded--the stout-strong frame,Dress’d in its russet suit of good Scotch cloth:(Then what the told-out story of those twenty years? What of the future?)
caption: The visual style is impressionism. Two figures sit on an old wharf with a dilapidated boat tied to it. One of them is a bearded, burly man dressed in a rust-colored suit made of good Scottish cloth. He has a rugged sailor's kit and a large brass-bound box. In the background, we see the restless sea with waves crashing against the shore. The scene portrays the reunion of the sailor with his homeland after having been away for over 20 years. The changes in the landscape and the absence of his parents are noticeable. The painting leaves the question of the sailor's story and future hanging in the air.

The image is of an old wharf, with sand and water. Two men are seated on the sand, one a returner, the other a resident. The returner has the visage of a seasoned sailor: weather-beaten, bearded with a strong, stout build. The evidence of his journey is visible in his sailor kit, canvas bag and brass-bound box.

341-001.poem: Orange Buds by Mail from Florida
341-001.text: A lesser proof than old Voltaire’s, yet greater,Proof of this present time, and thee, thy broad expanse, America,To my plain Northern hut, in outside clouds and snow,Brought safely for a thousand miles o’er land and tide,Some three days since on their own soil live-sprouting,Now here their sweetness through my room unfolding,A bunch of orange buds by mall from Florida.
caption: In a bold and vibrant pop art style, an image depicts a cozy winter cabin surrounded by snow-capped trees. In the foreground, a bundle of small, bright orange buds hover in mid-air, filling the space with energetic radiance. The buds offer proof of the fertile and diverse land of America, having travelled thousands of miles to make their way to the cabin in the far north.
Photorealistic. An image of a plain Northern hut with a small bunch of sweet-smelling orange buds sitting in a vase near a window covered with snow and outside clouds.

342-001.text: The soft voluptuous opiate shades,The sun just gone, the eager light dispell’d--(I too will soon begone, dispell’d,)A haze--nirwana--rest and night--oblivion.
caption: With an impressionist style, the painting depicts a sunset on a lake surrounded by trees. The sun has just left the sky, leaving behind warm orange and pink tones. The colors in the sky and the water begin to blend together, creating a soft haze. The painting portrays a sense of peacefulness, evoking a feeling of Nirvana, in which the viewer feels at rest and at peace.

Surrealist. The painting shows a landscape with a gradient of soft shades from violet to pink. The sun has set, and the light is fading. The scene is peaceful, and a thick haze is hanging over the area.

343-001.poem: You Lingering Sparse Leaves of Me
343-001.text: You lingering sparse leaves of me on winter-nearing boughs,And I some well-shorn tree of field or orchard-row;You tokens diminute and lorn--(not now the flush of May, or Julyclover-bloom--no grain of August now;)You pallid banner-staves--you pennants valueless--you overstay’d of time,Yet my soul-dearest leaves confirming all the rest,The faithfulest--hardiest--last.
caption: The style is impressionistic. In the center of the image, a winter tree stands bare and sturdy. In the foreground are leaves, sparse and few, clinging to the branches. They are no longer the vibrant fullness of spring or summer, but they remain, representing endurance and resilience. The leaves on this tree are the last of the season and though they are tired and worn, they remain faithful and true to the tree. The image captures the essence of perseverance and devotion, even in the midst of hardship.

Photorealistic still life photograph of a tree branch, with few leaves remaining in late autumn. The lack of leaves feeling stark and dejected, but the remaining ones are steadfast and true, representing the enduring spirit.

344-001.text: Not meagre, latent boughs alone, O songs! (scaly and bare, likeeagles’ talons,)But haply for some sunny day (who knows?) some future spring, somesummer--bursting forth,To verdant leaves, or sheltering shade--to nourishing fruit,Apples and grapes--the stalwart limbs of trees emerging--the fresh,free, open air,And love and faith, like scented roses blooming.
caption: The visual style for this picture could be impressionist. The image shows leafless, scaly tree branches without a single leaf.  But, there is a hint of a change of season to come with flowers and new leaves in the summer. Sandy and green brushstrokes in the background represent a flowing, fresh, and open air. In the foreground, apples and grapes, as well as blossoming scented roses, add a pop of color and brightness. The image showcases a sense of hope for change and growth, despite the current state of barrenness.

This photo depicts a barren tree with scaly branches, symbolic of eagle talons, but with potential for growth and budding fruit in the future. Equally symbolized is the growth of love and faith like blooming scented roses. The visual style is impressionistic.

345-001.text: To-day, with bending head and eyes, thou, too, Columbia,Less for the mighty crown laid low in sorrow--less for the Emperor,Thy true condolence breathest, sendest out o’er many a salt sea mile,Mourning a good old man--a faithful shepherd, patriot.
caption:
Visual Style: Impressionistic. 
A figure, symbolizing the nation of Columbia, is portrayed with bowed head and eyes downcast. The background is a stormy ocean with a silhouette of a ship on the horizon. In the forefront of the painting, waves are crashing on a rocky shore. The atmosphere is of solitude and mournfulness, evoking the memory of a beloved patriot, with the figure of Columbia expressing a sense of condolences with a pensive expression.

Realistic painting. A figure of Columbia  looking down with eyes full of sorrow, weeping for an old man who is a patriot and a shepherd with his folded flock on a hill in the background. The high sea and clouds evoke distance and the feeling of loss.

346-001.text: As the Greek’s signal flame, by antique records told,Rose from the hill-top, like applause and glory,Welcoming in fame some special veteran, hero,With rosy tinge reddening the land he’d served,So I aloft from Mannahatta’s ship-fringed shore,Lift high a kindled brand for thee, Old Poet.
caption: Realistic oil painting of a hero standing atop a hill, holding a flaming torch high in the air. The countryside surrounding him is bathed in a rosy hue. In the distance, a ship is seen off the coast of Mannahatta.

In the style of Impressionism. A ship-bathed shore with a proud figure holding a torch, in the distance a hill with burning embers that illuminate the land, a reminiscent of a glorious hero's welcome of ancient Greece.

347-001.text: In some unused lagoon, some nameless bay,On sluggish, lonesome waters, anchor’d near the shore,An old, dismasted, gray and batter’d ship, disabled, done,After free voyages to all the seas of earth, haul’d up at last andhawser’d tight,Lies rusting, mouldering.
caption: The picture has a somber and melancholic mood, captured in the style of photorealism. The image depicts an old, battered ship anchored in a lagoon surrounded by still waters. The ship appears to have a dismasted and worn-out exterior, attested by the rust and mold growing on its hull. The ship has seen better days and has likely voyaged through stormy seas before being left here to decay. It feels abandoned and alone in some forgotten corner of the world.

A melancholic picture with a vintage touch. An old and rusty ship anchored in a still and silent bay with no signs of life around her. The ship seems abandoned and forgotten, a once mighty vessel now reduced to a mere ghost of her former self.

348-001.text: Now precedent songs, farewell--by every name farewell,(Trains of a staggering line in many a strange procession, waggons,From ups and downs--with intervals--from elder years, mid-age, or youth,)“In Cabin’d Ships, or Thee Old Cause or Poets to ComeOr Paumanok, Song of Myself, Calamus, or Adam,Or Beat! Beat! Drums! or To the Leaven’d Soil they Trod,Or Captain! My Captain! Kosmos, Quicksand Years, or Thoughts,Thou Mother with thy Equal Brood,” and many, many more unspecified,From fibre heart of mine--from throat and tongue--(My life’s hotpulsing blood,The personal urge and form for me--not merely paper, automatic typeand ink,)Each song of mine--each utterance in the past--having its long, longhistory,Of life or death, or soldier’s wound, of country’s loss or safety,(O heaven! what flash and started endless train of all! comparedindeed to that!What wretched shred e’en at the best of all!)
caption: The visual style is abstract, with a mix of colors, shapes and lines that blend together in no particular order. The imagery includes floating fragments and pieces of trains, carts and wagons on a backdrop that alternates between bright and dark colors. The picture represents the farewell of several songs each with a unique history, either personal or of the country, some optimistic or patriotic, and others filled with grief and pain. The artist has interwoven their own personal experiences and emotions into each song to make them more than just ink and paper.

The image is a collage of a chaotic procession including wagons, people from different ages, races, and backgrounds. They are in motion and the image is blurry, representing the many past songs the artist has written, including "In Cabin'd Ships", "Paumanok", and "Captain! My Captain!" among others. The image represents the artist's personal history and inspiration for each song.

349-001.text: After a week of physical anguish,Unrest and pain, and feverish heat,Toward the ending day a calm and lull comes on,Three hours of peace and soothing rest of brain.
caption: The visual style for this picture could be impressionistic. It is a painting of a human figure curled up in bed; their posture conveys physical discomfort. There is a visible shift in tone in the painting, as the cool blue and green hues dominate the forefront and gradually merge with warm orange and pink hues in the background. This creates an impression of relief and calm as if the character has finally found solace after a week of physical anguish.
Realistic surrealism. A chaos in the foreground with a person in distress, walking towards a sunset, and a lull falling behind them: a peaceful and calm landscape with clouds and cool colors.

350-001.text: The touch of flame--the illuminating fire--the loftiest look at last,O’er city, passion, sea--o’er prairie, mountain, wood--the earth itself,The airy, different, changing hues of all, in failing twilight,Objects and groups, bearings, faces, reminiscences;The calmer sight--the golden setting, clear and broad:So much i’ the atmosphere, the points of view, the situations whencewe scan,Bro’t out by them alone--so much (perhaps the best) unreck’d before;The lights indeed from them--old age’s lambent peaks.
caption: A surrealistic painting with vibrant colors that depict the grandeur of life. The painting features changing hues of the atmosphere during a beautiful sunset. There are various objects, groups, faces, and memories captured within the painting. The grand view overlooks a city, passion, sea, prairie, mountain, and wood. The golden clear setting of the sun is in full view. The painting reflects the culmination of life and the older generation passing on their wisdom to the younger generation.

A photograph of a sunset, depicting various landscapes from different points of view, including a city skyline, the ocean, prairies, mountains, and forests. The photograph captures vivid hues, objects, groups of people, and their faces, as well as the reminiscences they evoke, with the added depth and beauty of old age's haunting peaks.

351-001.text: After the supper and talk--after the day is done,As a friend from friends his final withdrawal prolonging,Good-bye and Good-bye with emotional lips repeating,(So hard for his hand to release those hands--no more will they meet,No more for communion of sorrow and joy, of old and young,A far-stretching journey awaits him, to return no more,)Shunning, postponing severance--seeking to ward off the last wordever so little,E’en at the exit-door turning--charges superfluous calling back--e’en as he descends the steps,Something to eke out a minute additional--shadows of nightfall deepening,Farewells, messages lessening--dimmer the forthgoer’s visage and form,Soon to be lost for aye in the darkness--loth, O so loth to depart!Garrulous to the very last.
caption: The visual style is impressionism. A group of people standing outside a house in the evening. One person is saying goodbye and hugging their friends, but they linger as they struggle to leave. The sun is setting and the shadows are getting longer as the person tries to extend their departure. As they start to walk away, their friends get smaller and harder to see in the gathering darkness. The person continues to talk and look back as they leave, not wanting to say goodbye.

A photograph in a candid style. An image of a group of friends saying goodbye after dinner, the emotions on their lips are visible with hugs.They try to prolong the inevitable departure, repeatedly saying goodbye, with one still standing at the exit door, reluctant to leave. Their faces grow dimmer, messages and farewells lessen as their friend disappears into the darkness.

352-001.poem: Sail out for Good, Eidolon Yacht!
352-001.text: Heave the anchor short!Raise main-sail and jib--steer forth,O little white-hull’d sloop, now speed on really deep waters,(I will not call it our concluding voyage,But outset and sure entrance to the truest, best, maturest;)Depart, depart from solid earth--no more returning to these shores,Now on for aye our infinite free venture wending,Spurning all yet tried ports, seas, hawsers, densities, gravitation,Sail out for good, eidolon yacht of me!
caption: The picture is done in a dramatic and adventurous style. The image is a white-hulled sloop with full sails, out in the open sea, leaving the shore behind for a forever journey. The vessel is unfazed by the challenges that stand before them, including rough currents and gravitation. It is a symbol of freedom and exploration, and the journey is just an epic beginning.
In an impressionistic style, a white sailboat is leaving the dock slowly. The rippling waves around it show that the boat may not return, but is off to an infinite journey.

353-001.text: And whence and why come you?
caption: Minimalistic. A wide open space with a person standing in the center, looking upward with arms extended, questioning a hovering object in the sky. The object is subtly depicted with a light glow emanating from it.
Surrealist. The picture is a silhouette of a person standing on a stairway leading to nowhere, with a dark, cloudy sky as the backdrop.

353-002.text: We know not whence, (was the answer,)We only know that we drift here with the rest,That we linger’d and lagg’d--but were wafted at last, and are now here,To make the passing shower’s concluding drops.
caption: With the artistic style of impressionism, a group of small boats in a vast ocean with a grey cloudy sky is depicted. The boats move aimlessly, but not without direction. Their final destination unknown, they continue to meander in the water. The boats appear like special vehicles from another world, exploring the vast waters with curiosity.

Surrealist. An image of people drifting through a misty, dreamlike landscape. They move slowly, unsure of their direction but finally arrive in a place where they are finally able to rest. The scene is punctuated by a soft rain, the last drops of a passing storm.

354-001.text: Good-bye my fancy--(I had a word to say,But ’tis not quite the time--The best of any man’s word or say,Is when its proper place arrives--and for its meaning,I keep mine till the last.)
caption: The visual style is impressionistic. An individual with a contemplative expression tilts their head slightly in farewell. The background is blurred with shades of blue and green that give a sense of distance. The person raises one hand in a gesture of leave-taking, with outstretched fingers that suggest they have more to say but are choosing not to speak at this time.

The picture is surrealist - a man is holding a balloon that is slowly drifting away, while he looks dejectedly at it. In the background, there are friends and family, but they are too far away. The man is trying to say something, but he's waiting for the right time.

355-001.poem: On, on the Same, Ye Jocund Twain!
355-001.text: On, on the same, ye jocund twain!My life and recitative, containing birth, youth, mid-age years,Fitful as motley-tongues of flame, inseparably twined and merged inone--combining all,My single soul--aims, confirmations, failures, joys--Nor single soul alone,I chant my nation’s crucial stage, (America’s, haply humanity’s)--the trial great, the victory great,A strange eclaircissement of all the masses past, the eastern world,the ancient, medieval,Here, here from wanderings, strayings, lessons, wars, defeats--hereat the west a voice triumphant--justifying all,A gladsome pealing cry--a song for once of utmost pride and satisfaction;I chant from it the common bulk, the general average horde, (thebest sooner than the worst)--And now I chant old age,(My verses, written first for forenoon life, and for the summer’s,autumn’s spread,I pass to snow-white hairs the same, and give to pulseswinter-cool’d the same;)As here in careless trill, I and my recitatives, with faith and love,wafting to other work, to unknown songs, conditions,On, on ye jocund twain! continue on the same!
caption: The style is impressionistic, depicting a joyous dance between two figures, representing the speaker's life and experiences. The figures are intertwined, merging into one and representing the speaker's single soul. The background is a collage of different eras and cultures, including the eastern world, ancient and medieval times, and America. The triumphs, failures, and joys of the speaker's life and nation are depicted in a celebratory manner, culminating in a song of pride and satisfaction. The figures continue moving forward, passing on their legacy to future generations.

A mixed media artwork that combines painting and collage. The canvas is filled with bold and bright colors, with varying shapes and textures that reflect different stages of life. The painting tells the story of an individual and their nation, reflecting on past challenges and triumphs, and the hope for the future.

356-001.text: After surmounting three-score and ten,With all their chances, changes, losses, sorrows,My parents’ deaths, the vagaries of my life, the many tearingpassions of me, the war of ’63 and ’4,As some old broken soldier, after a long, hot, wearying march, orhaply after battle,To-day at twilight, hobbling, answering company roll-call, Here,with vital voice,Reporting yet, saluting yet the Officer over all.
caption: In the art style of realism, a portrait of an old man, a war veteran who has been through great loss and pain. He is standing, but hunched over, with a single tear rolling down his face. Behind him is a sunset horizon. To his right, a war memorial of his fallen comrades, and on his left, a group of young soldiers stand, paying their respects. Despite his age and weariness, he stands proud and salutes his commanding officer.

Realistic with a dark and moody overcast. A tired, elderly soldier is standing up straight, still saluting his superior officer after surviving many battles and personal losses. The brightness of his salute contrasts with the worn expression on his face.

357-001.text: A vague mist hanging ’round half the pages:(Sometimes how strange and clear to the soul,That all these solid things are indeed but apparitions, concepts,non-realities.)
caption: The picture is depicted in the style of impressionism. Fog surrounds half of the canvas. The other half is filled with blurred pages of a book. The pages are made to look like they are dissolving into the mist. Above the mist, there is a faint outline of something undefined, but the viewer gets the impression that it represents a spiritual world.

Surrealistic style. A blurred mist on half of an open book, with the other half in focus. The image is split in two, with one side showing solid objects and the other side depicting those objects as apparitions.

358-001.text: Somehow I cannot let it go yet, funeral though it is,Let it remain back there on its nail suspended,With pink, blue, yellow, all blanch’d, and the white now gray and ashy,One wither’d rose put years ago for thee, dear friend;But I do not forget thee. Hast thou then faded?Is the odor exhaled? Are the colors, vitalities, dead?No, while memories subtly play--the past vivid as ever;For but last night I woke, and in that spectral ring saw thee,Thy smile, eyes, face, calm, silent, loving as ever:So let the wreath hang still awhile within my eye-reach,It is not yet dead to me, nor even pallid.
caption: The visual style is impressionism. A painting of a pale funeral wreath hanging on a nail, with a dimly lit background of pink, blue and yellow hues, faded and blanched. A withered rose sits next to it. Although the colors have lost their vitality and turned gray, memories of the past remain vivid, causing the image of a dear friend to appear in the ring of the wreath. The smile, eyes, and face of the friend are portrayed, calm, silent and loving. The wreath appears to still have a presence, it is not yet dead, nor even pale.

Surrealism. A wilted rose suspended in the air with a faded wreath in the background. The rose represents memories and the wreath represents the past, though both are blanched and surrounded by a gray and ashy atmosphere. The rose suddenly comes to life, becoming vibrant and colorful as memories of a dear friend come flooding back.

359-001.text: The soothing sanity and blitheness of completion,The pomp and hurried contest-glare and rush are done;Now triumph! transformation! jubilate!
caption: A painting in the style of impressionism depicts a serene landscape - blue skies, green fields, and a calm stream. In the foreground, a figure stands with their arms raised, as if celebrating a victory.
Abstract expressionism. A chaotic, busy scene gradually giving way to a peaceful, serene one. The final image is a celebratory burst of color and energy.

360-001.text: From east and west across the horizon’s edge,Two mighty masterful vessels sailers steal upon us:But we’ll make race a-time upon the seas--a battle-contest yet! bearlively there!(Our joys of strife and derring-do to the last!)Put on the old ship all her power to-day!Crowd top-sail, top-gallant and royal studding-sails,Out challenge and defiance--flags and flaunting pennants added,As we take to the open--take to the deepest, freest waters.
caption: The picture is in the style of a vintage adventure comic book. Two large sailing ships approaching each other from the East and West. One ship's flag is raised as a challenge while the other raises defiance. The blue sea is rough and monstrous waves surround the ships. The sailors on both ships are ready for a battle of wills and skill on the high seas.

With an abstract style, picture two ships approaching from opposite sides of the horizon. The ships engage in a sea battle, with bright colors and energetic movement. The ships are adorned with flags and banners.

361-001.text: Have I no weapon-word for thee--some message brief and fierce?(Have I fought out and done indeed the battle?) Is there no shot left,For all thy affectations, lisps, scorns, manifold silliness?Nor for myself--my own rebellious self in thee?
caption: Surrealistic. A dark background with an abstract character holding an empty weapon. A smaller abstract character with multiple limbs is standing in a submissive position in front of the larger one. The larger character appears to be questioning if they have truly fought their inner demons with no words left to defend themselves or attack the controlled and affected image the smaller character portrays.

This picture is rendered in expressionist style. In it, one can see a person looking at their own reflection in a shattered mirror. Their hand is reaching towards the shards for a final weapon-word, as if they've already fought a long battle with themselves and with someone else.

361-002.text: Down, down, proud gorge!--though choking thee;Thy bearded throat and high-borne forehead to the gutter;Crouch low thy neck to eleemosynary gifts.
caption: This image would be done in a surrealist style. A proud, bearded man is seen bent forward, his throat and forehead pressed down to the ground as if being forced there. An outstretched hand holds out a small gift, while the man grovels on the ground to receive it. A narrow gorge looms in the background.
Surrealist. A gaping, bearded and proud gorge is being choked while its forehead is forced downwards towards a gutter. In the background, neck crouches low, begging for alms.

362-001.text: I doubt it not--then more, far more;In each old song bequeath’d--in every noble page or text,(Different--something unreck’d before--some unsuspected author,)In every object, mountain, tree, and star--in every birth and life,As part of each--evolv’d from each--meaning, behind the ostent,A mystic cipher waits infolded.
caption: The visual style could be surrealism. A detailed, close-up of a tree reveals faces hidden within its bark, while a mountain range in the background is depicted in a manner that looks almost like a mirage. The stars above seem to twinkle just a little bit brighter than usual, and each one appears to be connected in a complex pattern, like an intricate web. In the foreground, a baby's face appears to be emerging out of the landscape, and as the viewer looks closer, they will see that many other elements of life are also hidden within the picture, each one waiting to be discovered like a secret code or message.

The picture is a vibrant collage, featuring images of iconic songs, books and text, distinct and lesser-known authors, natural objects like mountains, trees and stars, and birth and life. Every object is connected and intertwined with each other and holds a deep, hidden meaning. The style is surrealistic with vibrant colors and complex imagery.

363-001.text: After a long, long course, hundreds of years, denials,Accumulations, rous’d love and joy and thought,Hopes, wishes, aspirations, ponderings, victories, myriads of readers,Coating, compassing, covering--after ages’ and ages’ encrustations,Then only may these songs reach fruition.
caption: The visual style is impressionism. The picture depicts a large tree with gnarled branches, reaching towards the sky. The background is a hazy, blurred image of books and papers scattered around the tree. The tree is surrounded by a group of people, their faces filled with joy and wonder as they gaze up at the tree. There is a feeling of growth and accumulation, with layers upon layers of branches and leaves covering the tree. The picture embodies the idea of patience and persistence, that only after a long, long course of growth, will the tree bear fruit.

In a surrealist style, a garden with an enormous, ancient tree surrounded by several layers of thick vines and moss representing the "ages' encrustations". At its base, the tree is surrounded by hundreds of different flowers and other plants that metaphorically represent the "hopes, wishes, aspirations, ponderings, and victories" of humanity throughout the ages.

364-001.text: Add to your show, before you close it, France,With all the rest, visible, concrete, temples, towers, goods,machines and ores,Our sentiment wafted from many million heart-throbs, ethereal but solid,(We grand-sons and great-grandsons do not forget your grandsires,)From fifty Nations and nebulous Nations, compacted, sent oversea to-day,America’s applause, love, memories and good-will.
caption: A vintage style photograph containing all of France's well-known landmarks, including churches, Eiffel Tower, factories, machinery, mining materials and other goods. The photograph shows a large gathering of people from many different nations, old and new. The sentiment of the photo is of love, memories, and goodwill. The atmosphere is ethereal, yet a solidified gathering of souls.

Photo-montage. A collage with many images - the Arc de Triomphe, the Eiffel Tower, intricate French architecture, bustling Parisian city streets, trolleys weaving through the crowds, a shipment of goods being loaded onto a ship, multilingual signs, and factories - all representing the production, people, and beauty of France. The montage is surrounded by a misty halo of colorfully attired people, each of different cultural origin, sending their love, admiration, and goodwill across the ocean to France.

365-001.text: Over and through the burial chant,Organ and solemn service, sermon, bending priests,To me come interpolation sounds not in the show--plainly to me,crowding up the aisle and from the window,Of sudden battle’s hurry and harsh noises--war’s grim game to sightand ear in earnest;The scout call’d up and forward--the general mounted and his aidesaround him--the new-brought word--the instantaneous order issued;The rifle crack--the cannon thud--the rushing forth of men from theirtents;The clank of cavalry--the strange celerity of forming ranks--theslender bugle note;The sound of horses’ hoofs departing--saddles, arms, accoutrements.
caption: Realistic. A soldier stands amongst a solemn church service, with priests and mourners gathered around. Suddenly, he hears the sounds of battle, and the emotions that come with it. The soldier imagines the sounds of rifles firing, cannons booming, and horses galloping into battle. The soldier is in the middle, with the church and war happening simultaneously.

The photograph is in a black and white photojournalistic style, captured moments of chaos and preparation for battle. Amongst the organized rows of mourners, soldiers hurry down the aisle, carrying weapons and accoutrements. The cavalry is heard clanking and marching as orders are shouted across the field.

366-001.text: Ah, whispering, something again, unseen,Where late this heated day thou enterest at my window, door,Thou, laving, tempering all, cool-freshing, gently vitalizingMe, old, alone, sick, weak-down, melted-worn with sweat;Thou, nestling, folding close and firm yet soft, companion betterthan talk, book, art,(Thou hast, O Nature! elements! utterance to my heart beyond therest--and this is of them,)So sweet thy primitive taste to breathe within--thy soothing fingersmy face and hands,Thou, messenger--magical strange bringer to body and spirit of me,(Distances balk’d--occult medicines penetrating me from head to foot,)I feel the sky, the prairies vast--I feel the mighty northern lakes,I feel the ocean and the forest--somehow I feel the globe itselfswift-swimming in space;Thou blown from lips so loved, now gone--haply from endless store,God-sent,(For thou art spiritual, Godly, most of all known to my sense,)Minister to speak to me, here and now, what word has never told, andcannot tell,Art thou not universal concrete’s distillation? Law’s, allAstronomy’s last refinement?Hast thou no soul? Can I not know, identify thee?
caption: A descriptive and abstract expressionist painting. The sun is setting on a window, casting a warm glow on an old and frail man who is sweating profusely. A cool and refreshing breeze enters the room through the open window, gently vitalizing him. The man's face and hands are being soothed by the breeze, which brings with it a sense of nature's elements. He feels the vastness of the sky, prairies, mighty northern lakes, oceans, and forests. The abstract figure of a messenger is present, represented by the breeze that is now whispering goodbye, but it leaves the man with a feeling of universal connections to all things.

Dreamlike and surreal. The picture shows a gust of wind entering through an open window and wrapping around the protagonist. A mixture of emotions can be seen on the person's face as they interact with the invisible entity, which pulsates with a cosmic energy.

367-001.text: An ancient song, reciting, ending,Once gazing toward thee, Mother of All,Musing, seeking themes fitted for thee,Accept me, thou saidst, the elder ballads,And name for me before thou goest each ancient poet.
caption: The visual style is watercolor. A woman with flowing hair holding an old book while looking up to the sky. Various figures from ancient tales, depicted in muted tones, surround her. Behind her, beautiful, rolling hills highlighted with warm red and orange hues.

Surrealist. A woman, who is also a tree, is holding an antique book, and is gazing at a sunset. The words "Mother of All" are etched behind her, and ancient poets surround the tree, each with the name of their work on their forehead.

367-002.text: (Of many debts incalculable,Haply our New World’s chieftest debt is to old poems.)
caption: Visionary. The image comprises of the outline of a landmass, overlaid in layers of light, and colors suggesting the history and depth of time. The land is surrounded by a series of ghostlike figures representing different periods in time. In the forefront, a group of figures carrying old books with light emanating from them, representing the debts owed to old poems, stands facing the land.
Surrealism. A depiction of a new world rising from a pile of old books that are gradually dissolving into the air. The world is vast, colorful and magical.

367-003.text: Ever so far back, preluding thee, America,Old chants, Egyptian priests, and those of Ethiopia,The Hindu epics, the Grecian, Chinese, Persian,The Biblic books and prophets, and deep idyls of the Nazarene,The Iliad, Odyssey, plots, doings, wanderings of Eneas,Hesiod, Eschylus, Sophocles, Merlin, Arthur,The Cid, Roland at Roncesvalles, the Nibelungen,The troubadours, minstrels, minnesingers, skalds,Chaucer, Dante, flocks of singing birds,The Border Minstrelsy, the bye-gone ballads, feudal tales, essays, plays,Shakespere, Schiller, Walter Scott, Tennyson,As some vast wondrous weird dream-presences,The great shadowy groups gathering around,Darting their mighty masterful eyes forward at thee,Thou! with as now thy bending neck and head, with courteous handand word, ascending,Thou! pausing a moment, drooping thine eyes upon them, blentwith their music,Well pleased, accepting all, curiously prepared for by them,Thou enterest at thy entrance porch.
caption: The picture is presented in a realistic style. The image features a person standing with a modest expression, looking at a group of individuals in front of them. Surrounding the group are different symbols of literature and epics from various regions, such as Egyptian and Chinese myths, Hindu epics, and biblical prophets. The image captures the immense influence of literature and culture on the person's identity, represented by the large group of historic figures looking on in awe. The person is depicted with a bowed head and eyes closed, lost in the sounds of the music. The scene suggests a moment of deep reflection for the person as they prepared to embark on their journey.

A vibrant collage of various cultures and eras depicted through historical and mythological characters, poets, musicians, and storytellers. A noble figure, their head bent in appreciation, surveys the surrounding stories with a sense of reverence before entering a grand entranceway. Art style: surrealist.

368-001.text: Welcome, Brazilian brother--thy ample place is ready;A loving hand--a smile from the north--a sunny instant hall!(Let the future care for itself, where it reveals its troubles,impedimentas,Ours, ours the present throe, the democratic aim, the acceptance andthe faith;)To thee to-day our reaching arm, our turning neck--to thee from usthe expectant eye,Thou cluster free! thou brilliant lustrous one! thou, learning well,The true lesson of a nation’s light in the sky,(More shining than the Cross, more than the Crown,)The height to be superb humanity.
caption: Art Nouveau style. An embracing figure with a beaming smile welcoming someone with open arms. In the background, a bright, sunny landscape with a shining star in the sky. The figure looks forward, symbolizing hope for a bright future.

The photograph is taken from a low angle to depict a bright Brazilian brother with a wide smile on his face. He stands in front of a sunny background while he is embraced lovingly by someone from the North. Their arms are outstretched towards the subject as they look at him with hopeful and expectant eyes.

369-001.text: Sounds of the winter too,Sunshine upon the mountains--many a distant strainFrom cheery railroad train--from nearer field, barn, house,The whispering air--even the mute crops, garner’d apples, corn,Children’s and women’s tones--rhythm of many a farmer and of flail,An old man’s garrulous lips among the rest, Think not we give out yet,Forth from these snowy hairs we keep up yet the lilt.
caption: The picture is done in a soft and warm painting style. The winter scene is set with a beautiful snowy mountain in the background. In the foreground, there are fields of harvested crops, including piles of apples and corn. The air is filled with sounds of the winter; from cheery railroad trains in the distance, to the whispers of the field, and the rhythm of many farmers and flails working together. The scene is completed with a hint of an old man's garrulous lips adding to the rest of the sounds. All of these sounds show that despite the snowy hairs of old age, they still keep up the lilt.

A painting in the impressionistic style with vibrant colors displaying a winter landscape dominated by picturesque snowcapped mountains. The landscape is complemented by a meandering train line, barns, and farmhouses producing varied sounds ranging from whispers in the air, crops being harvested, women and children speaking, and the rhythm of a farmer's flail while the geriatric elder onlooker muses his thoughts.

370-001.text: As I sit in twilight late alone by the flickering oak-flame,Musing on long-pass’d war-scenes--of the countless buried unknownsoldiers,Of the vacant names, as unindented air’s and sea’s--the unreturn’d,The brief truce after battle, with grim burial-squads, and thedeep-fill’d trenchesOf gather’d from dead all America, North, South, East, West, whencethey came up,From wooded Maine, New-England’s farms, from fertile Pennsylvania,Illinois, Ohio,From the measureless West, Virginia, the South, the Carolinas, Texas,(Even here in my room-shadows and half-lights in the noiselessflickering flames,Again I see the stalwart ranks on-filing, rising--I hear therhythmic tramp of the armies;)You million unwrit names all, all--you dark bequest from all the war,A special verse for you--a flash of duty long neglected--your mysticroll strangely gather’d here,Each name recall’d by me from out the darkness and death’s ashes,Henceforth to be, deep, deep within my heart recording, for manyfuture year,Your mystic roll entire of unknown names, or North or South,Embalm’d with love in this twilight song.
caption: The visual style is impressionistic. A solitary figure is sitting by a flickering fire under an oak tree. The figure is deep in thought and reminiscing about war scenes. Silhouettes of soldiers can be seen in the flickering flames. Ghostly images of soldiers from all parts of America (North, South, East, and West) rise from the flames before disappearing. The figure is surrounded by a dark mist and the names of unknown soldiers appear around them. The image captures the atmosphere of reflection and melancholy, as the figure remembers each name from the mystic roll, each one deep within their heart.

Photography style: Black and white documentary. A person sits alone in a dimly lit room, next to a flickering candle, lost in thought. As they reminisce about the aftermath of a war and the countless unknown dead, they begin to see images of ghostly soldiers arising in their mind's eye, whose names may never be known, but whose memory they vow to preserve for many years to come.

371-001.text: When the full-grown poet came,Out spake pleased Nature (the round impassive globe, with all itsshows of day and night,) saying, He is mine;But out spake too the Soul of man, proud, jealous and unreconciled,Nay he is mine alone;--Then the full-grown poet stood between the two, and took eachby the hand;And to-day and ever so stands, as blender, uniter, tightly holding hands,Which he will never release until he reconciles the two,And wholly and joyously blends them.
caption: Realistic with mystical elements. A man stands between two entities: a depiction of Mother Nature as a round globe with day and night patterns and a silhouette of a proud, jealous soul. The man holds hands with each, symbolizing a reconciliation between them. The surroundings exude a magical appearance with swirling, bright colors.

Realistic painting style. A man stands between the sun and the moon, as they both appear to argue over him. The man holds each hand, balancing himself between the two, determined to blend their two worlds together into a perfect harmony.

372-001.text: When his hour for death had come,He slowly rais’d himself from the bed on the floor,Drew on his war-dress, shirt, leggings, and girdled the belt aroundhis waist,Call’d for vermilion paint (his looking-glass was held before him,)Painted half his face and neck, his wrists, and back-hands.Put the scalp-knife carefully in his belt--then lying down, restingmoment,Rose again, half sitting, smiled, gave in silence his extended handto each and all,Sank faintly low to the floor (tightly grasping the tomahawk handle,)Fix’d his look on wife and little children--the last:
caption: The picture is in the style of a Renaissance portrait, with a man lying in bed, his face and body painted with red vermilion paint. He is putting on his shirt, leggings, and war dress, and is carefully placing a scalp-knife in his belt. He rises from his bed, extends his hand silently to his family, and smiles before resting for a moment. Finally, he sinks down, holding tightly onto his tomahawk, with his gaze fixed on his wife and children as his final act.

The photograph is in black and white with high contrast lighting. It shows a Native American man slowly getting out of bed and dressing himself in his warrior attire. A person holds a mirror up to him as he paints half his face and neck, wrists, and backhands with vermilion paint. He puts a scalp-knife carefully in his belt and lies down again to rest for a moment, before rising to sit up and extend his hand to his family.

372-002.text: (And here a line in memory of his name and death.)
caption: The visual style could be minimalist or abstract. It could be an image of a gravestone with a simple design or symbol, surrounded by flowers or candles. The overall feel could be one of somberness and reflection.
Minimalism - a frame with a solitary black line on a white background, creating a sense of emptiness and commemoration.

373-001.text: A voice from Death, solemn and strange, in all his sweep and power,With sudden, indescribable blow--towns drown’d--humanity bythousands slain,The vaunted work of thrift, goods, dwellings, forge, street, iron bridge,Dash’d pell-mell by the blow--yet usher’d life continuing on,(Amid the rest, amid the rushing, whirling, wild debris,A suffering woman saved--a baby safely born!)
caption: The image is done in a dramatic style, perhaps in dark and moody colors. The background of the picture is a devastated city. The city is in ruins with destroyed buildings, bridges and debris in the streets. In the foreground, we see a woman cradling a newborn baby with a look of relief on her face, both of them safe amidst the chaos. In the distance, we see Death himself, a silent, hooded figure surveying the wreckage.

The picture is a dark toned photo of a chaotic cityscape. Destroyed buildings, debris, and rubble scattered around the area. Amongst all this destruction, a newborn baby is being held by a rescue worker and a woman is being carried to safety. The photo captures the moment of tragedy and hope.

373-002.text: Although I come and unannounc’d, in horror and in pang,In pouring flood and fire, and wholesale elemental crash, (thisvoice so solemn, strange,)I too a minister of Deity.
caption: The visual style is abstract expressionism. The picture depicts a turbulent and fiery scene with a solemn and strange face emerging from the chaos. The figure can be seen as an ethereal minister of a higher power, bringing both horror and salvation to those watching the scene.
Surrealism. A figure, in the midst of chaos with fire and water raining down, holds a solemn expression. The overall mood captures the force of a divine being making an unpredictable appearance.

373-003.text: Yea, Death, we bow our faces, veil our eyes to thee,We mourn the old, the young untimely drawn to thee,The fair, the strong, the good, the capable,The household wreck’d, the husband and the wife, the engulfed forgerin his forge,The corpses in the whelming waters and the mud,The gather’d thousands to their funeral mounds, and thousands neverfound or gather’d.
caption: The picture is in black and white with a somber tone. The image shows a cemetery with tombstones and gravestones stretching as far as the eye can see. In the foreground, people are depicted bowing their heads and covering their faces with veils, as if mourning. The scene shows the loss of people, ranging from the old to the young, including the fair, the strong, the good, and the capable, with homes destroyed and couples taken away. The picture also portrays people lost in the waters and the mud and thousands left unburied.

In documentary style. A series of solemn and sorrowful shots, depicting people from all walks of life mourning and crying while they pay homage to their lost loved ones. The emotion is tangible as the camera lingers on the individuals and their grief, capturing their private moments of lamentation.

373-004.text: Then after burying, mourning the dead,(Faithful to them found or unfound, forgetting not, bearing thepast, here new musing,)A day--a passing moment or an hour--America itself bends low,Silent, resign’d, submissive.
caption: This image would likely be done in a painterly, classical style. It shows a somber view of a cemetery, with a few scattered mourners who are respectfully gathered around the gravestones. In the far background, an entire cityscape that represents America can be seen with bowed heads, conveying a sense of grief and solemnity as they pay their respects to the dead.
